By decreasing cAMP
By increasing cAMP

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 10:

A 30-year-old male, who works in a factory that manufactures explosives, came to the OPD with a peculiar complaint. He says that he gets headaches and feels transient dizziness every Monday after his weekend off. Exposure to which compound is likely to produce his symptoms?
Nitroglycerin
Benzodiazepines
Propranolo
Verapami



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
The patient is most likely suffering from Monday disease which is associated with exposure to nitroglycerin.
Continuous exposure to high levels of nitrates can occur in the chemical industry, especially where explosives are manufactured.
When contamination of the workplace with nitrate compounds is severe, workers find that upon starting their week, they suffer headaches and transient dizziness. After a day or so back at work, tolerance develops. Over the weekend, when exposure to the chemicals is reduced, tolerance disappears, so symptoms recur each Monday.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 11:

A 60 year old male is on verapamil for angina. Which of the following is not an adverse effect of this medication?

Gingival hyperplasia
Headache
Constipation
Tachycardia



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
Tachycardia is not an adverse effect of verapamil.
Verapamil has a direct negative chronotropic effect on the heart. It is more likely to cause bradycardia because of its significant cardio depressant action. Any reflex stimulation of heart due to peripheral vasodilation is effectively countered by the direct effect.
Common side effects of verapamil include headache, gingival hyperplasia, and constipation.

[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 13:
Cilnidipine is a novel dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that blocks both L- and N-type calcium channels.
Blockage of N-type calcium channels results in the reduction of sympathetic activity. It provides additional anti-hypertensive action without inducing reflex tachycardia.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 14:

Which of the following is more likely to precipitate angina?
Amlodipine
Nifedipine
Diltiazem
Verapami



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 14:
Amongst the given calcium channel blockers, nifedipine is more likely to precipitate angina.
Nifedipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker having a rapid onset and short duration of action. It results in an abrupt decrease in blood pressure resulting in reflex tachycardia.
Increased contractility leads to an increase in O2 demand which may precipitate angina.
Option A: Amlodipine and extended-release preparations of nifedipine do not cause a steep fall in blood pressure and subsequent activation of sympathetic tone. Therefore, they are less likely to precipitate angina.
Options C and D: Verapamil and diltiazem have relatively less action on peripheral vascular smooth muscles. They have a direct inhibitory effect on cardiac tissue causing negative ionotropic effect (verapamil > diltiazem).

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 17:

A 30-year-old athlete complained of chest pain during his practice sessions. He is diagnosed to be suffering from exertional angina and is prescribed atenolol. Which of the following changes are not caused by this drug?
Decrease in cardiac contractility
Decrease in heart rate
Decrease in blood pressure
Decrease in coronary collateral circulation



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 17:
Atenolol is a beta-blocker which increases the coronary collateral circulation, thereby increasing the blood flow towards the ischaemic region. This provides relief in exertional angina.
Beta-blockers decrease the heart rate, contractility, and arterial blood pressure. These effects are beneficial by decreasing the myocardial O2 demand. A decrease in heart rate increases the time available for myocardial perfusion.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 18:

Which of the following drugs can be used to balance the undesirable effects of beta-blockers in angina?
Verapami
Nitrates
Ivabradine
Diltiazem


[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 18:
Beta-blockers cause an increase in end-diastolic volume and ejection time. These effects can be balanced using nitrates by preferential venous dilatation, thus reducing preload.
Beta-blockers also block the baroreceptor mediated reflex tachycardia caused by nitrates due to vasodilation.
Options A and D: Verapamil and diltiazem are not combined with beta-blockers as they can cause additive suppression of SA node and AV nodal conduction.
Option C: Ivabradine is a pacemaker I(f) "funny" current inhibitor. Its addition does not reverse the undesirable effect but only adds to the bradycardia caused by beta blockers.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 19:

Which of the following drugs is associated with coronary steal phenomenon?
Dipyridamole
Diltiazem
Propranolo
Verapami



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 19:
Coronary steal phenomenon is seen with dipyridamole.
In patients with partial obstruction of coronary vasculature, a region of ischemia develops in the myocardium. In the absence of drugs, arterioles in the ischemic areas are usually maximally dilated as a result of local compensatory mechanisms.
When dipyridamole is administered, it acts as a nonselective arteriolar dilator. It can only dilate the vessels of the normal myocardium as the vessels of the ischemic myocardium are already maximally dilated. This diverts (steals) the blood away from the ischemic myocardium towards the normal myocardium. This is termed as coronary steal phenomenon.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 20:

Which of the following statements about ranolazine is not true?
It is recommended as first-line treatment for acute angina.
Hypotension is uncommon.
It improves glycemic control.
It is metabolised by CYP3A4



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 20:
Ranolazine is not recommended as a first-line agent for acute angina. It is approved as a second-line agent for chronic angina.
Ranolazine acts by reducing late sodium current (INa) that facilitates calcium entry via the sodium-calcium exchanger. The reduction in intracellular calcium concentration results in decreased cardiac contractility. Additionally, it also reduces cardiac fatty acid oxidation and stimulates glucose metabolism. It results in a small decrease in HBA1c, thus improving glycemic control.

It is metabolized by CYP3A4 and hence should not be used with CYP3A4 inhibitors such as macrolides, imidazole antibiotics, and HIV protease inhibitors.
The most frequent side effects are dizziness, headache, nausea, and constipation. Hypotension is uncommon.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 3:

A patient with Prinzmetal angina is administered isosorbide mononitrate and is noticed to have symptomatic relief. What is the mechanism of action of nitrate in this case?
Endothelium independent coronary vasodilation
Reduced cardiac contractility
Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume
Decreased diastolic perfusion pressure



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 3:
The mechanism of action of nitrates in prinzmetal angina is endothelium-independent coronary vasodilatation.
Prinzmetal angina occurs due to vasospasm of the coronary arteries. Nitrates relax the smooth muscles of epicardial coronary arteries and relieve coronary artery spasm.
In the case of stable angina, the primary mechanism of action of nitrates is preferential dilatation of veins (by increasing cGMP). Venous dilatation leads to a decrease in the venous return to the heart (preload). This decreases the ventricular end-diastolic volume and thereby a decrease in myocardial oxygen consumption. The diastolic perfusion pressure (aortic blood pressure in diastole - left ventricular pressure in diastole) is increased.

The sublingual route is used for the termination of attacks. Oral extended-release capsule and transdermal patch are used for prophylaxis. The onset of action is approximately 60 min.

Topical nitroglycerine ointment can be used to provide symptomatic relief in patients with anal fissures.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 7:

An 18-year-old boy was brought to the ER in an unconscious state. His coworker states he works in a factory manufacturing pesticides. Based on this, the medical officer suspects cyanide poisoning and administers sodium nitrite. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of this drug in this case?
Produces methemoglobinemia
Produces sulfhemoglobinemia
Produces carboxyhemoglobinemia
Produces deoxyhemoglobinemia


[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:
The mechanism of action of sodium nitrite as an antidote for cyanide poisoning is by the development of methemoglobinemia.
Cyanide binds to the cytochrome oxidase (complex IV) of the electron transport chain (ETC), thereby blocking it. When sodium nitrite is administered, it releases the nitrite ion. This ion binds to hemoglobin to form methemoglobin. The methemoglobin so formed, has a high affinity for the cyanide ion and binds to it, thus, detaching it from the cytochrome oxidase. This regenerates active cytochrome normalizing the function of ETC.
The cyanide ion with methemoglobin forms cyanmethemoglobin. Sodium thiosulphate is administered for the elimination of this compound. The thiosulfate forms thiocyanate ion with the cyanide and this is readily excreted.

subject: Pharmacology

AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 1:

Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line medication for an elderly patient with hypertension?
Hydrochlorothiazide
Furosemide
Chlorthalidone
Spironolactone



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 1:
The most appropriate first-line antihypertensive among the given drugs is chlorthalidone.
Thiazide diuretics are recommended as one of the first-line antihypertensive drugs for elderly patients without any comorbidities. Among them, guidelines recommend chlorthalidone over hydrochlorothiazide because of its longer duration of action.
First-choice drugs used in the treatment of hypertension in patients without any comorbidities include:
ACE inhibitors or ARBs: No evidence of superiority of one class over the other. However, ACE inhibitors have a higher risk of side effects like dry cough and angioedema.

Calcium channel blockers: Extended-release, long-acting dihydropyridines are preferred.

Thiazide diuretics: Chlorthalidone is usually preferred to hydrochlorothiazide.
Loop diuretics like furosemide and torsemide are less effective antihypertensives than thiazides. They are not indicated for the routine management of hypertension.
In the presence of any associated conditions or comorbidities, the first choice drugs for the treatment of hypertension would be as follows:

Comorbidities

Angina

Benign prostatic hyperplasia
 1 blockers
Pregnancy

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 10:

A pregnant woman with hypertension, on treatment with methyldopa, comes for routine evaluation. She is found to have a positive Coombs test but is asymptomatic. What is the next course of action for this patient?
Immediately stop methyldopa
Taper the dose of methyldopa
Monitor for signs of hemolysis
Switch to labetalo



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
The best course of action for the patient is close monitoring for any signs or symptoms of hemolysis.
Coombs test is done to test the presence of antibodies against Rh antigens on the red blood cells, which result in hemolysis. Positive Coombs test is seen in 20% of patients who receive methyldopa.
However, only 1-5% of such patients develop hemolytic anemia and hence, a positive Coombs test is not a necessary indication for stopping methyldopa treatment. They must be monitored closely and any signs that indicate hemolytic anemia needs prompt discontinuation of the drug.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 11:

Which of the following is not true about clonidine?
Reduction in central sympathetic flow
Prazosin completely antagonizes its action
Sedation and xerostomia are common side effects

It can be combined with vasodilators



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
Prazosin does not antagonize the effect of clonidine. Prazosin is a selective  1 receptor antagonist whereas clonidine is an alpha 2 receptor partial agonist.
On oral administration, clonidine stimulates alpha 2A receptors in CNS and results in decreased central sympathetic flow. This causes a decrease in BP.
However, on IV administration postsynaptic alpha 2B receptors are activated at higher doses which cause a transient rise in blood pressure. It also causes significant reductions in HDL lipids, apolipoproteins AI and AII.
It can be combined with vasodilators but has to be used with caution as potentiation of each other's actions can occur.

subject: Pharmacology

A patient presents with complaints of multiple episodes of intermittent palpitations, throbbing headache, and sweating. Blood pressure measured during one of these episodes is 210/120 mm Hg. The results of 24-hour urinary metanephrines were inconclusive. Which of the following could be used for diagnosis?
Phentolamine
Phenoxybenzamine
Clonidine
Prazosin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 12:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of pheochromocytoma. When first-line investigations like measurement of 24-hour urinary metanephrines are inconclusive, clonidine suppression test is used in the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma.
An oral dose of 0.3 mg clonidine is given, followed by the measurement of norepinephrine (NE)
concentration at 3 hours. A concentration of >500 pg/mL of NE indicates a positive test. Option A: Phentolamine test is not recommended due to its low sensitivity and specificity.
Options B and D: Phenoxybenzamine and prazosin are used in the treatment of pheochromocytoma but have no role in its diagnosis.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 15:

Which of the following drugs reduces blood pressure primarily by directly decreasing the heart rate?
Propranolo

Prazosin
Alpha methyl dopa
Nitroprusside sodium



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 15:
Propranolol reduces blood pressure by directly decreasing the heart rate. It is a nonselective
beta-blocker and blocks the beta 1 receptor of the heart (SA node) thus reducing the heart rate and blood pressure.
It also reduces renin secretion by blocking beta 1 receptors in JG cells. Reduction in renin release also contributes to blood pressure reduction.
Option B: Prazosin is a selective alpha 1 blocker and dilates both arteries and veins and may cause reflex tachycardia.

Option C: Alpha methyldopa is a selective alpha 2 receptor agonist. Alpha 2 receptors are autoreceptors present on the presynaptic membrane. On stimulation, central sympathetic discharge is reduced. Alpha methyldopa can indirectly reduce heart rate.
Option D: Nitroprusside is a vasodilator and may cause reflex tachycardia.

Options B and D: Amlodipine and felodipine are longer-acting dihydropyridines that are available in tablet forms. They are used for long-term treatment of hypertension.

Which of the following statements is incorrect about diazoxide?
It acts by causing prolonged opening of ATP dependent K+ channels in beta cells
It can cause severe hypoglycaemia
It can be used to treat patients with insulinoma
It is used as an antihypertensive agent



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 19:

Diazoxide causes hyperglycemia, not hypoglycemia.
Diazoxide is a potent K+ channel opener and opens up the ATP-sensitive K+ channel and thus prevents depolarization of pancreatic beta cells and subsequent insulin release. It is used in some cases of insulinoma to reduce insulin secretion and prevent hypoglycemia.
It was earlier used as an intravenous agent for hypertensive emergencies due to its strong vasodilatory action.

subject: Pharmacology

A pregnant woman with preeclampsia and is started on hydralazine. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the drug?
It decreases cerebral vascular resistance

Postural hypotension is not a common problem
It increases plasma renin activity



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 20:
Hydralazine causes preferential dilatation of arteries over veins.
Hydralazine acts directly on vascular smooth muscles. The precise mechanism is unknown but involves a decrease in intracellular Ca2+ concentrations.
Option A: It causes a selective decrease in vascular resistance in coronary, cerebral and renal circulation, with a smaller effect in skin and muscle.
Option C: Because of preferential dilatation of arterioles over veins, postural hypotension is not a common problem.
Option D: Hydralazine-induced vasodilation causes reflex activation of the sympathetic system through baroreceptor-mediated reflexes resulting in increased plasma renin activity.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 21:

The efficacy of an antihypertensive agent is being studied in a clinical trial. During the course of the trial, the researchers observed hair regrowth and generalized hypertrichosis in balding patients. What is the mechanism of action of the drug being studied?
Closes K+ channels in vascular smooth muscle
Activates K+ channels in vascular smooth muscle
Activates Ca2+ channels in vascular smooth muscle
Closes Ca2+ channels in vascular smooth muscle



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 21:
The antihypertensive drug with the side effect of excess hair growth is minoxidil and it acts by activating ATP-sensitive K+ channels in smooth muscles. This causes hyperpolarization that results in the relaxation of smooth muscles of arterioles.
Topical minoxidil is also used for the treatment of androgenetic alopecia.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 22:

A patient presented to the ER with severe headache and vomiting. On examination, the blood pressure was found to be 220/130 mm Hg and papilledema was also seen. What is the mechanism of the drug of choice for the condition?
Increased cAMP
Calcium channel blockage
Stimulation of guanylyl cyclase
K+ channel opener


[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 22:
The given scenario of severe hypertension (blood pressure 180/120 mmHg) with fundoscopic changes (flame haemorrhages and/or papilloedema) is suggestive of malignant hypertension. The drug of choice is IV nicardipine which acts by calcium channel blockage.
Nicardipine blocks the influx of extracellular calcium across the vascular and myocardial smooth muscle cell membranes by blocking the voltage-sensitive calcium channels during depolarization. The decrease in intracellular calcium causes dilation of the coronary and systemic arteries.
Other preferred agents for malignant hypertension are clevidipine with labetalol or esmolol. Note: Sodium nitroprusside is no longer the treatment of choice for acute hypertensive problems

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 23:

A patient with malignant hypertension is being managed with sodium nitroprusside infusion. He is at risk of developing all of the following adverse effects except?
Methhemoglobinemia
Cyanide toxicity
Drug-induced lupus syndrome
Thiocyanate toxicity



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 23:
Drug-induced lupus is not an adverse effect of sodium nitroprusside infusion.
When nitroprusside is administered at a high rate, it can result in the production of methemoglobin and cyanide. Cyanide is further metabolized to thiocyanate. On prolonged infusion, thiocyanate toxicity can also occur especially in patients with renal failure.

subject: Pharmacology

Solution to Question 24:
Hydrochlorothiazides are not given to this patient.
Gout is a metabolic disease associated with hyperuricemia.Thiazides increase direct urate reabsorption in the proximal renal tubules and are associated with elevated serum uric acid levels and may precipitate gout. Hence, hydrochlorothiazides are not used to treat hypertension in gout patients.

Within 30-90 minutes of the initial dose of prazosin or when the dosage is increased, there is marked orthostatic hypotension or syncope. This is known as the first-dose phenomenon. After a few initial doses, tolerance develops to this side effect. Initiating low doses at bedtime is recommended to minimize this phenomenon.

Absorbed Al3+ can contribute to osteoporosis, encephalopathy and proximal myopathy in CRF patients.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 3:

A patient on lithium therapy developed hypertension. He was started on thiazides for hypertension. After few days, he developed coarse tremors and other symptoms suggestive of lithium toxicity. Explain the likely mechanism of this interaction.
Thiazide inhibits the metabolism of lithium
Thiazides act as an add on drug to lithium
Thiazides increase the tubular reabsorption of lithium
Thiazides cause water loss therby increase lithium levels



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 3:
Thiazides act by increasing the tubular rabesorption of lithium.
Thiazide use is accompanied by sodium loss which is compensated in a few days by increased reabsorption of Na+ in the proximal tubule.
The kidney handles both lithium and Na+ in the same way. Thus, along with Na+ reabsorption, there will be an increase in the reabsorption of lithium also, resulting in decreased excretion of lithium.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 4:

A hypertensive patient on losartan requires an add on drug to achieve his blood pressure goal. Which of the following drugs will not increase the risk of hyperkalemia when added to his current medication?
Atenolo
Amiloride
Indapamide
Aliskiren



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 4:
Indapamide is a thiazide diuretic that increases K+ excretion decreases the risk of hyperkalemia associated with ACE inhibitors or ARBs such as losartan.
Option A: Beta-blockers can contribute to K+ retention by decreasing renin release and further reducing aldosterone secretion. Non-selective beta-blockers may also interfere with the cellular uptake of K+ ions.
Option B: K+ sparing diuretics like amiloride cause a decrease in K+ excretion and increase the risk of hyperkalemia.
Option D: Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor and increases the risk of hyperkalemia when combined with losartan.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 5:

Long term reduction of blood pressure by thiazide diuretics is mainly by which of the following mechanisms?
Reduction in extracellular volume
Reduction in sympathetic activity
Reduction in peripheral vascular resistance
Increase in extracellular volume



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
Long term reduction of blood pressure by thiazide diuretics is mainly due to a reduction in peripheral vascular resistance.
Thiazide diuretics initially decrease extracellular volume by their action on NaCl transporter in distal convoluted tubules in the nephrons. However, the compensatory response from activation of RAAS raises the extracellular volume returns almost to pre-treatment levels after a few weeks.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 6:

A diabetic patient is diagnosed with hypertension during his annual health check-up. What is the treatment of choice for him?
Chlorthalidone
Carvedilo
Captopri
Nifedipine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
ACE inhibitors such as captopril or ARBs can be considered as a treatment of choice in hypertensive patients with diabetes because of the renoprotective action. It benefits diabetic patients by reducing the risk of occurrence and progression of diabetic nephropathy.
They are also recommended in patients with CKD irrespective of diabetes status as they can delay the progression of nephropathy.
Option A: Thiazide diuretics worsen glycemic control and are not preferred in diabetic patients. Option B: Beta-blockers, especially non-selective blockers, worsen glycemic control.

Option D: Calcium channel blockers have a neutral effect on glycemic control and can be used in diabetes if ACE inhibitors or ARBs cannot be given.

explanation:

A patient is diagnosed with hypertension during routine health evaluation. Which of the following is not recommended as first-line therapy for him?
Verapami
Doxazosin
Metolazone
Quinapri


[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:
Alpha blockers like doxazosin are not recommended as first-line therapy for uncomplicated essential hypertension.
As per the European Society of Cardiology 2018 guidelines for hypertension, the classes of drugs recommended as first line therapy are:
ACE inhibitors
Angiotensin receptor blockers
Calcium channel blockers
Thiazide diuretics

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 8:

Which class of antihypertensive drugs has a favourable effect on lipid profile?
Thiazide diuretics
Beta blockers
Alpha 1 selective blockers
Calcium channel blockers



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:
Alpha 1 selective blockers have a favourable effect on lipid profile. They decrease plasma concentrations of triglycerides, total LDL-cholesterol and increase HDL cholesterol.
Option A: Thiazides increase plasma concentrations of triglycerides, LDL-cholesterol and total cholesterol. HDL may decrease or remain unchanged.
Option B: Non-selective beta-blockers increase triglycerides and decrease HDL levels. However, total cholesterol remains unchanged.
Option D: Calcium channel blockers have a neutral effect on the lipid profile.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 9:

Methyldopa is primarily used for which of the following conditions?
Hypertension in pregnancy
Renovascular hypertension
Hypertension with gout
Refractory hypertension



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 9:
Methyldopa is preferred for chronic hypertension in pregnancy based on its safety and efficacy data for both mother and fetus.
Antihypertensives found safe in pregnancy:
Hydralazine
Methyldopa
Dihydropyridine CCBs like nifedipine, amlodipine - however, they should be stopped before abor as they weaken the uterine contractions
Cardioselective beta-blockers and those with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity Antihypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy:
ACE inhibitors, Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARB)

Diuretics
Nonselective beta-blockers
Nitroprusside
Labetalol is considered the first-line agent for hypertensive emergency in pregnancy.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 1:

Choose the correct pair matching with the diagram:





A: Loop diuretics, B: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
A: Loop diuretics, B: Thiazides
A: Thiazides, B: Loop diuretics
A: Thiazides, B: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 1:
A is the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle and loop diuretics act on this part of the nephron.
B is the distal convoluted tubule and thiazides act on this part of the nephron. Site of action of other diuretics:
Proximal tubule - carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
Collecting ducts and late distal tubule - epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) inhibitors and aldosterone antagonists

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 10:

A patient with a glioblastoma multiforme is started on mannitol as palliative therapy. Which of the following statements is false regarding its diuretic action?
Renal blood flow is increased
Reduction in medullary tonicity
Extracellular fluid compartment is expanded
GFR is decreased


[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic. These drugs do not cause much change in the GFR.
Osmotic diuretics cause extraction of fluid from the intracellular compartment resulting in the expansion of the extracellular compartment. The renal blood flow increases and renin release is inhibited. An increase in renal medullary blood flow removes NaCl and urea from the renal medulla thus reducing medullary tonicity. There is not much change in the total GFR.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 11:

A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of swelling of both feet and of breathlessness on exertion. After evaluation, she was diagnosed with congestive cardiac failure. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in this patient?
Mannitol
Spironolactone
Furosemide
Hydrochlorothiazide



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
Mannitol is contraindicated in patients with cardiac failure.
Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic. It acts by extracting water from the intracellular compartments, which results in the expansion of the extracellular fluid. This results in volume overload and frank pulmonary edema in patients with cardiac failure.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 12:

A patient with hypertension is prescribed chlorthalidone. What would be the effect of this drug on the excretion of electrolytes?
A
B
C
D



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 12:
Chlorthalidone is a thiazide diuretic which increases Na+ and K+ excretion and decreases Ca2+ excretion.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 13:

Thiazide diuretics are not used in the treatment of which of the following conditions?
Idiopathic hypercalciuria with nephrocalcinosis
Hyperlipidemia
Congestive heart failure
Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 13:
Thiazide diuretics are not used in the treatment of hyperlipidemia. They result in an increase in the levels of LDL, total cholesterol, and triglycerides.
Option A: Thiazide reduces Ca2+ excretion and is used in the treatment of idiopathic hypercalciuria with nephrocalcinosis.
Option C: They are also used in the treatment of edema associated with CHF, hepatic cirrhosis, and nephrotic syndrome.
Option D: Thiazides are the mainstay for the treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. They reduce the kidney's ability to excrete free water. They increase proximal tubular water absorption and block the ability of DCT to form dilute urine.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 14:

A 45-year-old man with hypertension is prescribed chlorthalidone. Which of the following is unlikely to occur in this patient?
Hyponatremia
Hypokalemia
Erectile dysfunction

Hypocalcemia



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 14:
Hypocalcemia is unlikely to occur in a patient on chlorthalidone, a thiazide diuretic. Thiazide diuretics do not cause hypocalcemia. They result in hypercalcemia.
Thiazide and loop diuretics share similar side effects except that loop diuretics cause Ca2+excretion (loop loses calcium) whereas thiazides retain Ca2+ and cause hypercalcemia.
Other side effects of thiazide diuretics are:
Hypokalemia
Hyponatremia
Hypomagnesemia
Metabolic alkalosis
Hypercalcemia
Hyperuricemia

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 15:

A 42-year-old man in the nephrology ward has a GFR of less than 30mL/min, suggestive of severe renal failure. What is the best drug that can be given to him?
Chlorthalidone
Metolazone
Xipamide
Hydrochlorothiazide



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 15:
Metolazone is effective in severe renal failure (GFR<30ml/min).

Metolazone works primarily in the distal convoluted tubule, rather than the proximal convoluted tubule, and has little effect on GFR and can hence be used in patients with a reduced GFR. Indapamide is another thiazide diuretic that may be effective in severe renal failure.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 16:

A patient has been on lisinopril since being diagnosed with hypertension last year. His blood pressure readings are quite high, and the doctor considers adding a diuretic. Which amongst the following would be the ideal add on drug?
Spironolactone
Eplerenone
Hydrochlorthiazide
Amiloride



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 16:
Hydrochlorothiazide would be the ideal add-on drug. It is a thiazide diuretic and causes hypokalemia, which can counteract the hyperkalemia caused by lisinopril, an ACE inhibitor.
Aldosterone causes Na+ absorption in the collecting duct and the distal tubule in exchange for H+ and K+. ACE inhibitors decrease angiotensin II levels and thereby, decrease aldosterone levels.
Decreased aldosterone level causes K+ retention by reducing the exchange. Therefore, ACE inhibitors cause retention of K+.
Diuretics that cause elevation of plasma K+ levels are not suitable for combining with ACE inhibitors.
Potassium-sparing diuretics like spironolactone, eplerenone, and amiloride are contraindicated with ACE inhibitors.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 17:

A 10-year-old boy is brought with complaints of vomiting and lethargy after swallowing several pills of his father’s medication. Serum electrolytes indicate hyperkalemia. Which of the following drugs can you rule out?
Triamterene
Spironolactone
Amiloride
Indapamide



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 17:
Indapamide can be ruled out as it is a thiazide diuretic that causes hypokalemia. The other drugs are potassium-sparing diuretics that cause hyperkalemia.
K+ sparing diuretics work by 2 mechanisms:
Blocking the ENaC (epithelial sodium channel)
Triamterene
Amiloride
Aldosterone receptor antagonist
Spironolactone
Eplerenone
Canrenone

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 18:

Which of the following diuretics do not need to be present in the tubular lumen for pharmacological action?
Thiazide diuretics
Loop diuretics
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
Aldosterone antagonists



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 18:
Aldosterone antagonist acts from the interstitial side of the tubular cells. They do not have to be present in the tubular lumen for their action.
Aldosterone antagonists enter the tubular cells from the basolateral membrane. They competitively inhibit the binding of aldosterone to mineralocorticoid receptors.

Thiazide diuretics, loop diuretics, ENaC inhibitors, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors have to be present in the lumen for its action. They are all secreted from the proximal tubule into the tubular fluid through the organic anion/ cation transport process.
Osmotic diuretics reach the lumen via glomerular filtration.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 19:

Canrenone is a metabolite of:
Acetazolamide
Spironolactone
Eplerenone
Metolazone



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 19:
Canrenone is a metabolite of spironolactone.
Spironolactone is metabolized completely in the liver. It is also converted to an active metabolite, canrenone that is responsible for more than 50% of the spironolactone action. Spironolactone has a half-life of 1-2 hours while canrenone has a half-life of around 18 hours.
Eplerenone is an aldosterone receptor antagonist similar to spironolactone and metabolized primarily by CYP3A4, but no active metabolites have been identified.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 2:

Diuretics acting on which part of the nephron have maximum efficacy?
Proximal tubule
Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle
Collecting tubule
Distal tubule



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 2:
Loop diuretics have the maximum efficacy. They act on the thick ascending loop of Henle by blocking Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter.
Option A: Although 65% of Na+ is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule, diuretics acting here do not have maximum efficacy. This is because the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle has a great reabsorptive capacity and it absorbs most of the filtrate from the proximal tubule.
Options C and D: Diuretics acting distal to the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle have limited efficacy because most of the reabsorption of Na+ (>90%) would have already occurred by the time the tubular fluid reaches there.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 20:

A 52-year-old man with alcoholic cirrhosis develops ascites. What is the drug of choice for management?
Chlorothiazide
Acetazolamide
Spironolactone
Mannitol



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 20:
The diuretic of choice in a patient with cirrhotic ascites is spironolactone.
Spironolactone is a competitive inhibitor of the mineralocorticoid receptor in the late distal tubule and collecting duct of the kidneys. It causes a decrease in sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the distal tubule. As a result, spironolactone promotes sodium diuresis but maintains body potassium levels.
Spironolactone is particularly helpful in edematous states caused or exacerbated by hyperaldosteronism such as in cirrhotic ascites.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 21:

Which of the following is not a side effect seen in a patient receiving spironolactone?
Gynaecomastia
Hyperkalemia
Metabolic alkalosis
Renal insufficiency



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 21:
Aldosterone antagonists cause hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis and not metabolic alkalosis. They inhibit H+ secretion in parallel with K+ secretion thus resulting in acidosis.
Other side effects are:
Hyperkalemia
Gynecomastia
Renal insufficiency.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 22:

Which of the following is not an indication for amiloride use?
Lithium induced polyuria
Cystic fibrosis
Calcium nephrolithiasis
Liddle syndrome



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 22:
Amiloride is not used in the treatment of calcium nephrolithiasis. The condition is sometimes treated with thiazide diuretics but not amiloride.

Amiloride is a K+ sparing diuretic that acts by inhibiting the epithelial Na+ channels. The various uses of amiloride are:
Edema/hypertension - usually in combination with thiazides
Lithium-induced polyuria - blocks lithium transport into collecting tubules
Cystic fibrosis - aerosolized amiloride enhances mucociliary clearance; acts by inhibiting Na+ absorption from epithelial surfaces and increasing hydration of secretions
Liddle syndrome - hyperactive epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) activity is reduced



The diuretic effect of theophylline is due to the blockade of adenosine (A1) receptors. Theophylline is a methylxanthine drug that acts by -
Inhibition of phosphodiesterase enzyme (PDE)
PDE3 inhibition - relaxation of bronchial smooth muscle
PDE4 inhibition - inhibition cytokines and chemokine release, which leads to a decrease in immune cell migration and activation
Blockade of adenosine receptors inhibits bronchoconstriction, however, blockade of A1 receptors in the glomerular afferent arteriole and PCT causes diuresis.
Activating enzyme histone deacetylase-2, which is responsible for its anti-inflammatory action

Anti-Arrythmic Drugs

subject: Pharmacology

Which of the following statements about furosemide is true?

Acute pulmonary edema is an indication
Acts on the proximal convoluted tubules
Causes mild diuresis
Given only by parenteral route



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 3:
Furosemide is indicated in acute pulmonary edema. It is a loop diuretic that acts on the thick ascending loop of Henle and inhibits Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter.

Loop diuretics have maximum efficacy amongst all the diuretics and are therefore called high ceiling diuretics. They can be given by both the oral and parenteral routes.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

A 70-year-old man with pulmonary edema is started on furosemide. Which of the following would you not expect after starting the drug?
Hyperglycemia
Hypomagnesemia
Hypokalemia
Acidosis



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 4:
Furosemide causes metabolic alkalosis.
The adverse effects of furosemide (loop diuretics) are:
Hypovolemia
Hyponatremia
Hypokalemia
Hypocalcemia
Hypomagnesemia
Hyperuricemia
Increased LDL-C and decreased HDL-C
Glucose intolerance - hyperglycemia
Ototoxicity

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 5:

High ceiling diuretics are used in the treatment of all of the following patients except:
40-year-old man with anasarca
35-year-old woman with a head injury and cerebral edema
56-year-old woman with acute pulmonary edema
48-year-old man with pulmonary hypertension



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
High ceiling diuretics are not used in pulmonary hypertension.
High ceiling or loop diuretics have diuretic properties as well as vasodilatory action.
Diuretic property - removing excess fluid in hepatic, renal, and cardiac diseases
Vasodilatory action - quick symptomatic relief of symptoms in LVF and acute pulmonary edema. They are also used for the treatment of chronic CHF.
Pulmonary artery hypertension is a condition where there is increased pulmonary vascular resistance. Since nitric oxide is an important regulator of pulmonary vascular resistance, PDE5 inhibitors like sildenafil, vardenafil or tadalafil are primarily used in the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 6:

A 65-year-old woman with chronic kidney disease was given a diuretic intravenously. Following administration of the drug, she developed tinnitus and diminished hearing. Which of the following drugs was most likely given?
Thiazide
Spirinolactone
Ethacrynic acid
Triamterene



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
Ethacrynic acid is the diuretic that was most likely given as it is commonly associated with ototoxicity.
Ototoxicity occurs with rapid intravenous infusion and the hearing impairment and deafness are usually reversible.
Ethacrynic acid should be used only in patients who are not able to tolerate other loop diuretics.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 7:

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors do not cause:
Increased bicarbonate excretion
Urinary alkalinization
Metabolic alkalosis
Potassium loss



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors do not cause metabolic alkalosis. They cause metabolic acidosis due to increased bicarbonate excretion
Option B: Increased bicarbonate excretion causes urinary alkalinization.
Option D: Increased delivery of Na+ to distal tubules causes increased K+ excretion.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 8:

Which of the following can be administered intravenously?
Brinzolamide
Dorzolamide
Acetazolamide
Methazolamide



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:
Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that can be administered intravenously. It is indicated in the acute management of angle-closure glaucoma for the rapid reduction of IOP before surgery. The oral formulation is given for open-angle glaucoma.
Options A and B: Brinzolamide and dorzolamide are available only as ophthalmic drops and used in open-angle glaucoma.
Option D: Methazolamide is available as an oral formulation and used for open-angle glaucoma.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 10:

A patient presented to the ER with dizziness and palpitations. ECG is shown below. Which of the following drugs cannot be used in this condition?


Digoxin
Verapamil
Quinidine

Lignocaine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
The scenario and ECG findings (absent P waves and RR intervals that are irregularly irregular) are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Lignocaine is not used in atrial arrhythmias.
Lignocaine is a class 1B anti-arrhythmic agent. It blocks Na+ channels mostly in the closed/inactivated state. It is not used in atrial arrhythmias because the atrial action potential is so short that the Na+ channels are in a closed/ inactivated state for only a brief amount of time.
Lignocaine is used in the acute treatment of ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation. Drugs mostly used for supraventricular arrhythmia are:
Adenosine
Verapamil
Diltiazem
Digoxin
Drugs used for ventricular arrhythmia are:
Lidocaine
Mexiletine
Drugs used in both conditions are:
Amiodarone
Beta-blockers
Class 1a / 1c antiarrhythmics

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 11:

Which of the following is incorrect regarding lignocaine?
Gastrointestinal absorption is good
High volume of distribution
In heart failure patients, both loading and maintenance doses are decreased
Indicated for prophylaxis of arryhythmias in all cases of suspected MI



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
Lignocaine decreases the incidence of arrhythmias in patients with suspected MI. However,
it increases mortality probably by precipitating heart block or congestive heart failure. Hence it is not routinely used for prophylaxis in MI patients but it is used only when indicated.
Gastrointestinal absorption of lignocaine is good but bioavailability is very less due to high first-pass hepatic metabolism. Therefore, it is not used through the oral route.
Lignocaine has a high volume of distribution. The loading dose is required to achieve rapid action.
In heart failure, both volumes of distribution and clearance are reduced. Both the loading dose and maintenance dose have to be reduced.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 12:

Which of the following is a correct statement regarding antiarrhythmics?
Sotalol has additional class II action
Esmolol has additional class IV action
Propranolol has additional class I action
Both A and C



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 12:
Sotalol has both class II (beta-blocker) and class III action (K+ channel blockade). Though it is a nonselective beta-blocker, as an antiarrhythmic, it is classified under class III.
Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker with additional membrane-stabilizing action especially at higher doses: Na+ channel blockade/ class I action.
Esmolol is a beta 1 selective blocker that does not have any additional class effect.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 13:

A 60-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of bluish discoloration of the skin on the sun-exposed areas. He has been on medication for monomorphic ventricular tachycardia for the past 3 years. Which drug is most likely implicated in this condition?
Lidocaine
Adenosine
Amiodarone
Mexiletine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 13:
The scenario is suggestive of blue man syndrome which is most likely caused by amiodarone.
One of the side effects of amiodarone is photosensitivity. In some cases, bluish discoloration of the skin is seen, predominantly in the sun-exposed areas. This could be due to the immune response in dermal layers by amiodarone or the accumulation of amiodarone in superficial layers of skin.
The symptoms are reversible on drug discontinuation. The syndrome is related to both dose and photosensitivity.
The side effects of amiodarone include:
Pulmonary fibrosis
Hypotension, depressed ventricular function
Torsades de pointes
Corneal microdeposits
Hepatotoxicity
Neuropathies
Photosensitivity
Thyroid dysfunction
Other such syndromes associated with drugs are:
Red man syndrome - Vancomycin
Gray baby syndrome - Chloramphenicol

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 14:

Chronic usage of an antiarrhythmic drug leads to optic neuritis and smurf skin or ceruloderma in a patient. Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of this drug?
K+ and Na+ channel blockade
Ca2+ channel blockade

Adrenergic blockade
Cl- channel blockade



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 14:
Optic neuritis and smurf skin (blueman syndrome or ceruloderma) are caused by
amiodarone. It acts by blocking K+, Na+, and Ca2+ channels. It also blocks adrenergic effects. It does not block Cl- channels.

Amiodarone is classified as a class III antiarrhythmic agent. It exerts its function through the following mechanisms:
Blockade of transient outward delayed rectifier and inward rectifier K+ currents
Blockade of inactivated Na+ channels with a rapid rate of recovery
Decreases Ca2+ current
Non-competitive adrenergic blockade
It is the drug of choice for acute treatment of VT and VF. The side effects of amiodarone include:
Pulmonary fibrosis
Hypotension, depressed ventricular function
Torsades de pointes
Corneal microdeposits
Hepatotoxicity
Neuropathies
Photosensitivity
Thyroid dysfunction

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Which of the following adverse effects is least likely in a patient who is on chronic amiodarone therapy?
Dry cough
Corneal microdeposits
Hepatic dysfunction
Nephrotoxicity



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 15:
Nephrotoxicity is not an adverse effect of chronic amiodarone therapy. Pulmonary
fibrosis associated with dry cough is the most serious side effect of chronic amiodarone therapy. It can rapidly progress and become fatal.
The side effects of amiodarone include:
Pulmonary fibrosis
Hypotension, depressed ventricular function
Torsades de pointes
Corneal microdeposits
Hepatotoxicity
Neuropathies
Photosensitivity
Thyroid dysfunction

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 16:

Which of the following antiarrhythmic drugs is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease?
Amiodarone
Sotalol
Quinidine
Lignocaine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 16:
Amiodarone is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease.

The most serious adverse effect during chronic amiodarone therapy is pulmonary fibrosis, which can be rapidly progressive and fatal. Underlying lung disease, doses of 400 mg/day or more, and recent pulmonary insults such as pneumonia appear to be risk factors for this condition.
Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug. The side effects of amiodarone include:
Pulmonary fibrosis
Hypotension, depressed ventricular function
Torsades de pointes
Corneal microdeposits
Hepatotoxicity
Neuropathies
Photosensitivity
Thyroid dysfunction

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 17:

Which of the following statements about dronedarone is incorrect?
It does not contain iodine moiety
Has stronger antiadrenergic effects than amiodarone
Less effective antiarrhythmic when compared to amiodarone
Dose adjustment has to be done in renal failure



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 17:
Dronedarone undergoes hepatic metabolism and hence dose adjustment is not required in renal failure as it is not excreted through the kidneys.
Dronedarone is a non-iodinated congener of amiodarone. Like amiodarone, it is a blocker of multiple ion channels. It has stronger antiadrenergic effects than amiodarone. It is less effective in maintaining sinus rhythm and is considered less antiarrhythmic when compared to amiodarone.
Unlike amiodarone, it does not cause thyroid dysfunction or pulmonary fibrosis. However, it causes hepatotoxicity and increases the risk of stroke and heart failure.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 18:

Given below is the ECG of a patient who presented to the emergency room with sudden onset palpitations and breathlessness. Which of the following drugs can be used in this condition?



Atropine
Mexiletine
Verapamil
Lidocaine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 18:
The clinical scenario and the ECG findings are suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Verapamil and diltiazem are used in both acute treatment and prophylaxis of PSVT.
Their mechanism of action is by slowing SA node automaticity and AV nodal conduction velocity. Additionally, they also decrease cardiac contractility and reduce blood pressure.
Dihydropyridines like nifedipine and amlodipine do not have any antiarrhythmic property. Drugs used for supraventricular arrhythmias are:
Adenosine
Verapamil
Diltiazem

Digoxin
Drugs used for ventricular arrhythmias are:
Lidocaine
Mexiletine
Drugs used in both conditions are:
Amiodarone
Beta-blockers
Class 1A / 1C antiarrhythmics

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 19:

Vernakalant is indicated in which of the following types of arrhythmias?
Ventricular fibrillation
Atrial fibrillation
Atrial flutter
Ventricular flutter



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 19:
Vernakalant is a newer antiarrhythmic agent indicated in atrial fibrillation. Its mechanisms of action include:
Frequency and voltage-dependent block of the early and late components of the sodium current
The muscarinic potassium current IKACh, which is constitutively activated in atrial fibrillation is also blocked
It is indicated for rapid termination of atrial fibrillation in patients with no or minimal structural heart disease.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 2:

The additional mechanism by which class 1A drugs additionally prolong action potential duration is:
Blocking Na+ channels
Opening Na+ channels
Blocking K+ channels
Opening K+ channels



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 2:
Class IA antiarrhythmics block K+ channels leading to prolongation of action potential duration. The main action of class IA antiarrhythmics is blocking Na + channels causing:
Slowing the upstroke of the action potential
Slowing conduction
Prolonging the QRS duration

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 20:

A patient presented with palpitations and light-headedness. His ECG is shown below. Which of the following drugs is least likely to cause this condition?



Quinidine
Disopyramide
Procainamide
Lidocaine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 20:
The given scenario and the ECG findings (rapid asynchronous complexes and an undulating baseline) point towards a diagnosis of torsades de pointes. Lidocaine use is unlikely to cause this condition.

Lidocaine belongs to class IB antiarrhythmics. It is considered to have the least arrhythmogenic potential among antiarrhythmics.
Among the antiarrhythmics, class Ia and class III drugs prolong action potential duration and thus prolong QT interval. They are also prone to cause torsades de pointes.

The drug of choice for the termination of PSVT is adenosine. Drugs used for supraventricular arrhythmias are:
Adenosine
Verapamil

Drugs used for ventricular arrhythmias are:
Lidocaine

Amiodarone
Beta-blockers

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 22:

A patient who was recently diagnosed with a seizure disorder presents to the casualty with altered mental status. His ECG shows a prolonged QTc. There is history of sudden cardiac deaths in his family at an early age. On further evaluation, a diagnosis of congenital long QT syndrome is made. Which is the most suitable pharmacological agent to treat this condition?
Metoprolol
Mexilitine
Nicorandil

Isoprenaline



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 22:

Beta-blockers like metoprolol are the mainstay of pharmacological therapy in both asymptomatic and symptomatic patients with congenital LQTS. They reduce both syncope and sudden cardiac death (SCD).
Long QT syndrome (LQTS) is a disorder of ventricular myocardial repolarization characterized by a prolonged QT interval on the electrocardiogram that can lead to symptomatic ventricular arrhythmias and an increased risk of sudden cardiac death.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 23:

An elderly patient with heart failure and atrial fibrillation is stabilized with digoxin. By what mechanism does it control the arrhythmia in this patient?
Vagolytic action
Sympatholytic action
Increasing vagal tone
Decreasing atrial repolarization by blocking Na+ channels



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 23:
Digoxin results in an increased vagal tone which helps in controlling the ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation.
Increased vagal tone increases the AV nodal refractoriness due to blockade of Ca2+ channels. It also results in hyperpolarisation and shortening of atrial action potentials due to activation of ACh-mediated K+ channels in the atria.



The given clinical scenario is suggestive of torsades de pointes. Only amitriptyline causes this condition, among the above drugs.
Torsades de pointes (French: twisting of points) is a life-threatening form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with rapid asynchronous complexes and an undulating baseline on ECG.


Hypolipidemic Drugs

It causes prominent anticholinergic side effects like urinary retention, dry mouth, blurred vision, precipitation of glaucoma, and constipation.
It is the drug of choice for vagally mediated atrial fibrillation such as sleep-induced or atrial fibrillation in athletes.

QT prolongation is seen with quinidine.

Blurred vision in a patient being treated for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is most likely due to:

[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:
Blurred vision is the most common dose-related non-cardiac adverse effect of flecainide therapy.
Flecainide is a class 1C antiarrhythmic agent. It acts mainly by sodium channel blockade. It does not cause any change in the action potential duration.
Flecainide is used in paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVTs):
Atrioventricular nodal re-entrant tachycardia (AVNRT)
AV re-entrant tachycardia (AVRT)

Solution to Question 9:
Sotalol is a class III antiarrhythmic agent with additional beta-adrenergic blocking effects. (class II antiarrhythmic action)

Propranolol is a class II antiarrhythmic agent that has an additional Na+ channel blocking effect. (class I antiarrhythmic action)
Esmolol is a short-acting beta-blocker with minimal/no action on cardiac Na+ and K+ channels.

Statins act on the HMG-CoA reductase enzyme, thus inhibiting cholesterol synthesis.



Note: Necrotizing myopathy is a newly defined form of idiopathic inflammatory myopathy. Patients who have anti-HMG Co-A reductase antibodies should not be given statins to control

high cholesterol as they may develop this type of statin-induced necrotizing myopathy.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 10:

What is the drug of choice for type IIa and IIb hyperlipoproteinemias?
Statins
Fibrates
Niacin
Bile acid sequestrants



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
The drugs of choice for type IIa and IIb hyperlipoproteinemias are statins.
In type IIa or IIb hyperlipoproteinemias, there is increased LDL cholesterol with +/- increase in TG. Statins have the maximum LDL lowering property among the hypolipidemic drugs.
Therefore, they are the drugs of choice in this case.
In type III/IV hyperlipoproteinemias, there is mainly an increase in triglyceride(TG) level. Fibrates reduce the TGs contained in VLDL and increase the HDL. So they are the drugs of choice for these conditions.



Mipomersen is an antisense oligonucleotide that acts as an inhibitor of apo B-100 synthesis.
Mipomersen binds to the mRNA of apo B-100 resulting in degradation of apo B-100 mRNA and eventually reduction of apo B-100 synthesis.

Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone System

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 2:

Hepatic cholesterol synthesis is maximal between midnight and 2 am. So most of the statins are preferably administered in the evening for maximal effect. Which statin can be taken irrespective of the time of the day?
Simvastatin
Pravastatin
Atorvastatin
Lovastatin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 2:
Atorvastatin has a longer half-life (19 ± 9 hours) and may be taken at any time of the day. Other drugs that can be taken irrespective of the time of day:
Rosuvastatin - has a half-life of 20 ± 6 hours
Pitavastatin - has a half-life of 12 hours
All other statins, which have a plasma half-life of around 4 hours or less, should preferably be administered in the evening.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 3:

A patient with hypercholesterolemia on statin therapy presents to your OPD for follow-up. You notice his cholesterol is still high and decide to add on another drug that directly inhibits the absorption of cholesterol. Which of the following will you prescribe?
Ezetimibe
Orlistat
Cholestyramine
Niacin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 3:
Ezetimibe is the drug that prevents hypercholesterolemia by directly inhibiting the absorption of cholesterol.
Ezetimibe acts by interfering with a specific cholesterol transport protein NPC1L1 in the intestinal mucosa and reduces the absorption of both dietary and biliary cholesterol. It causes
a compensatory increase in hepatic cholesterol synthesis but LDL cholesterol is decreased. Statins block this enhanced cholesterol synthesis (cholesterol synthesis inhibitors) and so their combination has a synergistic effect.
Option B: Orlistat is an anti-obesity drug that acts by inhibiting pancreatic and gastric lipase and thus interferes with the digestion and absorption of dietary triglycerides.
Option C: Cholestyramine is a bile acid sequestrant. The bile-acid sequestrants are highly positively charged and bind negatively charged bile acids. Because of their large size, the resins are not absorbed, and the bound bile acids are excreted in the stool.
Cholestyramine primarily reduces LDL levels by increasing hepatic bile acid synthesis; which results in increased LDL uptake and diversion of cholesterol to bile acid production.
Option D: Niacin reduces lipolysis by hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) and reduces hepatic triglyceride synthesis.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 4:

Which drug decreases Lipoprotein(a)?
Fenofibrate
Niacin
Gemfibrozi
Colestipo



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 4:
The drug that decreases Lipoprotein(a) is niacin.
Niacin is the only lipid-lowering agent that lowers lipoprotein(a) levels significantly. It also results in a decrease in LDL, VLDL, and triglycerides along with an increase in HDL cholesterol.
The main adverse effect of niacin is cutaneous flushing and pruritus which can be controlled by pretreatment with aspirin. Niacin can also cause hepatotoxicity, GI toxicity, and hyperuricemia.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 5:

Which of the following drugs would you warn a patient taking statins against, due to the highest risk of myopathy?
Fenofibrate
Gemfibrozi
Colestipo
Niacin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
Myopathy risk is highest when statins are used along with gemfibrozil.
Gemfibrozil is a fibrate that inhibits the uptake of statins into the hepatocytes and prevents its metabolism, thereby increasing its bioavailability. Thus, the risk of toxicity of statins increases.
Other drugs interacting similarly with statins include:
Cyclosporine
Digoxin
Warfarin
Macrolide antibiotics
Azole antifungals.
Option A: Fenofibrate does not have much interaction with statins.
Option C: Colestipol is a bile acid sequestrant and does not have much effect on statin metabolism.
Option D: Niacin can also rarely increase the risk of statin-induced myopathy but the risk is much lower than that with gemfibrozil. So here gemfibrozil is the best answer.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 6:

A patient who is on statin therapy asks about a new drug called evolocumab that his friend is taking for hyperlipidemia. What is the route of administration of this drug?
Intramuscular
Intraderma
Subcutaneous
Intravenous



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
Evolocumab is a PCSK-9 inhibitor that is administered as a subcutaneous injection.
PCSK-9 is a protease that binds to the LDL receptors on the surface of hepatocyte and enhances the lysosomal degradation of the LDL receptor. This results in higher plasma LDL levels. inhibition of PCSK-9 results in a reduction of plasma LDL levels.
Two approved PCSK-9 inhibitors are alirocumab and evolocumab.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 7:

Which among the following is a microsomal triglyceride transfer protein inhibitor?
Ticlopidine
Gugulipid
Lomitapide
Evinacumab



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:
Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) inhibitor is lomitapide.
MTP adds triglycerides to nascent VLDL in the liver and to chylomicrons in the intestine. Its inhibition decreases VLDL secretion and thus decreases the accumulation of LDL in the plasma. It is approved for use in homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia.
Options A: Ticlopidine is an antiplatelet agent.
Option B: Gugulipid is a plant extract that is commonly used for hyperlipidemia but has very little/no evidence to support its use.

Option D: Evinacumab is a recently approved angiopoietin-like 3 (ANGPTL3) inhibitor. It is indicated as an adjunct to other LDL-cholesterol lowering therapies for homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia in adults and pediatric patients aged 12 years and older.

subject: Pharmacology

A patient with hereditary hyperlipoproteinemia is prescribed a fibrate. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
Increased lipolysis of triglycerides
Inhibit lipolysis in adipose tissues
Inhibit HMG CoA synthetase
Binds bile acids and bile salts in the intestine



[EXPLANATION START]

Fibrates increase the lipoprotein lipase activity through PPAR- and cause increased lipolysis of triglycerides.
Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is a key enzyme in the degradation of VLDL. Fibrates bind to PPAR alpha and cause stimulation of lipoprotein lipase enzyme. Increased LPL synthesis enhances the clearance of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins. Additionally, fibrates also stimulate fatty acid oxidation and reduce the expression of apo C-III (inhibitor of lipolysis).

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 9:

A 45-year-old obese man presented to your OPD. His lipid profile showed elevated levels of cholesterol and triglycerides. On examination, you notice palmar xanthomas. What is the drug of choice for his condition?
Statins
Niacin
Fibrates
Alirocumab



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 9:
The given scenario of elevated cholesterol and triglycerides along with the presence of palmar xanthomas (pathognomonic sign) is indicative of type III hyperlipoproteinemia. The drugs of choice for this condition are fibrates.
Fibrates are also preferred in patients having severe hypertriglyceridemia (TG >1000 mg/dl) who are at risk for pancreatitis.
The response to fibrate therapy in Type III hyperlipoproteinemia patients include:
Elevated cholesterol and triglyceride levels are dramatically lowered.
Tuberoeruptive and palmar xanthomas may regress completely.
Angina and intermittent claudication also improve. The image below shows palmar xanthoma.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

A 40-year-old diabetic male is on ACE inhibitors for hypertension. Which among the following is the most serious adverse effect you would expect to see in this patient?
Hypotension
Hypokalemia
Hypocalcemia

Hypercalcemia



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
The most significant adverse effect seen with the use of ACE inhibitors is hypotension.
ACE inhibitors are used in the management of hypertension and are one of the first-line drugs for this condition.
Option B: ACE inhibitors may cause hyperkalemia in patients with renal insufficiency or diabetes. Options C and D: ACE inhibitors do not affect calcium levels significantly.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 11:

A 40-year-old man is diagnosed with hypertension and is prescribed losartan. Which of the following statements about the drug is incorrect?
It is a competitive angiotensin receptor antagonist
It attenuates platelet aggregation
Associated with negligible cough
Causes hyperuricemia



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
Losartan use is not associated with hyperuricemia. In fact, losartan is uricosuric and can also be used in patients with gout.
Losartan is a competitive angiotensin II receptor antagonist. It binds to the AT1 receptor with high affinity. it is also a competitive antagonist of the thromboxane A2 receptor and attenuates platelet aggregation. Losartan has no effect on ACE and it does not inhibit bradykinin breakdown. This results in negligible incidences of cough.




The combined use of ACE inhibitors and ARBs are not commonly indicated as they increase the risk of hyperkalemia.
They also increase the risk of hypotension and renal injury. Any such use should be done under the supervision of specialists with frequent monitoring.
