subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 5:

A patient with a history of mania, on lithium therapy, is brought with complaints of vomiting and multiple episodes of diarrhea. On examination, coarse tremors and an ataxic gait are noted. What is the expected level of serum lithium in this patient?
> 1.2 mEq/L
> 0.8 mEq/L
> 1.5 mEq/L
> 0.5 mEq/L



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
Clinical features are suggestive of lithium toxicity, where serum levels >1.5 mEq/L are considered toxic.
Lithium has a narrow therapeutic index (0.8–1.2 mEq/L) and therefore requires monitoring to suspect toxicity. The toxic effects of lithium usually start manifesting when the serum level crosses
1.5 mEq/L.
Acute intoxication is characterized by:
Vomiting
Profuse diarrhea
Coarse tremors
Ataxia
Coma
Convulsions.
A fine action tremor is common in patients taking lithium at therapeutic doses and can develop at any time during treatment. Therapeutic lithium tremor is generally symmetric, limited to the arms, and nonprogressive.Tremor from lithium toxicity is coarser and more disabling, may also affect the legs, and occurs with other symptoms of toxicity.
Serious effects of lithium toxicity will involve confusion, hyperreflexia, and seizures. Motor and cognitive side effects can become irreversible with persistent cerebellar tremor being the most common.

> 2.0 mEq/L

In acute overdoses, hemodialysis is indicated in:
Serum lithium level is > 4.0 mEq/L
Patients exhibiting symptoms of toxicity.

subject: Pharmacology

Lithium is not indicated in generalized anxiety disorder. Bipolar disorder is the primary indication for lithium.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 8:

Which of the following must be administered initially in patients with acute mania with psychotic features?
Lithium
Olanzapine
Carbamazepine
Sodium valproate



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:
In acute mania, even in patients without overt psychotic manifestations, atypical antipsychotics like olanzapine is used initially for rapid control of psychosis. Atypical antipsychotics are also effective as monotherapy.
The therapeutic effects of lithium, carbamazepine, and valproic acid are seen only after a few days. Therefore they are effective only with daily dosing with adequate serum monitoring.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

A patient with mania has been initiated on lithium therapy. While counseling the patient about the medication, which of the following effects do you mention as the most common CNS adverse effect?
Ataxia
Slurred speech
Fine tremors
Coarse tremors



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 9:
The most common CNS adverse effect of lithium in the therapeutic dose range is fine postural hand tremors. Therapeutic lithium tremor is generally symmetric, limited to the arms, and nonprogressive.
Options A and B: Ataxia, slurred speech, and/or incoordination are adverse effects seen during peak CNS/serum concentrations. Single bedtime dosing can avoid these adverse effects.
Option D: Coarse tremors are seen in case of lithium toxicity and is more disabling and may also affect the legs.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 1:

Which of the following drugs crosses the blood-brain barrier?
Dopamine
Levodopa
Both A and B
Carbidopa



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 1:
Levodopa crosses the blood-brain barrier.
It is a naturally occurring aromatic amino acid and an immediate precursor of dopamine that can cross the blood-brain barrier. Dopamine does not cross the blood-brain barrier because of the polar nature of the molecule. Levodopa is also a polar compound but it can cross the blood-brain barrier through an aromatic amino acid transporter.
Therefore, levodopa is used therapeutically when dopamine is required for central action. Levodopa is converted to dopamine by the decarboxylase enzyme.
Carbidopa is a peripheral decarboxylase inhibitor and does not penetrate the blood-brain barrier.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 10:

Which of the following dopamine agonists is an ergot derivative?
3, 4 and 5
1, 2 and 3
1 and 2
4 and 5



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
Bromocriptine and pergolide are ergot derivatives that act as potent agonists at the D2 receptor. Pramipexole and ropinirole are non-ergot derivatives having D2/D3 receptor agonistic action.
They are better tolerated and have fewer GI symptoms than bromocriptine.

Dopamine agonists can be classified as follows:
Ergot derivatives - Bromocriptine, pergolide, cabergoline
Non-ergot derivatives - Pramipexole, ropinirole, apomorphine, rotigotine
Dopaminergic agonists exert subtype-selective activation of dopaminergic receptors involved in the Parkinsonism circuit of the striatum.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 11:

A 50-year-old female patient visits the OPD with complaints of burning sensation associated with an irresistible urge to move her legs since 2 weeks. It occurs especially at night and the discomfort gets relieved on moving her legs. Which is the first-line drug that can be prescribed for this patient?
Benztropine
Gabapentin

Riluzole
Clonazepam



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
The symptoms in this patient are suggestive of restless leg syndrome and gabapentin is the first-line choice of treatment for this condition.
Restless leg syndrome is a typical sensory-motor disorder that generally affects the legs during rest periods, especially sleep. There is an irresistible urge to shake the legs associated with burning sensation, itching, and cramps of the legs. In idiopathic cases, dopaminergic hypofunction is postulated.
In patients with restless legs syndrome, iron stores are initially repleted, and the aggravating factors are eliminated. If RLS still persists, initial therapy with a gabapentinoid (pregabalin, gabapentin, gabapentin enacarbil) are preferred, rather than a dopamine agonist (pramipexole, ropinirole, rotigotine). This is due to the high frequency of intermediate and long-term augmentation with dopamine agonists, as well as their risk of impulse control disorders.
FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of restless leg syndrome:
Gabapentin
Ropinirole
Pramipexole
Rotigotine
A dopamine agonist is used as an alternative in patients with increased risk for side effects from gabapentinoids, such as those with obesity and its complications, a past or present history of moderate to severe depression, a disorder causing gait instability or respiratory failure, and a history of substance use disorder.
Option A: Benztropine is an anticholinergic that can be used for drug-induced parkinsonism. Option C: Riluzole is a benzothiazole derivative that is used in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.
Option D: Benzodiazepines like clonazepam can be used as co-adjuvant drugs in the treatment of restless leg syndrome but should not be used as first-line therapy.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of drug-induced parkinsonism, for which the drug of choice is benzhexol, also known as trihexiphenidyl.
Drug-induced parkinsonism is caused by certain drugs that have D2 antagonistic action, such as typical antipsychotics. Due to the decrease in dopaminergic activity, they result in an unbalanced cholinergic activity. Benzhexol is a centrally acting antimuscarinic agent. It acts by restoring the cholinergic balance in the striatal interneurons.
The following drugs are implicated in drug-induced parkinsonism:

Typical antipsychotics
Phenothiazines, haloperidol
Atypical antipsychotics
Risperidone, olanzapine
Dopamine depleters
Reserpine, tetrabenazine
Antiemetics
Metoclopramide, levosulpirid e
Calcium channel blocke rs
F unarizine, cinnarizine

Antidepressant and Antianxiety Drugs

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 2:

A 55-year-old is diagnosed with Parkinson's disease and is started on levodopa therapy. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the drug?
In parkinsonism, phenothiazines reduce its efficacy
It is a prodrug
Pyridoxine reduces effect of levodopa in parkinsonism
Domperidone reduces levodopa induced emesis and its therapeutic potentia



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 2:
Domperidone is an antidopaminergic antiemetic that can reverse levodopa-induced emesis without affecting the therapeutic potential as it cannot cross the blood-brain barrier.
The antiemetic effect is through its action on CTZ which is outside the blood-brain barrier.
Option A: Typical antipsychotics like phenothiazines can reduce the efficacy of levodopa because of its central D2 blocking property.
Option B: Levodopa is a prodrug. It is converted into dopamine by the decarboxylase enzyme in CNS.
Option C: Pyridoxine can reduce the effect of levodopa by increasing its peripheral conversion to dopamine by potentiating peripheral dopa decarboxylase enzyme.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 3:

After initiation of levodopa therapy, a 55-year-old patient starts experiencing adverse effects. Which of these side effects is not decreased by the addition of carbidopa?
Nausea and vomiting
On and off effect
Cardiac arrhythmias
Hallucinations



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 3:
Behavioral adverse effects like confusion, hallucinations, nightmares, delusions, postural hypotension are not reduced after the addition of carbidopa.
In fact, they are increased in patients who are taking levodopa with peripheral decarboxylase inhibitors. This is because higher levels of dopamine are formed in CNS.
The combination of levodopa with peripheral decarboxylase inhibitors like carbidopa inhibits peripheral adverse effects of dopamine. This decreases the adverse effects like:
Anorexia, nausea, and vomiting
Cardiac arrhythmias
On and off effect of motor performance

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 4:

A 60-year-old male is brought to the casualty in a confused state. On examination, he has severe muscle rigidity. His son says that the patient is on treatment for Parkinson's disease but has forgotten to take his medication as they went on a holiday trip. What is the likely

diagnosis in this patient?
Wearing off phenomenon
On / Off phenomenon
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
Serotonin syndrome



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 4:

Abrupt withdrawal of levodopa or dopaminergic agonists can precipitate neuroleptic malignant syndrome. It is characterized by extreme rigidity, confusion, and hyperthermia.
It is an emergency condition that can turn fatal if immediate intervention is not done. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is commonly associated with the use of typical antipsychotics.
Option A: Wearing off phenomenon - Each dose of levodopa improves mobility for a period of 1-2 hours. After that, the effect of the drug wears off, and rigidity and akinesia return. This can be surpassed by increasing the dosing and frequency.
Option B: On/off phenomenon - Rapid fluctuation between on and off periods.
On period: When the patient has a beneficial effect of the medications but with disabling dyskinesias
Off period: No beneficial effects from anti-Parkinsonism medications.
'Wearing off' and 'On / Off' phenomenon occur with long-term treatment of levodopa. Option D: Serotonin syndrome occurs with co-prescription of MAO-inhibitors and SSRIs.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

A patient on long-term treatment with levodopa and carbidopa for Parkinson's disease is diagnosed with on/off phenomenon. Which of the following drugs is used to treat this condition?
Safinamide
Amantadine
Benztropine
Domperidone



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
Safinamide is used for the treatment of the on/off phenomenon. Management of On/Off phenomenon:
To prolong the 'On' phase:
COMT inhibitor - entacapone, tolcapone
Irreversible MAO-B inhibitor - selegiline, rasagiline
Reversible MAO-B inhibitor - safinamide.
Rescue from 'Off' phase: injection apomorphine
Dopaminergic agonists like pramipexole, ropinirole, and rotigotine are also effective in the treatment of the on/off phenomenon.

Haloperido
Chlorpromazine
Trifluperazine
Quetiapine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of levodopa-induced psychosis for which quetiapine is the most appropriate treatment.
Quetiapine and clozapine are the two atypical antipsychotics that are most effective and best tolerated in levodopa-induced psychosis.
Typical antipsychotics are effective against levodopa-induced psychosis but may cause marked worsening of parkinsonism. Hence, atypical antipsychotics are deemed safer.

Ropinirole
Amantadine
Apomorphine

Entacapone is a peripheral COMT inhibitor that increases the bioavailability of levodopa.
It inhibits the peripheral metabolism of levodopa thereby increasing the bioavailability of levodopa.
Options B and D: Ropinirole and apomorphine are dopamine receptor agonists and do not have any significant effect on levodopa bioavailability.
Option C: Amantadine which is an antiviral drug is also anti-Parkinsonian due to its varied actions including increased release and decreased uptake of dopamine. It has no significant effect on the bioavailability of levodopa.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Which of the following anti-Parkinsonism drugs is correctly matched with its mechanism of action?
Tolcapone - COMT inhibition
Rasagiline - Muscarinic antagonism
Amantidine - MAO-B inhibition
Apomorphine - Inhibition of dopa



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:
Tolcapone and entacapone are selective, potent, and reversible COMT (catechol-O-methyl transferase) inhibitors.
COMT metabolizes levodopa and blockade of this pathway prolongs the half-life of levodopa and allows a larger fraction of the administered dose to reach the brain.
Option B: Rasagiline is a selective MAO-B inhibitor.
Option C: Amantadine acts by antagonism of the NMDA type of glutamate receptors.
Option D: Apomorphine is a dopaminergic agonist that is FDA-approved as a 'rescue therapy' for the acute intermittent treatment of 'off' episodes.

subject: Pharmacology

Which of the following statements is false regarding the use of selegiline in Parkinsonism?

Incidence of cheese reaction is minima
May be used for on / off phenomenon
It forms amphetamines as metabolites



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 9:
Selegiline acts as a selective MAO-B inhibitor.
At higher doses, MAO-A can also be inhibited. Higher doses are used for depression and administered in the form of the transdermal patch.
Option B: Selective MAO-B inhibitors do not interfere significantly with the peripheral metabolism of dietary amines and do not cause cheese reaction.
Option C: It has lower efficacy than levodopa but when added with levodopa it prolongs its action and also decreases the wearing-off effect of levodopa.
Option D: Selegiline forms metabolites like amphetamine and methamphetamine that can result in anxiety, insomnia, and other undesirable effects. Rasagiline, unlike selegiline, does not form amphetamines as metabolites.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 1:

Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of antidepressants?
Change in neurotransmitter receptor sensitivity
Decrease in level of neurotransmitters
Change in efficacy of neurotransmitters
Increase the reuptake of neurotransmitters



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 1:

Antidepressants increase levels of neurotransmitters at the synapse by preventing their reuptake. Due to a prolonged increase in the levels of neurotransmitters, there is a change in neurotransmitter receptor sensitivity which is thought to be the major mechanism responsible for the treatment of depression.
Chronic treatment with a number of antidepressants desensitizes presynaptic autoreceptors and heteroreceptors, producing long-lasting changes in monoaminergic neurotransmission.
Postreceptor effects of antidepressant treatment, including modulation of GPCR signaling and activation of protein kinases and ion channels, are involved in the mediation of the long-term effects of antidepressant drugs.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 10:

A 30-year-old woman having depression took multiple tablets of amitriptyline in an attempt to commit suicide. Which of the following statements regarding the management is incorrect?
Physostigmine is not recommended
Sodium bicarbonate should be administered to treat acidosis
Atropine sulphate should be administered as an antidote
Diazepam should be injected to control seizures



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
Tricyclic antidepressants like amitriptyline are competitive antagonists of muscarinic receptors. Atropine being an antimuscarinic drug should not be administered.
Tricyclic antidepressant overdose presents with anticholinergic effects. Hypotension occurs because of alpha1 receptor blockade.
TCAs act on Na+ channels and cause slowed conduction and depressed cardiac contractility resulting in serious arrhythmias. Seizures and agitation may occur followed by depression.
Management of TCA overdose:
Initial resuscitation by securing airway, breathing, and circulation.
Hypotension - IV fluids and norepinephrine infusion.

Cardiac-depressant effects - bolus dose of sodium bicarbonate helps overcome Na+ blockade by increasing extracellular Na+. It also addresses metabolic acidosis which is often present.
Arrhythmias - lignocaine for ventricular arrhythmias.
Seizures - benzodiazepines like diazepam/lorazepam.
Physostigmine can reverse anticholinergic effects but can aggravate cardiac depression and cause seizures. Therefore physostigmine is not recommended.

Solution to Question 12:
Duloxetine should be avoided as it is contraindicated in patients with closed-angle glaucoma. SNRIs like duloxetine and milnacipran have anticholinergic side effects like mydriasis which can precipitate closed-angle glaucoma attacks.
Duloxetine is the longest-acting SNRI with no withdrawal symptoms. In addition to the treatment of depression and anxiety, it is also used in fibromyalgia, peripheral neuropathy, and stress incontinence.
Option A: Venlafaxine is the shortest acting SNRI with the maximum risk of withdrawal symptoms. It is approved for use in PTSD, panic disorder, and depression associated with hypotension. It is contraindicated in pregnancy.
Option C: Desvenlafaxine is a longer-acting SNRI and hence has lesser risk of withdrawal symptoms.
Option D: Fluoxetine is an SSRI, not an SNRI. It is avoided as it can cause mydriasis and narrow the angle.

[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 15:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of drug discontinuation or withdrawal symptoms which are seen after sudden discontinuation of SSRIs. Fluoxetine has the least risk of causing drug-discontinuation symptoms.

Nausea

Flu-like symptoms
Insomnia
Irritability

Withdrawal is least with fluoxetine as its metabolite norfluoxetine has the longest half-life. Thus the plasma level of norfluoxetine is maintained for a long time even after stopping the drug, minimizing withdrawal symptoms. Withdrawal is seen maximum with paroxetine.

Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) mainly used to treat major depressive disorder or generalized anxiety disorder.
Nausea is the commonest side effect of SSRIs as they target the 5HT3 receptor.
Vivid dreams may occur because the drug suppresses REM sleep (the stage of dream), hence when patients eventually fall into REM sleep it may be more intense.
Anorgasmia is the persistent inability to achieve orgasm despite responding to sexual stimulation. A proposed mechanism of escitalopram causing sexual dysfunction involves stimulation of the 5HT2C receptors.



Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) should be used carefully in the young for the management of depression due to increased suicidal ideation. In children and adolescents, there appears to be a slightly increased risk of suicidal ideations and attempts, but not of completed suicide.
Somatic symptoms of depression improve faster than psychological symptoms when a patient is started on SSRIs and hence patients have the energy to act on their thoughts of deliberate
self-harm and suicide (paradoxical suicide).

Opioids - Functions and Classification

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 5:

A college student on MAO inhibitor therapy for depression consumed two bottles of beer during a party. The next day he started experiencing severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. Tyramine
Tyrptophan
Threonine
Thiamine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical presentation of a hypertensive crisis in a patient on MAO inhibitor therapy is suggestive of cheese reaction, which is seen after consumption of foods rich in tyramine (beer).
Tyramine is an indirect sympathomimetic. It induces the release of catecholamines from the neurons. Tyramine can be produced in high concentrations in protein-rich foods by decarboxylation of tyrosine during fermentation.
Normally tyramine is inactivated when taken orally because it is readily metabolized by MAO in the liver. In patients who are on MAO inhibitor therapy, the tyramine taken in the diet is not inactivated and results in its increased sympathomimetic effect resulting in elevated blood pressure, termed as hypertensive crisis or cheese reaction. Drug of choice for cheese reaction is IV phentolamine.
When MAO inhibitors are taken along with SSRI or TCA, it results in serotonin syndrome due to the overstimulation of 5HT receptors. The clinical features are a triad of:
Cognitive effect - delirium, coma
Autonomic effects- hypertension, tachycardia
Somatic effects- myoclonus, hyperreflexia, tremors

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 1:

A middle-aged woman with resistant intractable back pain is planned to receive neuraxial opioids for analgesia. Which of the following is the site of action of this drug in the spinal cord?
Ventral horn of spinal cord
Dorsal horn of spinal cord
Lateral horn of spinal cord
No spinal component is seen with opioid analgesia



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 1:
The spinal component of opioid analgesia is seen due to the action in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
Opioid analgesia:
Spinal component: opioids act in the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn to inhibit the release of excitatory transmitters like substance P from primary afferents carrying pain impulses. This action is through interneurons that are involved in the gating of pain impulses.
Supraspinal component: action at the medulla, periaqueductal gray matter, limbic, and cortical areas alter the processing and interpretation of pain impulses. It also sends inhibitory impulses through descending pathways to the spinal cord.
Peripheral action: acts on small primary afferent terminals in the skin or deeper structures, decreasing their sensitization following tissue injury.

Contraindications to the use of Morphine:
Bronchial asthma: Histamine release can cause bronchoconstriction and precipitate attacks of asthma.

Adjuvants are indicated only for mild pain

Intravenous route is preferred



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 19:
The true statement is the use of morphine falls under step 3 of WHO analgesic ladder for chronic pain in adults.
WHO has developed 3 step ladder for chronic/cancer pain relief in adults. The 3 main principles are as follows:
By the clock: Drugs should be given “by the clock” or “around the clock” rather than
“on-demand”.
By the mouth: The oral route is preferred. If not feasible, the least invasive route should be considered.
By the ladder: Drugs are given in the following order, Non-opioids  Mild opioids  Strong opioids. Adjuvants are added at any stage of the WHO ladder to relieve anxiety.
Note: This 3-step ladder approach is inexpensive and 80-90% effective when utilized optimally.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 11:

A 60-year-old man was posted for bronchoscopy under procedural sedation. After the administration of anesthetic drugs, he developed chest wall rigidity and ineffective spontaneous ventilation. Attempts at manual ventilation were unsuccessful due to the
non-compliant chest wall. The opioid that is most commonly associated with this condition is?
Morphine
Fentany
Pethidine
Tramado



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
Chest wall rigidity and ineffective ventilation is a classic presentation of 'wooden chest syndrome'. This opioid-induced muscle rigidity is most commonly associated with the use of lipophilic opioids such as fentanyl and its congeners (alfentanil, sufentanil, and remifentanil).
Risk factors for wooden chest syndrome:

Rapid administration of a large dose of fentany
Concomitant use of nitrous oxide
Old age
The clinical presentation can vary from mild hoarseness to chest wall rigidity severe enough to prevent adequate bag-and-mask ventilation.
Management of wooden chest syndrome:
Discontinuation of the opioid
Replacement of the opioid with a non-lipophilic version (such as hydromorphone or morphine) for analgesia
Consider naloxone for reversal (you do not want to reverse analgesia on an intubated patient unless absolutely necessary)
Addition of a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker for paralysis
Supportive ventilatory care

Infusion-related chills and rigors associated with amphotericin B, aldesleukin, trastuzumab, and alemtuzumab are also managed with meperidine in combination with other agents.

It is used parenterally as an analgesic for moderate to severe pain or as an adjunct to general anesthesia.
Opioids available for intranasal administration are butorphanol and fentanyl.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 20:

A 40-year-old man, on treatment with fluoxetine for depression, was started on an opioid for severe neuropathic pain. A few days later he had an episode of syncope and was brought to the casualty. ECG taken is given below, with QTc = 477 ms. Which of the following drugs is most likely the cause?


Morphine
Meperidine
Methadone
Propoxyphene



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 20:
The given ECG findings show QT prolongation which is associated primarily with the use of methadone.
In the ECG QTc(corrected QT interval= QT/RR) is 477ms. Normal QTc is about 440ms. Values of more than 440ms in males and 460ms in females are considered to be prolonged. QT prolongation can present as syncope or cardiac arrest.
Methadone has additive action with agents known to cause QT prolongation. Serious cardiac arrhythmias including torsades de pointes have been noted with methadone use.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Long acting mu receptor agonist
Used for chronic pain relief
Rapidly absorbed from GIT and appears in plasma within 30 min of oral administration
Onset of analgesia is 30-60 min after parenteral and 1-2 h after oral administration


[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 21:
Methadone’s onset of analgesia is 10-20 minutes after the parenteral route, and 30-60 minutes after the oral route of administration.
Option A: Methadone is a long-acting mu receptor agonist with a plasma half-life of 15-40 hours. Option B: It is an analgesic and used for chronic pain relief.
Option C: Absorption from GIT is rapid and appears in plasma within 30 minutes and reaches peak concentrations at around 4 hours.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 22:

A young man is scheduled for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. His medical history is significant for depression and he is on monoamine oxidase inhibitors for the same. Which of the following opioids can be safely administered to him?
Tramado
Meperidine
Dextromethorphan
Morphine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 22:
Morphine can be safely administered as it does not inhibit the neuronal reuptake of serotonin and hence does not trigger serotonin syndrome in patients on MAO inhibitors.
Phenylpiperidine series of opioids such as meperidine, tramadol, dextromethorphan,
and methadone inhibit the neuronal reuptake of serotonin leading to serotonergic overactivity. This can cause serotonin syndrome in patients receiving monoamine oxidase inhibitors.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 23:

A woman sustained multiple fractures in a motorcycle accident. Her physician prescribed an oral opioid for analgesia which is a partial agonist at mu and a full agonist at kappa receptors. Identify the drug given.
Pentazocine
Buprenorphine
Tramado
Fentany



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 23:
Pentazocine is a partial agonist at mu and a full agonist at kappa receptors. Analgesia produced by pentazocine is predominantly mediated by the  receptor.
Pentazocine is a mixed agonist-antagonist opioid agent. It is a full agonist at the  receptor and a partial agonist or weak antagonist at the µ receptor.
Buprenorphine is a partial agonist at mu receptors but an antagonist at kappa receptors.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 24:

A cancer patient is dependent on morphine for pain management. His physician decides to switch him to buprenorphine. Due to which property he chooses this new drug?
Partial agonism at mu receptor
Partial agonism at kappa receptor
Partial antagonism at mu receptor
Partial antagonism at kappa receptor



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 24:
Buprenorphine is a partial agonist at the mu receptor with a lower intrinsic activity compared to morphine and hence does not produce withdrawal symptoms in patients with morphine dependence.
Buprenorphine is a synthetic thebaine congener and also acts as an antagonist at kappa receptor.
It is more potent than morphine at mu receptor but with lower intrinsic activity and ceiling effect. Due to lower intrinsic activity, it has no withdrawal symptoms and can be used in the treatment of morphine dependence.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 25:

An elderly man with bone metastasis is receiving intravenous opioids for pain management. Which of the following drugs can be safely administered to him without a risk of developing respiratory depression?
Morphine

Buprenorphine
Fentany
Alfentany



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 25:
Buprenorphine can be safely administered to this patient because of its ceiling effect on respiratory depression.
Ceiling effect is defined as no further increase in the effect of the drug with a further increment in dose, once the ceiling level is reached.
Opioid agonist-antagonist compounds produce respiratory depression (and analgesia) with a ceiling effect which means increasing the dose further does not produce any further respiratory depression and may actually result in increased ventilation (due to the predominance of antagonist actions).
Other drugs that show the ceiling effect are:
Butorphano
Nalbuphine
Pentazocine.
Respiratory depression with morphine, fentanyl & alfentanyl does not have a ceiling effect because they are pure opioid agonists. As the dose increases, respiratory depression also increases progressing to respiratory arrest.






Butorphanol is an agonist at  receptor. It may be a partial agonist or antagonist at µ receptor.
Pentazocine, butorphanol, buprenorphine, meptazinol, nalorphine, nalbuphine, and dezocine are mixed agonist-antagonist opioids.
All opioid agonist-antagonists are µ antagonists and k agonists, except buprenorphine, pentazocine, and dezocine. Buprenorphine, pentazocine, and dezocine are partial agonists at the  receptor.
Option A: Naltrexone is a pure antagonist at µ, k, and  receptors. Option B: Meperidine is a pure agonist of both  and  receptors.

Opioid Antagonists

Which of the following has the most rapid analgesic action?
Fentany

Solution to Question 3:
The most rapid analgesic action is achieved by remifentanil.
Analgesic action (peak) is achieved within 1 to 1.5 min following intravenous administration. Analgesic action- duration for peak action:
Remifentanil: 1 to 1.5 min
Fentanyl: 5 min

The rapid onset of action and the rapid recovery (within 15 min) owing to metabolism by plasma esterases of remifentanil make it an ideal analgesic for short painful procedures.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

A middle-aged man with liver metastasis and altered LFT is posted for a surgery. What would be the opioid of choice in him?
Fentany
Alfentani

Sufentani
Remifentani



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 4:
Opioid of choice in patients with compromised hepatic function is remifentanil.
Remifentanil is hydrolyzed by plasma and tissue esterases and hence its metabolism is independent of hepatic function.
Other opioids like fentanyl, alfentanil, and sufentanil are metabolized by the liver.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 5:

A 48-year-old woman with CKD is scheduled for a surgery. Her serum creatinine is 2.4mg/dL and eGFR is 13. Which of the following opioids can be safely used in her?
Pethidine
Remifentani
Alfentani
Morphine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
The given lab values in a CKD patient are suggestive of renal failure and remifentanil can be safely used in renal failure patients.
Remifentanil is hydrolyzed by plasma and tissue esterases. The pharmacokinetics and the pharmacodynamics of remifentanil are not altered by renal dysfunction.
Option A: Pethidine is metabolized to norpethidine, accumulation of which can lead to CNS excitatory effects (seizures).
Option C: High levels of alfentanil can lead to prolonged action.
Option D: Morphine is metabolized to morphine-6-glucuronide which can accumulate leading to respiratory depression.
Note: Fentanyl clearance is not altered by renal failure but its plasma protein binding is decreased which can alter the concentration of the free drug. Hence, fentanyl is the second drug of choice after remifentanil.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 6:

A patient who underwent an intra-abdominal surgery is about to receive intraspinal opioid injection for analgesia. Which of the following drugs should not be used for this purpose?
Sufentany
Alfentany
Fentany
Remifentani



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
Remifentanil should not be used for intraspinal injection.
Remifentanil is formulated in combination with glycine. Glycine acts as an inhibitory neurotransmitter in the spinal dorsal horn that causes a reversible motor weakness when it is injected intrathecally.
For this reason, remifentanil is not approved for spinal or epidural use.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Which of the following is the shortest acting opioid?
Fentany
Remifentani
Alfentani
Sufentani



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:
The shortest acting opioid is remifentanil with t1/2 of 8-20 minutes.

The rapid metabolism by tissue esterases and rapid clearance results in its ultra short-acting nature.
Remifentanil has the fastest onset of action and recovery, making it the opioid of choice in daycare surgery.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 8:

Which among the following is not included in neuroleptic anesthesia?
Nitrous oxide

Propofo
Droperido
Fentany



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:
Propofol is not included in neuroleptic anesthesia.
Neuroleptic anesthesia includes fentanyl, droperidol, and nitrous oxide. Neuroleptic analgesia includes fentanyl and droperidol.
Neuroleptic anesthesia is characterized by analgesia, the absence of clinically apparent motor activity, suppression of autonomic reflexes, maintenance of cardiovascular stability, and amnesia.
QT interval prolongation and torsades de pointes due to droperidol have made this technique obsolete.

Fentanyl is available as a transdermal patch and can be prescribed to this patient. It is mainly used for chronic pain.
Various routes of administration of fentanyl are: intravenous, epidural, spinal,

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 10:

A 33-year-old man with a history of heroin addiction is referred to a rehabilitation center. Which of the following would you use as a substitute drug for maintenance therapy?
Methylmorphine
Methadone
Meperidine
Methylphenidate



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
Methadone is used as a substitute drug for the maintenance therapy of opioid (heroin)
dependence. This is because of its good oral bioavailability and long half-life.
Methadone is substituted for opioids during detoxification to avoid withdrawal symptoms. Once stabilized, the dose is gradually reduced and the drug is stopped slowly over days.
Due to its long half-life and accumulation in tissues, discontinuing the drug still results in low concentrations of the drug in plasma resulting in protracted withdrawal symptoms.

Maintainance therapy for opioid dependence:
Long-acting opioid agonist - a safer substitute like methadone is given in a supervised manner to prevent withdrawal symptoms
Partial agonist - buprenorphine can also be used
Clonidine, lofexidine - alpha-2 agonists act as sympatholytic and reduce the withdrawa symptoms
LAAM(L-Alpha-Acetyl-Methadol) - opioid agonist which reduces craving
Naltrexone - is an opioid antagonist used in maintenance therapy to prevent relapses

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 11:

A physician prescribes naltrexone to a patient undergoing treatment for opioid addiction. What is the function of this drug in opioid addiction?
Prevention of relapse
Treatment of withdrawa
Treatment of overdose
Prevention of withdrawa


[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
Naltrexone is used for the prevention of relapse in opioid addiction.
It is given only after initial opioid detoxification. The patient should be opioid-free for 7-10 days and have a negative naloxone challenge (no withdrawal after naloxone administration).
Naltrexone is a pure opioid antagonist which is more potent than naloxone. It is orally active and has a long duration of action which makes it suitable for opioid blockade therapy in post-addicts.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Which of the following is incorrect about the use of naltrexone in the treatment of opioid addiction?
Discontinuation of naltrexone does not cause withdrawal symptoms
It satisfies craving in opioid addicts
It blocks the effects of opioids if they are used
It is administered only when the patient has completed detoxification from opioids



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 12:
Naltrexone does not satisfy the craving of opioid addicts. It is an opioid antagonist with a high affinity for  opioid receptors.
Naltrexone does not suppress craving in opioid addiction but it suppresses craving in chronic alcoholics.
Opioid agonists such as methadone and buprenorphine suppress craving and withdrawal symptoms and are therefore used in the first stage of detoxification in opioid addiction.
Option A: Discontinuation of naltrexone ingestion has no negative physical consequences, as opposed to discontinuation of agonist maintenance therapies, which results in the emergence of opioid withdrawal symptoms. This is a major reason for noncompliance and treatment failure.
Option C: It blocks the effects of opioids and prevents the user from experiencing subjective symptoms of opioid intoxication such as euphoria on subsequent use. As the user does not experience these symptoms, he does not develop a craving for the substance. Thus, naltrexone prevents relapse.
Option D: It is only administered when the patient has completed a medically supervised detoxification from opioids because it can cause immediate withdrawal symptoms.



Disulfiram cannot be used to treat heroin dependence.

It is an aldehyde dehydrogenase inhibitor used in the maintenance therapy of alcohol abstinence. Maintainance therapy for opioid dependence:
Long-acting opioid agonist - a safer substitute like methadone is given in a supervised manner to prevent withdrawal symptoms
Partial agonist - buprenorphine can also be used
Clonidine, lofexidine - alpha-2 agonists act as sympatholytic and reduce the withdrawal symptoms
LAAM(L-Alpha-Acetyl-Methadol) - opioid agonist which reduces craving
Naltrexone - is an opioid antagonist used in maintenance therapy to prevent relapses

subject: Pharmacology

An elderly man, who is on chronic morphine therapy for pain relief, visits your clinic with complaints of not passing stools for the last 4 days. Which of the following drugs is best suited to treat his condition?

Methylnaltrexone
Dextromethorphan
Nalmefene



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:

The given clinical picture points towards opioid-induced constipation. Methylnaltrexone, an opioid antagonist with predominant peripheral action is best suited for treating opioid-induced constipation.
Methylnaltrexone is a peripheral µ receptor antagonist. It was introduced in the treatment of opioid-induced constipation refractory to other measures.
It is a quaternary ammonium compound and hence cannot cross the blood-brain barrier. It can reverse the effects mediated by peripheral opioid receptors and spares CNS effects like analgesia.
The peripherally acting opioid antagonists include:
Methylnaltrexone
Naloxego
Naldemedine
Alvimopan

Naltrindole

Nalbuphine

Naltrindole is a new non-peptide drug which has a selective antagonistic activity on the  receptor. This drug is still in the trial phase and is not yet in use.
Option B: Naloxone is considered a pure opioid receptor antagonist but at high doses, it is found to have partial agonistic activity on the - and -opioid receptors.
Option C: Nalbuphine is an agonist-antagonist opioid which acts as an antagonist at the  receptor and an agonist at the  receptor.
Option D: Naltrexone is a -, - and -opioid receptor antagonist.

Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical features are suggestive of opioid overdose. Naloxone is the drug of choice for opioid overdose.
Opioid overdose symptoms:
Triad of coma, respiratory depression, and pinpoint pupils (miosis)
Hypotension, bradycardia
Shallow breathing
Hypothermia
Naloxone is also used for reversing neonatal asphyxia due to opioid usage in labor. Naloxone is a pure opioid antagonist which reverses all effects except sedation.
Note: Naloxone is contraindicated in infants born to mothers with opiate addiction as it may precipitate acute neonatal withdrawal with seizures.

Ethanol slows down metabolism of methanol

Ethanol reverses the actions of methanol

Solution to Question 10:
Administration of ethanol slows down the metabolism of methanol. Ethanol has a higher affinity for alcohol dehydrogenase than methanol.

Alcohol consumption during disulfiram therapy can lead to increased concentrations of acetaldehyde. This can cause aversive reactions resulting in flushing, pulsating headache, throbbing pain in the head and neck, nausea, vomiting, rashes, respiratory difficulties, chest pain, and autonomic manifestations.
Disulfiram is an irreversible inhibitor of both cytosolic and mitochondrial forms of aldehyde dehydrogenase. It is used in behavioral modification for alcohol de-addiction.

Drugs for Alzheimer's Disease and Other Neurodegenerative Disorders

subject: Pharmacology

The black-outs associated with high levels of ethanol can be attributed to its action on which of the following receptors?
GABA-A receptor

NMDA receptor is implicated in many aspects of cognitive function including learning and memory.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 3:

Ethanol ingestion results in enhanced diuresis. What is the most probable mechanism causing this?
Inhibition of ADH action in collecting tubules
Stimulation of ADH action in collecting tubules
Stimulation of ADH release from pituitary gland
Inhibition of ADH release from pituitary gland



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 3:
Ethanol inhibits the release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH)/ vasopressin from the posterior pituitary gland. This results in enhanced diuresis observed with ethanol ingestion.
Inhibition of ADH action in collecting tubules is not the mechanism by which alcohol induces diuresis. Stimulation of ADH release or action will have an antidiuretic action.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 4:

What effect does acute consumption of ethanol have on cytochrome enzymes?
Induction

Inhibition
Stimulation
No effect



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 4:
Acute consumption of ethanol inhibits the function of several cytochrome enzymes that are involved in the metabolism of drugs. CYP2E1 is one of the isoenzymes that is specifically inhibited.
Chronic consumption of alcohol causes induction of cytochrome enzymes, particularly CYP2E1, increasing the rate of metabolism of drugs dependent on CYP2E1 for metabolism.

subject: Pharmacology

Disulfiram is an irreversible inhibitor of both cytosolic and mitochondrial forms of aldehyde dehydrogenase.
Ethanol consumption during disulfiram therapy can lead to increased concentrations of acetaldehyde. Increased acetaldehyde levels can cause flushing, pulsating headache, throbbing pain in the head and neck, and other aversive reactions.
Disulfiram is indicated in alcohol deaddiction maintenance therapy. Option 1: Fomepizole is an inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase.

[EXPLANATION START]

Topiramate has shown efficacy in maintaining abstinence and reducing craving in chronic alcoholism.
Though effective, topiramate is not yet approved for use in alcohol deaddiction maintenance. It is used off-label for this indication.
Ondansetron and baclofen are other drugs that are found to be effective but not yet approved for this use.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

A young man presented to the ER with complaints of headache, vomiting, and blurring of vision after he consumed a bottle of illicit liquor. His ABG shows a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following statements would be incorrect regarding his management?
Fomepizole is used intravenously
Intravenous ethanol is an alternative to fomepizole
Hemodialysis is not effective

[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical picture and labs are suggestive of accidental methanol toxicity. Hemodialysis is used in severe cases of methanol toxicity.

A serum methanol concentration greater than 50 mg/dl is serious enough to consider hemodialysis. It can be used to remove both methanol and its toxic metabolite formic acid from the blood.
Option A: Fomepizole, an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor, is administered intravenously in methanol toxicity. It acts by inhibiting the formation of formic acid.
Option B: Intravenous ethanol is an alternative to fomepizole. It has a higher affinity to alcohol dehydrogenase than methanol. Thus, saturation of ADH enzymes results in less formation of toxic formic acid.
Option D: Folate-dependent systems are responsible for the oxidation of formic acid to CO2. Both folinic and folic acid are often administered during methanol toxicity but the exact benefit is yet to be determined.
Note: Ethanol is given intravenously in the management of methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 1:

A 70-year-old male patient is brought to the OPD by his son, with complaints of increasing forgetfulness. Neuroimaging shows marked cortical atrophy of temporal and parietal lobes. What is the most striking neurochemical disturbance in this condition?
Deficiency of acetylcholine
Deficiency of dopamine
Deficiency of serotonin
Deficiency of glutamate



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 1:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Alzheimer's disease (AD). The most striking neurochemical disturbance in AD is the deficiency of acetylcholine in the subcortical area (especially in the nucleus basalis of Meynert).
Neurotransmitters like glutamate and 5-HT and other areas of the brain like the hippocampus are also involved in the pathogenesis of this disease.
The drugs used in Alzheimer's disease are:
Central acetylcholine esterase inhibitors targeting acetylcholine deficiency
NMDA antagonists targeting glutamate excitotoxicity

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Inhibition of glutamate release
Inhibition of GABA reuptake
NMDA glutamate receptor antagonism
Kainate glutamate receptor antagonism



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
Riluzole does not act by causing inhibition of GABA reuptake.
Riluzole is the only drug known to improve survival in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), also known as Lou Gehrig's disease. The mechanism of action involves the reduction of
glutamate-induced excitotoxicity by:
Inhibition of glutamate release
Antagonism of NMDA and kainate-type glutamate receptor
Direct action on the voltage-dependent sodium channels.

Edaravone was approved by the FDA for the treatment of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).
It has free radical scavenging properties that may reduce oxidative stress. The exact mechanism of action is unknown. It is to be administered as an IV infusion with an initial treatment cycle of daily dosing for 14 days, followed by a 14-day drug-free period. Subsequent treatment cycles consist of dosing on 10 of 14 days, followed by a 14 day drug-free period.
The major adverse effect of edaravone is hypersensitivity because the infusion contains sodium bisulfite. Other adverse effects include bruising, gait disorder, and headache.
Tafinlar (dabrafenib) and Mekinist (trametinib), are both indicated as monotherapy in BRAF V600E/K (BRAF V600E mutation-positive) melanoma. They are approved for combined administration, for the treatment of anaplastic thyroid cancer (ATC) that cannot be removed by surgery or that has spread to other parts of the body (metastatic).
Piracetam is a nootropic agent (a drug that enhances cognitive function) that is used off-label to enhance memory. It is also used to treat myoclonus.

General Principles of Antimicrobial Therapy

John Cunningham (JC) virus antibody titer is being measured in a patient with multiple sclerosis. During treatment with which of the following drugs are the titres mandatory?
Alemtuzumab
Natalizumab
Glatiramer
Interferon



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:

John Cunningham (JC) virus antibody titre measurement is mandatory during treatment with monoclonal antibodies like natalizumab. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is a life-threatening disease caused by the JC virus in patients with multiple sclerosis.
It is more common when the patient is immunocompromised during their treatment with natalizumab. The current recommendation is to start natalizumab only in a patient who tests negative for JC antibodies.
Seroconversion can occur anytime during treatment. Regular monitoring for JC antibody every 6 months is recommended in JC antibody-negative patients on natalizumab.

subject: Pharmacology

AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 11:

Adrenaline is used to treat histamine-induced bronchoconstriction in a patient with brittle asthma. What is this type of antagonism called?
Physiological antagonism
Chemical antagonism
Competitive antagonism
Uncompetitive antagonism



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
Adrenaline and histamine are physiological antagonists.
Adrenaline and histamine act on bronchial muscles. Histamine acts on H1 receptors and produces bronchoconstriction. Adrenaline acts on 2 receptors and produces bronchodilation. Two drugs acting on different receptors and resulting in opposite responses means having pharmacological effects in the opposite direction. This is called physiological antagonism or functional antagonism.
Option B: Chemical antagonism refers to a reaction between two chemicals to neutralize their effects, such as is seen with chelation therapy.
Option C: Competitive antagonism is a type of receptor antagonism that occurs when the agonist and antagonist compete for the same binding site on the receptor.
Option D: In uncompetitive inhibition, inhibitors form a complex with an intermediate complex of the substrate and transporter. This inhibits subsequent translocation.

Decrease in both Km and Vmax
No change in Vmax

Non-competitive inhibitors cause a decrease in Vmax. In non-competitive inhibition:
The inhibitor binds to the adjacent site and not the catalytic site of the enzyme

The affinity of the enzyme is not altered and hence Km is unaltered

[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 13:
In competitive antagonism, the drug and the antagonist compete to bind to the same site of the receptor.
Agonists if present in high concentration, can displace the antagonists from the active site and overcome the competitive antagonism completely.
The dose-response curve in the case of competitive antagonism shifts to the right.

Potency:

AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 21:

Which of the following shows a U-shaped dose-response curve?
Vitamin
Anti-cancer drug
Steroid
Chelator



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 21:
Vitamins and essential metals show a U-shaped dose-response curve.
At a low dose, adverse effects are observed because there is a deficiency of these nutrients to maintain homeostasis. As dose increases, homeostasis is achieved, and the bottom of the
U-shaped dose-response curve is reached. As the dose increases to surpass the amount required to maintain homeostasis, toxicity can ensue.
Thus, adverse effects are seen at both low and high doses.




Hockey stick-shaped dose-response curve for toxicants that are also metabolic by-products.



Inverted U-shaped dose-response curve for ligands that downregulate their receptors.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 22:

What does the area between the dotted lines in this graph indicate?



Median effective dose
Median lethal dose
Therapeutic index
Therapeutic window



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 22:
The area between the dotted lines in the graph shows the therapeutic window. It is the range of steady-state concentrations of a drug that provides therapeutic efficacy with minimal toxicity.
The therapeutic index (TI) describes a relationship between the doses of a drug that causes lethal or toxic effects with the dose that causes therapeutic effects. It is also called the therapeutic ratio.
Mathematically, you can calculate TI by following way:
Therapeutic Index = LD50/ED50 (or) Therapeutic Index = TD50/ED50 Where,
LD50 (Median Lethal dose) is the minimum amount of drug that causes adverse effects in 50% of the population. LD50 could also be replaced with Toxic dose (TD50).
ED50 (Median Effective dose) is the quantity of a drug that can produce desired therapeutic effects in 50% of the population.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 23:

Therapeutic index is used for assessing which of the following factors?
Safety
Efficacy
Potency
Toxicity



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 23:
Therapeutic index is used to assess the safety of the drug administered. Therapeutic index = TD50/ED50
TD50 (Median toxic dose) = Dose required to produce a toxic effect in 50% of animals tested.
ED50 (Median effect dose) = Dose required to produce a therapeutic effect in 50% of the individuals.
Option B: Efficacy is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug. It expresses the effect produced by the receptors when bound by a certain drug.

Option C: Potency refers to the concentration (EC50) or dose (ED50) required to produce 50% of maximum effect where EC50 is the concentration of agonist resulting in a half-maximal response.
Option D: Median toxic dose is the dose required to produce a toxic effect in 50% of animals tested. Lethal dose is the dose required to kill 50% of animals tested.

subject: Pharmacology

Therapeutic index is calculated with which of the following equations?
ED50/LD50
LD50/ED50
ED50-LD50

[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 24:
Therapeutic index is calculated with the following equation = LD50/ED50. Therapeutic index is used to assess the safety of the drug administered.
LD50 (median lethal dose) refers to the dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals die. Larger the LD50, the safer the drug. In humans, TD50 is considered. TD50 refers to the dose of the drug that causes a toxic response in 50% of the population.
ED50 (median effective dose) refers to the dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals show the specific or desired effect
Clinically, the therapeutic range bound by the dose that produces the minimal necessary therapeutic effect and the dose that produces the maximal acceptable adverse effect is more relevant.

Solution to Question 4:
Muscarinic receptors are G-protein-coupled receptors among the given options. M1, M2, M3, M4, and M5 are the muscarinic Ach receptors.

M1 and M3 act through Gq protein and activate IP3/DAG causing increased cytosolic calcium.
M2 and M4 act through Gi protein and inhibit adenylyl cyclase causing increased potassium conductance.



Nicotinic receptors and GABA-A are examples of ion channel coupled receptors.


Insulin receptor is a tyrosine kinase receptor.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 6:

All of the following agents act by intracellular receptors except
Thyroid hormone
Vitamin D
Insulin
Steroid



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
Insulin receptors belong to the class of trans-membrane enzyme-linked receptors.
Transmembrane enzyme-linked receptors consist of a large extracellular ligand-binding domain. It is connected to an intracellular subunit having enzymatic property through a single transmembrane helical peptide chain. The enzyme on the cytosolic side is usually a protein kinase (tyrosine) or membrane-bound GC (guanylyl cyclase).
Physiological ligands for transmembrane enzyme-linked receptors are mostly growth factors and chemokines. Other receptors belonging to this class include:
Receptor tyrosine kinases - Growth factors (PDGF, EGF, VEGF); insulin
Membrane-bound GC - Natriuretic peptide
Receptor serine-threonine kinases - TGF-
Thyroid hormones, vitamin D, and steroids act via intracellular receptors.

Tyrosine kinase receptor
JAK-STAT receptor
Ligand-gated guanylyl cyclase receptor



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 9:
Nesiritide is recombinant B-type natriuretic peptide. Natriuretic peptide receptors are transmembrane ligand-gated guanylyl cyclase receptors.
Natriuretic peptides:
Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP): released from atrial storage granules in response to an increase in intravascular volume. It decreases blood pressure.
Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP): released from ventricular tissue in response to volume overload. Along with a decrease in blood pressure, it is known to reduce cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis.
C- type natriuretic peptide (CNP): synthesized in the brain and endothelial tissues and function to stimulate long bone growth.
ANP and BNP act on the NPR-A receptor. CNP acts on the NPR-B receptor.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 1:

A young man who collapsed at a concert was suspected to have bacterial meningitis. The other attendees of the concert were administered ciprofloxacin by the medical staff on duty. What is this kind of antimicrobial therapy called?
Preemptive therapy
Prophylactic therapy
Empirical therapy
Suppressive therapy



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 1:
The antimicrobial treatment initiated in a patient who is not yet infected is called prophylactic therapy. The goal is to prevent infection in some patients and to prevent dangerous manifestations of infections in other patients.
Option A: Preemptive therapy is therapy in an asymptomatic individual with evidence of infection
(high-risk).

Option C: Empirical therapy is broad-spectrum therapy in a patient with symptoms of infection but no microbiological confirmation of the causative agent.
Option D: Suppressive therapy is given to patients when the infection is controlled but not completely eradicated by the initial round of antimicrobial treatment. This is usually indicated for immunosuppressed patients.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 11:

Which of the following antibacterial agents does not act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis?
Carbapenems
Monobactams
Cephalosporins
Nitrofurantoin


[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
Nitrofurantoin is an antibacterial drug that does not act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.
The antibacterial activity of nitrofurantoin appears to correlate with the rapid intracellular conversion of nitrofurantoin to highly reactive intermediates by bacterial reductases. These intermediates react nonspecifically with many ribosomal proteins and disrupt the synthesis of proteins, RNA, DNA, and metabolic processes.
Carbapenems, monobactams, and cephalosporins are beta-lactam antibiotics that act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.



Bacitracin acts on the cell wall by inhibiting the synthesis of the cell wall.
It interferes with the dephosphorylation of bactoprenol (lipid carrier) which carries peptidoglycan subunits outside the cell membrane to the growing cell wall. It can also alter the integrity of the cell membrane.
Bacitracin is mainly active against gram-positive cocci and bacilli.

Antimalarial Drugs

The total microbial population was found to be susceptible to antimicrobials on testing but a subset of the same population was resistant which was undetected. What is this phenomenon called?
Cross resistance
Heteroresistance
Idioresistance
Alloresistance



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 2:
Heteroresistance occurs when a subset of the total microbial population is resistant, despite the total microbial population being susceptible on testing. The resistant subpopulation is usually well below the assay-detection limits.
Heteroresistant Staphylococci and M. tuberculosis have led to therapeutic failures and mortality.
C. albicans and C. neoformans with heteroresistance to fluconazole have resulted in increased treatment failures.
Note: For viruses, the resistant viral species occurring due to the above phenomenon is termed as 'quasi-species'. Quasi-species resistant to antiretroviral agents have resulted in the failure of antiretroviral therapy.

Penicillins
5-fluorocytosine
Aminoglycosides
Vancomycin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 3:
Aminoglycosides exhibit concentration-dependent killing and are preferably dosed once daily for maximum effect.
Peak concentration above MIC (minimum inhibitory concentration) matters for certain classes of drugs for their antimicrobial action. It is referred to as concentration-dependent killing. The period during which the concentration remains above MIC is not relevant for such drugs.
Aminoglycosides and quinolones have this property.
Time-dependent killing: The antimicrobial action is dependent on the period for which the concentration of drug remains above the MIC. Penicillins, 5-fluorocytosine and vancomycin have this property.

Which of the following antimalarial drugs is a slow acting schizonticide?
Artemether
Mefloquine
Pyrimethamine
Quinine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 1:

Pyrimethamine is a slow-acting schizonticide.
Female Anopheles mosquito inoculates Plasmodium species in the form of sporozoites into the human host during blood meal. Sporozoites migrate to the liver and mature into hepatic schizonts. Hepatic schizonts are released into the blood in the form of merozoites. Merozoites in the erythrocyte transform into ring form and erythrocytic schizonts. Some merozoites in the blood transform into gametocytes.
Antimalarial drugs are classified based on their onset of action of schizonticidal function as below:
Fast onset of action
Artemisinin derivatives like artemether , arteether and artesunate are fastest acting
Chloroquine
Intermediate onset of action
Mefloquine
Quinine
Proguani
Lumefantrine
Slow onset of action
Pyrimethamine
Sulfonamides
Tetracyclines
Clindamycin

[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 16:
Quinine is not associated with hypertension. It is associated with hypotension.
Quinine is used in the treatment of drug-resistant and severe P. falciparum malaria. It acts against asexual erythrocytic forms but has no significant effect on hepatic forms of malarial parasites.
Option A: Quinine use is associated with cinchonism which manifests as tinnitus, visual and auditory disturbances, headache, nausea, and vomiting.
Option B: Quinine has a stimulatory effect on pancreatic beta cells and can cause hypoglycemia.
Option D: Blackwater fever is a rare type of hypersensitivity reaction to quinine. It presents with massive hemolysis, hemoglobinemia, and hemoglobinuria that may lead to anuria, renal failure, and death.



Hemolysis in a G6PD deficient patient is more common with primaquine.
G6PD deficient patients are highly sensitive to oxidative stress. They are at increased risk of hemolysis due to the oxidant property of primaquine. Therefore, before initiating primaquine therapy, the G6PD status of the patient has to be determined. Passage of dark color urine is an indication of hemolysis and the drug has to be stopped if it occurs.
Quinine, chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine can also cause hemolysis in G6PD deficient patients, but the incidence is less compared to primaquine.



Sulfonamides , Quinolones and Urinary antiseptics

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 5:

Radical cure is required for malaria caused by which of the following species?
P. falciparum and P. vivax
P. falciparum and P. malariae
P. vivax and P. malariae
P. vivax and P. ovale



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
Radical cure is required for malaria caused by P. vivax and P. ovale.
In case of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale, malarial parasites have an exoerythrocytic stage (hypnozoites). In the exoerythrocytic phase malarial parasites are found in the liver that can cause relapse of malaria after clinical cure.
Therefore, they require radical cure by drugs acting on the exoerythrocytic stage. Primaquine is effective against the exoerythrocytic stages of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale in the liver. Primaquine is administered for 14 days for radical cure.

[EXPLANATION START]

Tafenoquine is used in the radical cure of Plasmodium vivax. Total eradication of plasmodium species which includes clinical curative and hypnozoites phase are called radical cure.
Primaquine and tafenoquine (derivative of primaquine) have very high activity against the latent tissue forms (hypnozoites) of the species. It is primarily used for the chemoprophylaxis and radical cure of P. vivax and P. ovale infections.

Worldwide, most species of Falciparum malaria are resistant to chloroquine. In all trimesters, pregnant women diagnosed with uncomplicated malaria caused by chloroquine-resistant P. falciparum infection can be treated with a combination of quinine and clindamycin.

explanation:

A 32-year-old man presents with fever with chills and seizures. On examination, his blood pressure was 70/50 mm of Hg and labored breathing was present. Solution to Question 9:
This scenario depicts a case of severe complicated falciparum malaria, and the drug of choice in this condition is artesunate. The image shows ring forms/early trophozoites in erythrocyte, which are binucleate (double chromatin) and this is characteristic of P. falciparum malaria.
Severe complicated malaria is caused by P. falciparum and is characterized by hyperparasitemia, hyperpyrexia, acidosis, respiratory distress, bleeding manifestation, cardiovascular collapse, renal failure and cerebral malaria.
As per WHO guidelines, all patients with severe malaria should be treated with intravenous or intramuscular artesunate for at least 24 hours. Once the patient recovers and can tolerate oral medications, oral ACT for 3 days is recommended.
Artemether is used only if parenteral artesunate is not available.

Sulfonamides are structural analogs of which of the following compounds?
Para-amino benzoic acid
Pteridine
Dihydropteroic acid
Dihydrofolic acid



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 1:
Sulfonamides are structural analogs of para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) that interfere in the synthesis of folic acid.
Sulfonamides competitively inhibit dihydropteroate synthase, the enzyme that is involved in the incorporation of PABA into pteridine (dihyropteroate diphosphate) to form dihydropteroic acid, which is an immediate precursor of folic acid.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 10:

What is the mechanism of action of fluoroquinolones in gram-negative bacteria?
Inhibits bacterial DNA helicase enzyme
Inhibits bacterial primase enzyme
Inhibits bacterial DNA gyrase enzyme
Inhibits bacterial topoisomerase IV



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
Fluoroquinolones inhibit two essential type II topoisomerases, DNA gyrase (in gram-negative bacteria) and topoisomerase IV (in gram-positive bacteria).
DNA gyrase introduces negative supercoils and thereby reduces the torsional strain that occurs when double-stranded DNA is being unwound for replication or translation. Topoisomerases IV is responsible for unlinking daughter chromosomes after replication. Quinolone antibiotics form a complex with the topoisomerase enzyme and the DNA, and thereby block DNA replication and bacterial cell division.

[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 14:
Delafloxacin is a newer fluoroquinolone approved for use in acute bacterial skin and skin structural infections (ABSSSI) caused by susceptible bacteria including MRSA.
Compared to other fluoroquinolones which are zwitterionic in nature, delafloxacin is anionic. This enables the molecule to achieve increased intracellular penetration and concentration, especially under acidic conditions (skin wounds). This results in increased antimicrobial activity and a decreased adverse event profile at clinically potent doses.

Ciprofloxacin

[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 17:
Moxifloxacin is metabolized predominantly by the liver and hence can be used safely in patients with decreased renal function without dose adjustment.
Fluoroquinolones, especially moxifloxacin, may be used as part of multiple-drug regimens for the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis.
Most of the available fluoroquinolones are cleared predominantly by kidneys and dosage needs to be adjusted in patients with renal failure. But fluoroquinolones such as moxifloxacin
and pefloxacin undergo hepatic elimination and so should be used carefully in patients with liver disease.

A 60-year-old woman undergoing treatment with moxifloxacin was brought to the casualty with delirium and seizures. Displacement of GABA from receptor
Inhibition of glycine metabolism



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 19:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a fluoroquinolones drug interaction, where NSAIDs augmented the displacement of GABA from its receptors, leading to CNS excitation symptoms.
Fluoroquinolones act as selective antagonists of GABAA receptors and thereby have the potential to cause CNS excitation. NSAIDs such as diclofenac cause the displacement of GABA from its receptors, further enhancing the neuropsychiatric adverse effects caused by fluoroquinolones.

A patient presents to the casualty with fever with chills and chest pain. He also gives history of passing brown-colored urine. He was prescribed an antimicrobial drug for urinary tract infection three days ago and his symptoms began after he had started this medication. Which of the following antimicrobial agents had most likely been prescribed?
Methenamine
Nitrofurantoin
Norfloxacin
Gatifloxacin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 23:
The patient had most likely been prescribed nitrofurantoin as the scenario depicts side effects of this drug.
Nitrofurantoin is a urinary antiseptic used against lower UTI caused by E.coli and enterococci. Its use results in brown urine. It is also associated with acute pneumonitis with fever, chills, cough, dyspnea, chest pain, pulmonary infiltration, and eosinophilia within hours to days of initiation of therapy. The symptoms resolve quickly after discontinuation of the drug.
The antibacterial activity of nitrofurantoin is due to its intracellular conversion to highly reactive intermediates by bacterial reductases. These intermediates react nonspecifically with ribosomal proteins and disrupt the synthesis of proteins, RNA, DNA, and other metabolic processes.



Pefloxacin is mainly metabolized in the liver and hence avoided in patients with liver disease. Quinolones with primarily hepatic metabolism include moxifloxacin, pefloxacin, and trovafloxacin
(withdrawn from the market due to hepatotoxicity).
Quinolones primarily excreted by the kidneys include ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, norfloxacin, lomefloxacin, and ofloxacin.

Antimicrobials Acting on 30s Subunit

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 5:

Which of the following options correctly describes the dose ratio of trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole in co-trimoxazole?
1 : 20 (trimethoprim : sulfamethoxazole)
1 : 5 (trimethoprim : sulfamethoxazole)
20 : 1 (trimethoprim : sulfamethoxazole)
5 : 1 (trimethoprim : sulfamethoxazole)



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
Co-trimoxazole is a combination of trimethoprim with sulfamethoxazole in the dose ratio of 1:5 (trimethoprim : sulfamethoxazole).
The antimicrobial activity of this combination is because of its actions on sequential steps in the pathway of synthesis of tetrahydrofolic acid as shown in the image.



Each agent alone usually exerts bacteriostatic activity. But when an organism is sensitive to both agents, bactericidal activity may be achieved.
Because trimethoprim is more lipid-soluble than sulfamethoxazole, it has a larger volume of distribution than the latter drug.
Therefore, when 1 part of trimethoprim is given with 5 parts of sulfamethoxazole (dose ratio is 1:5; trimethoprim:sulfamethoxazole), the peak plasma concentrations are in the ratio of 1:20, which is optimal for the combined effects of these drugs in vitro.

[EXPLANATION START]

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 9:

A girl presents to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain, dark-colored urine, and seizures. You find out that she was recently prescribed co-trimoxazole for a UTI. What is the probable diagnosis?
Acute intermittent porphyria
Porphyria cutanea tarda
Congenital erythropoietic porphyria
Hepatoerythropoietic porphyria



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 9:
The given neurovisceral symptoms following the use of sulfonamides point towards a diagnosis of acute intermittent porphyria (AIP).
AIP is a rare heme biosynthesis disorder due to a partial deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase (PBGD). Diagnosis is made based on elevated urine PBG levels. Alcohol, infections, pregnancy, and certain medications can trigger attacks by inducing heme synthesis. This results in the accumulation of porphyrin precursors, causing symptoms.
Side effects of sulfonamides are:
Acute intermittent porphyria - sulphonamides precipitate attacks
Hypersensitivity reaction - urticaria, erythema nodosum, erythema multiforme of the Stevens-Johnson type, exfoliative dermatitis, and photosensitivity

Crystalluria - due to low solubility. It is treated with good hydration and alkalization of urine
Hemolysis in G-6-PD deficiency (sulphonamides are oxidizers)
Kernicterus in the newborn (displace bilirubin)

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 1:

A patient diagnosed with tuberculosis is undergoing treatment with streptomycin. Which of the following is the primary intracellular site of action of this drug?
30S ribosomal subunit
DNA helicase enzyme
50S ribosomal subunit
Topoisomerase IV enzyme



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 1:
Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic and the primary intracellular site of action of aminoglycosides is the 30S ribosomal subunit.
Mechanism of action of aminoglycosides:
Aminoglycosides are transported actively across the cell membrane into the cytoplasm
(oxygen-dependent process)
Binding of aminoglycosides to 30S ribosomes cause misreading of mRNA template and result in incorporation of incorrect amino acids in the growing polypeptide chain
The resulting aberrant proteins may be inserted into the cell membrane leading to altered permeability of the cell membrane of bacteria causing bacterial death (bactericidal)

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 10:

In which of the following patients will you prescribe aminoglycosides at a lower dose?
A urosepsis patient with associated AKI
A cystic fibrosis patient with acute pulmonary exacerbation
A diabetic patient with infected burn wounds
A CLD patient with osteomyelitis



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
The dose of aminoglycosides is to be reduced in patients with renal failure (AKI) because clearance of the drug is reduced.
Aminoglycosides undergo minimum metabolism and are primarily excreted almost entirely by glomerular filtration. Therefore, renal failure decreases the clearance of the drug. Because the incidence of nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity is likely related to the overall exposure to aminoglycosides, it is critical to reduce the maintenance dose and dosing interval of these drugs in patients with impaired renal function.
Option B: Renal clearances are increased and the half-life is reduced in cystic fibrosis patients necessitating higher doses.
Option C: Burn patients have a more rapid drug clearance probably due to increased drug loss through burnt tissue and require higher doses in them.
Option D: Aminoglycoside dose adjustment is not required in liver disease

A patient who was recently started on i.v. gentamicin for enterococcal endocarditis presented to the OPD with complaints of headache and dizziness. By which of the following mechanisms does the drug cause this adverse effect?
Direct hair cell toxicity
Inhibition of hair cell Na+/K+ ATPase
