[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 13:
The scenario depicts a case of gentamicin-induced ototoxicity which is caused due to direct hair cell toxicity. Degeneration of vestibular hair cells and neurons leads to vertigo and associated headache.
Streptomycin and gentamicin produce predominantly vestibular effects. Amikacin, kanamycin, and neomycin primarily affect auditory function. Tobramycin affects both equally.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 14:

An elderly patient who was taken up for an emergency laparotomy showed prolonged respiratory depression which did not resolve with neostigmine. On inquiry, the attendant confirmed that the patient was on aminoglycoside therapy. Which of the following is least likely to cause this effect?
Amikacin
Kanamycin
Gentamicin
Tobramycin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 14:
The given scenario depicts the neuromuscular blockade effect of aminoglycosides, and tobramycin has the least potency for blockade in this group.
Decreasing order of potency for the neuromuscular blockade is:
Neomycin > Kanamycin > Amikacin > Gentamicin > Tobramycin

It is a recognized clinical side effect of aminoglycoside antibiotics, and this effect becomes significant (prolonged respiratory depression) when the drug is used in conjunction with neuromuscular blocking agents or calcium channel blockers. They are avoided in patients with myasthenia gravis.
Aminoglycosides cause neuromuscular blockade by interfering with calcium channels and thereby inhibiting acetylcholine's pre-junctional release and post-junctional sensitivity. The neuromuscular blockade produced by these antibiotics is not reversed by neostigmine but is reversed by IV calcium gluconate.

Which of the following organisms is resistant to tetracyclines?
MRSA
Pseudomonas aeruginosa
Rickettsia
Mycoplasma



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 17:
All strains of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are resistant to the action of tetracyclines.
Tetracyclines are active against MRSA and MSSA. Doxycycline and minocycline can be used in cutaneous MRSA infections.
Rickettsia and chlamydia are highly susceptible to tetracyclines. Tetracyclines are considered first line agents for chlamydial infections like non-specific urethritis/ endocervicitis and rickettsial infections like typhus, rocky mountain spotted fever, Q fever.
They are also second-line drugs in patients with syphilis who are allergic to penicillin.
Tetracyclines are bacteriostatic drugs which are more active against gram-positive than gram-negative. They are effective against spirochetes, Haemophilus ducreyi, Vibrio cholera, Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

Oral neomycin will not be effective for treating which of the following patients?
A patient requiring pre-operative antisepsis for bowel surgery
A elderly man with hepatic encephalopathy
A child with enteropathogenic E. coli associated diarrhea
A woman with a cut wound on the finger



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
Topical neomycin is used widely for a variety of infections of the skin and mucous membranes and to prevent infection of minor cuts and wounds.
Oral neomycin can be used for the eradication of bacteria confined to GIT in the following conditions:
Pre-operative antisepsis for bowel surgery
Hepatic encephalopathy: To reduce deleterious ammonia producing bacteria
Enteropathogenic E. coli associated diarrhea
Orally administered neomycin is poorly absorbed from the GI tract and is eliminated unchanged in the feces.
Neomycin is highly nephrotoxic in human beings and hence should not be administered systemically.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 7:

A patient with hospital-acquired pneumonia is being treated with an aminoglycoside antibiotic by a single daily dose administration method. This method is preferred over the multiple daily dosage method because of which of the following properties of aminoglycosides?
Decreased CYP450 mediated metabolism
Long post antibiotic effect
Increased binding to plasma proteins
Time dependent killin


[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:
Single daily dose aminoglycoside administration is more preferable to multiple daily dose administration because of the long post-antibiotic effect.
For certain classes of drugs such as aminoglycosides and quinolones, its antimicrobial action is dependent on the peak concentration above MIC (Minimum Inhibitory Concentration). It is referred to as concentration-dependent killing.
High-dose, extended-interval dosing schemes take advantage of the concentration-dependent activity of aminoglycosides to achieve maximal initial bacterial killing. And then because of the postantibiotic effect of aminoglycosides, good therapeutic response can be attained even when concentrations fall below MIC for a substantial fraction of the dosing interval.
Therefore, a single daily dose would be equal to or more effective than multiple 8 hourly doses. This dosing strategy may also reduce the ototoxicity and nephrotoxicity of these drugs.

Time-dependent killing is an effect seen when the antimicrobial action is dependent on the duration, the drug concentration remains above the MIC. Beta-lactams, macrolides, and vancomycin have this property.

explanation:

A patient who was diagnosed with urinary tract infection receives a single intramuscular dose of gentamicin. Within how many minutes of administration is the peak concentration of this drug achieved?
0-30 minutes
30-90 minutes
90-120 minutes
120-180 minutes



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:
Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic and the peak concentration of aminoglycosides following intramuscular administration is achieved after 30-90 minutes.
Aminoglycosides need therapeutic dose monitoring because of their low therapeutic index especially in patients in whom renal function is compromised. Both trough and peak levels are calculated for aminoglycosides.

The urine culture and sensitivity report of a patient with urinary tract infection is positive for aminoglycoside-resistant Enterococcus faecalis. What is the most common mode of this resistance?

Clinically, the most common cause of aminoglycoside resistance is drug inactivation by enzymes.
The inactivating enzymes are commonly acquired through conjugation and transfer of plasmids containing resistance genes.
Causes of aminoglycoside resistance are:
Drug inactivation by enzymes
Increased drug efflux
Decreased permeability to the dru
Modifications of the 30S ribosomal subunit that interferes with binding of the aminoglycosides

subject: Pharmacology

Gray baby syndrome is associated with the use of which of the following drugs?
Clindamycin
Chloramphenicol
Tetracycline
Cotrimoxazole



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 1:
Gray baby syndrome is associated with the use of chloramphenicol, especially in premature infants.
It develops due to the developmental deficiency of the enzyme glucoronyl transferase. This enzyme metabolizes chloramphenicol in neonates. Its deficiency leads to an inability to excrete

unconjugated drugs adequately through renal excretion. The initial symptoms are:
Vomiting
Refusal to suck
Irregularly rapid respiration
Periods of cyanosis. After 1-2 days:
Flaccid baby
Hypothermia
Ashen-gray color skin discoloration
If there is a recovery, usually there are no sequelae.

explanation:

Which of the following statements about streptogramins is true?

Synergistic activity of quinupristine and dalfopristine has bactericidal action
Quinupristin binds to the 30s subunit of ribosomes
Dalfopristin binds to the 30s subunit of ribosomes



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 12:
Quinupristin and dalfopristin are a combination of streptogramins and the synergistic activity of these drugs has bactericidal action.
Quinupristin binds to the 50s subunit of ribosomes and acts similar to macrolides by interfering in translocation and inhibiting protein synthesis.
Dalfopristin binds to a site nearby, resulting in conformational changes in the 50S ribosome thereby increasing the activity of quinupristin. The synergic activity of these drugs can have bactericidal action in certain susceptible bacteria.
Quinupristin/dalfopristin is active against gram-positive cocci and organisms responsible for atypical pneumonia (e.g., M. pneumoniae, Legionella spp., and C. pneumoniae).
Quinupristin is a streptogramin B molecule whereas dalfopristin is a streptogramin A molecule.

[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 13:
Linezolid binds to the P site of the 50s ribosomal subunit and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. It is an oxazolidinone that is active against various resistant organisms including MRSA.
Linezolid is well absorbed orally and the bioavailability approaches 100%, hence intravenous and oral doses are the same for this drug.
Linezolid is associated with the side effect of myelosuppression (anemia, leukopenia, pancytopenia, thrombocytopenia). Thrombocytopenia is the most common side effect. Platelet count monitoring is done in a patient with linezolid who is at risk of myelosuppression and blood dyscrasias. Linezolid also causes serotonin syndrome due to monoamine oxidase(MAO) inhibition.

Maraviroc is a chemokine receptor antagonist acting against the CCR5 receptor.

[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 13:
Efavirenz is not indicated for HIV-2 infection. It is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI).
NNRTIs are HIV-1 specific and have no activity against HIV-2. The binding site for NNRTI is virus strain-specific which only inhibits the HIV-1 reverse transcriptase. It is approved only for HIV-1 infections and should not be used for HIV-2 infections.
Ritonavir, tenofovir, and zalcitabine are indicated for HIV-2 infections.

explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 23:

A 45-year-old HIV-positive man was started on HAART. On follow-up testing, his CD4 cell count had decreased below 200/mm³. Subsequently, he developed diarrhea and redistribution of body fat. What is false about the causative drug class?
Atazanavir has the lowest propensity to increase total cholesterol levels.
Tipranavir is used in sub-therapeutic doses as a pharmacodynamic booster in cART.
Indinavir can cause nephrolithiasis when adequate hydration is not maintained.
Ritonavir is a potent inhibitor of the CYP3A4 isoform of P450 & may alter levels of drugs.


[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 23:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of adverse effects of gastrointestinal tolerance and fat redistribution due to protease inhibitors. HAART therapy includes this class of drugs along with 2 nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors +/- NNRTIs. Ritonavir, not tipranavir, is used in
sub-therapeutic doses as a pharmacodynamic booster of other protease inhibitors in cART.
This is because ritonavir is a potent inhibitor of the CYP3A4 isoform of P450. It inhibits their CYP3A-mediated metabolism and permits the use of lower doses of other protease inhibitors. Nelfinavir is the only protease inhibitor not boosted by ritonavir.
Indinavir is notable for its tendency to precipitate in the urinary tract, causing nephrolithiasis, unless the patient maintains a high state of hydration.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 24:

An AIDS patient on treatment with AZT, lamivudine, indinavir, ketoconazole, and cotrimoxazole, develops breast hypertrophy, central adiposity, hyperlipidemia, insulin resistance, and nephrolithiasis. Which of the following drugs could have caused these?
Azidothymidine
Indinavir
Ketoconazole
Lamivudine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 24:
Indinavir, a protease inhibitor, is the most likely cause for these adverse effects.
Patients being treated with protease inhibitors (e.g., indinavir) develop a syndrome involving the derangement of lipid metabolism. This causes changes in body fat distribution. Type 2 diabetes mellitus has also been reported. This is called HIV/HAART-associated lipodystrophy.
Indinavir can also precipitate in the urinary tract, causing nephrolithiasis, unless the patient is maintained in a high state of hydration.
Indinavir binds to the site of HIV-1 protease activity and inhibits cleavage of viral gag-pol polyprotein precursors into individual functional proteins required for infectious HIV. This results in the formation of immature, non-infectious viral particles.
Option A: Azidothymidine or zidovudine, is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. Chronic zidovudine administration has been associated with nail hyperpigmentation.
Option C: Ketoconazole is an antifungal agent that inhibits fungal ergosterol synthesis. Its adverse effects include liver dysfunction and testosterone synthesis inhibition leading to gynecomastia.
Option D: Lamivudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. It is one of the least toxic antiretroviral drugs. Neutropenia, headache, and nausea have been reported at
higher-than-recommended doses.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 25:

Which of the following is a monoclonal antibody approved for use in the treatment of HIV?
Bevacizumab
Ibalizumab
Panitumumab
Pembrolizumab



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 25:
Ibalizumab is an anti-CD4 monoclonal antibody approved for use in the treatment of multidrug-resistant HIV-1. It is administered intravenously.

It acts as an entry inhibitor. It blocks HIV-1 from infecting CD4+ T cells by binding to domain 2 of CD4 cells. It also interferes with post-attachment steps required for the entry of HIV-1 virus particles into host cells and thus prevents the viral transmission that occurs via cell-cell fusion.



The integrase inhibitor indicated in the treatment of HIV is raltegravir.
It inhibits the catalytic activity of the HIV-encoded integrase and prevents the integration of virus DNA into the host chromosome. It is eliminated primarily by glucuronidation by UGT1A1.
The other two FDA-approved integrase inhibitors are elvitegravir (EVG) and dolutegravir (DTG).
Options A and D: Lopinavir and ritonavir are protease inhibitors. Option B: Abacavir is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor.
Note: Dolutegravir (DTG) is recommended as the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis as per the recent MOHFW ùan 2020 guideline, in line with WHO.
The FDA approved dolutegravir tablets and suspension for the treatment of HIV-1 infection in pediatric patients at least four weeks old and weighing at least 3 kg who have never been treated for HIV or who have been treated, but not with an integrase inhibitor class of drug.
WHO recently recommended long-acting Cabotegravir, an HIV integrase strand transfer inhibitor may be offered as a HIV prevention option for people at substantial risk of HIV infection. It is an IM injectable form of pre-exposure prophylaxis that has been shown to be highly effective at reducing the risk of HIV acquisition. The first 2 injections were administered 4 weeks apart, followed thereafter by an injection every 8 weeks.

Zidovudine
Stavudine
Emtricitabine
Abacavir

Lamivudine and emtricitabine are not combined because of similar actions and no added benefits. Emtricitabine is a cytidine analog. It is chemically related to lamivudine and shares most of its pharmacodynamic characteristics.
The same holds good for the zidovudine and stavudine combination. Zidovudine and stavudine are thymidine analogues. In fact, efficacy may even decrease because of competition for a similar activation process.

explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 4:

Which of the following statements about lamivudine is false?
It is an effective agent for patients with chronic hepatitis B
Dose is lower for blocking HIV replication than HBV replication

Should not be used as monotherapy in HBV/HIV infected patients
Anti-HBe seroconversion occurs in a minority of the patients



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 4:
The daily dose of lamivudine indicated for HIV (300 mg) is higher than that of the dose indicated for HBV (100 mg).
Lamivudine has both anti-HIV and anti-HBV activity and is an effective agent for patients with chronic hepatitis B. It should not be used alone because resistance can rapidly emerge in HIV viruses.
Anti-HBe seroconversion occurs in only a minority of the patients taking lamivudine. Drugs that cause anti-HBe seroconversion:
Lamivudine
Entecavir
Adefovir
Tenofovir
Telbivudine
Pegylated interferon

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 5:

A patient on antiretroviral therapy presents with severe tingling and numbness in the legs. On examination, you find that his tendon reflexes are reduced. Which of the following drugs has the highest propensity to cause this condition?
Zidovudine
Lamivudine
Stavudine
Didanosine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
The scenario is suggestive of peripheral neuropathy. The drug causing maximum peripheral neuropathy is stavudine.
The incidence of peripheral neuropathy is very rare with both zidovudine and lamivudine. Lamivudine is considered one of the least toxic antiretroviral agents.
Didanosine is frequently associated with peripheral neuropathy, but stavudine is associated with the highest risk of peripheral neuropathy.

Note: Zalcitabine was associated with a higher incidence of peripheral neuropathy. It is no longer marketed.

1 and 3
2 and 4
3 and 5
1 and 5



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
Abacavir is a guanosine analogue and is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. Raltegravir is an integrase inhibitor.
Nelfinavir, saquinavir and ritonavir are protease inhibitors.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 7:

During a clinical trial, it was noted that the bioavailability of some drugs was substantially improved on ritonavir administration. Which of the following drugs does not exhibit this property?
Saquinavir
Lopinavir
Nelfinavir
Darunavir



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:
The bioavailability of nelfinavir is not substantially improved with ritonavir administration because it undergoes metabolism primarily by CYP2C1› and ritonavir is a weak inhibitor of CYP2C1›.
All other protease inhibitors undergo hepatic oxidative metabolism predominantly by the CYP3A4 enzyme. Ritonavir, being a potent inhibitor of CYP3A4 acts as a pharmacological booster in combination with other protease inhibitors.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Which of the following is a pharmacological booster with no antiretroviral activity?

Ritonavir
Vorinostat
Belinostat
Cobicistat



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:
Cobicistat is a pharmacological booster with no antiretroviral activity.
Cobicistat is a ritonavir analog developed as an exclusive pharmacological booster that inhibits the CYP3A4 enzyme and has no antiviral activity. It is available only in combination with atazanavir or darunavir or elvitegravir for HIV infections.
Ritonavir is also used as a pharmacological booster but it has antiretroviral activity.
Vorinostat and belinostat are histone deacetylase inhibitors. Vorinostat is approved for the treatment of patients with cutaneous T-cell lymphoma with persistent or recurrent disease after two systemic therapies.

The antiviral drug having dual antiviral activity against HIV and HBV is:

Antiviral drug having dual antiviral activity against HIV and HBV is emtricitabine.
It is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor similar to lamivudine. It has activity against HIV-1, HIV-2, and HBV.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Which of the following organisms is most sensitive to penicillin?
Staphylococcus
Streptococcus

[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 1:
Among the given organisms, Treponema pallidum is most sensitive to penicillin. Penicillin G remains the drug of choice for the treatment of syphilis.
Staphylococcus, Streptococcus, and Pneumococcus have developed variable resistance to penicillin G and penicillin G is no longer considered the drug of choice for most of the infections caused by them.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 10:

Which among the following is not a beta-lactamase enzyme inhibitor?
Tazobactam
Clavulanic acid
Piperacillin
Avibactam



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
Piperacillin is not a beta-lactamase enzyme inhibitor. It is an extended-spectrum beta-lactam
(ureidopenicillin) drug having significant antipseudomonal action.
Beta-lactamases are a family of enzymes produced by many gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria that inactivate beta-lactam antibiotics by opening the beta-lactam ring.
Beta-lactamase inhibitors available for clinical use are:
Clavulanic acid
Sulbactam
Tazobactam
Avibactam

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 11:

Which of the following antimicrobials is effective against an organism producing extended-spectrum beta-lactamases?
Amoxicillin - clavulanic acid
Penicillin
Piperacillin - tazobactam
Ceftriaxone



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:

Piperacillin-tazobactam is an antimicrobial that is effective against organisms producing extended-spectrum beta-lactamases.
Extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL) enzyme produced by bacteria causes resistance to most of the penicillins, cephalosporins (third and fourth generation), and monobactams. ESBL is most prevalent among gram-negative organisms like Klebsiella and E. coli.
ESBL can be inhibited by combining beta-lactamase inhibitors like clavulanic acid or tazobactam. Carbapenems and quinolones have inherent activity against ESBL.
Note: As piperacillin has greater activity against Klebsiella and other gram-negative organisms than amoxicillin, piperacillin-tazobactam can be considered as a better option in this question.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 12:

Which of the following is an acid-susceptible penicillin?
Methicillin
Ampicillin

Amoxicillin
Cloxacillin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 12:
Methicillin and nafcillin are penicillinase-resistant penicillins that are acid susceptible and are administered parenterally.
Methicillin use is associated with higher incidence of interstitial nephritis. Ampicillin, amoxicillin and cloxacillin are acid-resistant penicillins.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 13:

A patient who is being treated with an antimicrobial agent presents with neutropenia. Which of the following drugs could be the most likely cause?
Nafcillin
Methicillin
Carbenicillin
Ampicllin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 13:
Neutropenia is seen with nafcillin. It is penicillinase-resistant parenteral penicillin.
It is associated with side effects like neutropenia and interstitial nephritis. In patients with renal failure, it is associated with seizures.
Methicillin is also a penicillinase-resistant penicillin. Its use is associated with a higher incidence of interstitial nephritis than other penicillins, hence it is no longer used.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 14:

A 28-year-old man undergoing treatment with penicillin presents with fever, myalgia, and exacerbation of pre-existing cutaneous lesions. Which of the following diseases is he most probably being treated for?
Rheumatic endocarditis
Gonorrhoea
Syphilis
Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 14:
The given scenario is suggestive of Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction and it is associated with the use of penicillin in syphilis.
Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is a host immune reaction due to the release of spirochetal antigen by the dying T.pallidum in patients on treatment with penicillin. This occurs in primary and most cases of secondary syphilis and is characterized by fever, shivering, myalgia, exacerbation of esions and vascular collapse. Symptomatic treatment suffices and penicillin treatment need not be interrupted.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 15:

A patient who is undergoing treatment with antibiotics presents with diarrhea, fever, and leukocytosis. Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea is suspected. This condition is most commonly associated with the use of which of the following group of drugs?
Aminopenicillins
Tetracyclines
Carbapenems
Macrolide



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 15:
Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea is mostly due to aminopenicillins.

Antibiotic-associated colitis is caused by Clostridium difficile infection due to the destruction of the normal gut microbial flora by the use of antibiotics.
Although all antibiotics can cause the condition, the most commonly implicated are:
Ampicillin (aminopenicillin)
Clindamycin
Third-generation cephalosporins
Fluoroquinolones.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 16:

A patient being treated with ampicillin presents with diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. C. difficile infection is suspected. Which of the following monoclonal antibodies is approved for use in this patient?
Actoxumab
Bezlotoxumab
Bevacizumab
Adalimumab



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 16:
Bezlotoxumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to Clostridium difficile toxin B, indicated to reduce the recurrence of Clostridium difficile infection (CDI).
Actoxumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to Clostridium difficile toxin A but it is not approved because of lack of efficacy.
Adalimumab is an anti-TNF alpha antibody used in rheumatoid arthritis and various other conditions.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 17:

Systemic use of bacitracin is restricted due to:
Ototoxicity
Nephrotoxicity
Cardiotoxicity
Pulmonary toxicity



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 17:
The systemic use of bacitracin is restricted due to nephrotoxicity.
Bacitracin is a polypeptide antibiotic and it inhibits the synthesis of the bacterial cell wall.
Currently, it is used topically for dermal infections and for ophthalmic infections. Parenteral use of this antibiotic leads to nephrotoxicity.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 18:

Daptomycin is not indicated in which of the following conditions?
Complicated skin and soft-tissue infections
Complicated bacteremia
Community acquired pneumonia
Right-sided endocarditis



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 18:
Daptomycin is not indicated in community-acquired pneumonia because even though it penetrates adequately into the lung, it is inactivated by pulmonary surfactant and thus is not useful.
Daptomycin is a cyclic lipopeptide antibiotic. It acts by depolarising bacterial membranes resulting in loss of membrane potential and cell death.
Daptomycin is indicated in the following infections:
Complicated skin and soft-tissue infections
Complicated bacteremia caused by staphylococcus and streptococcus
Right-sided endocarditis
Vancomycin-resistant enterococcal infections

Its efficacy in the above-mentioned conditions is comparable to that of vancomycin.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 19:

Polymyxins are effective against:
Gram-positive bacteria
Gram-negative bacteria
Acid-fast bacilli
Anaerobic bacteria



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 19:
Polymyxins are effective against gram-negative bacteria.
Polymyxin group of antibiotics includes polymyxin B and colistin which have their antimicrobial spectrum limited primarily to gram-negative aerobic bacteria. They interact with the phospholipid of the bacterial cell membranes and disrupt it.
Polymyxins are used in various topical formulations. Parenteral formulations are used only in serious systemic infections that are resistant to other antimicrobials. Nephrotoxicity limits widespread systemic use.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 2:

Which of the following statements about penicillin-binding proteins is false?
Present within cell membrane of bacteria
Mutation in the PBPs gives rise to resistance
PBPs are involved in protein synthesis
These are targeted by imipenem



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 2:
The targets for the action of -lactam antibiotics are collectively termed penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) and they are not involved in protein synthesis.
Transpeptidase enzyme and related proteins constitute the penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) which are present in the bacterial cell membrane. Transpepetidase is involved in the synthesis of peptidoglycan of the bacterial cell wall. All -lactam groups of antibiotics bind to PBPs and inhibit the last step in peptidoglycan synthesis.

Mutation in the different PBPs confers resistance to the bacteria against the beta-lactams. Methicillin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) occurs due to alteration in the PBPs.
Imipenem targets the PBPs, disrupting cell wall synthesis and causing death of the micro-organism.
Beta-lactam group of antibiotics include:
Penicillins
Cephalosporins
Carbapenems
Monobactam

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 20:

What is the mechanism of resistance by lactamases■ to -lactam antibiotics?
Alteration of penicillin binding protein
Degradation of antibiotics
Drug efflux
Alteration in 50s ribosome structure



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 20:
Resistance by lactamases is through the degradation of antibiotics.
The bacterial cell wall is made of heteropolymeric peptidoglycan that confers mechanical stability. The -lactam antibiotics inhibit the last step in peptidoglycan synthesis by acylating the transpeptidase via cleavage of the –CO–N– bond of the -lactam ring. These transpeptidase targets are collectively called Penicillin Binding Proteins (PBPs)
Beta-lactamases are enzymes produced by certain bacteria that inactivates -lactam antibiotics by hydrolysis of the -lactam ring in their structure.
The resistance to penicillins and other beta-lactam antibiotics can be conferred through one of the four mechanisms:
Inactivation of antibiotic by lactamases
Modification of target PBPs
Impaired penetration of drug to target PBPs
Antibiotic efflux

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 21:

A known asthmatic patient with fever and sore throat was prescribed an antibiotic. Two days later he presents with a maculopapular rash. Which of the following drugs might have caused this?
Prednisolone
Salbutamo
Fexofenadine
Amoxicillin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 21:
Skin rashes of all types may be caused by allergy to penicillin.
Amoxicillin and ampicillin are aminopenicillins. The incidence of skin rashes appears to be highest following the use of ampicillin, at about 9%.
Amoxicillin is a close congener of ampicillin with the following features:
Better oral absorption; food does not interfere with the absorption
Incidence of diarrhea is less
More active against penicillin-resistant pneumococci

Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that requires therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) as it has a narrow therapeutic index. It is nephrotoxic and ototoxic (predominantly vestibular effects).
The threshold for toxicity for gentamicin is the plasma concentration of 2 g/mL, the maximum recommended for prolonged exposure.
Aminoglycoside antibiotics act by binding to the 30s ribosome and inhibiting protein synthesis. Their ability to cause misreading of DNA templates and the formation of aberrant proteins that get incorporated into bacterial cell membranes makes them bactericidal agents.
Common ototoxic drugs are:
Antibiotics - aminoglycosides (gentamicin > tobramycin > amikacin > neomycin), erythromycin, tetracyclines.
Chemotherapeutic agents - cisplatin, bleomycin, nitrogen mustards.
High dose aspirin, acetaminophen, NSAID’s
Antimalarials - quinine, quinidine
Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors - sildenafi

Cephalosporins, Vancomycin and Carbapenems

Solution to Question 4:
Penicillin G is not the drug of choice for Lyme disease, but is an alternative to doxycycline, amoxixilline and cefuroxime in the treatment of Lyme disease.
Penicillin G is the drug of choice for all forms of actinomycosis, syphilis and rat-bite fever.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 5:

Which of the following is false about penicillins?
Penicillin V is absorbed orally
Benzathine penicillin is short acting penicillin
Cloxacillin is beta lactamase and acid resistant
Ampicillin is not resistant to beta lactamases



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
Benzathine penicillin G and procaine penicillin G are repository preparations of penicillin G and are long-acting.

They are given as deep I.M. injection. Benzathine penicillin has the longest half-life and is administered every 2-4 weeks.
Penicillin V is an acid-resistant penicillin preparation that is administered orally. Ampicillin has an extended spectrum but is not resistant to beta-lactamases.
Penicillinase-resistant penicillins are:
Cloxacillin
Dicloxacillin
Flucloxacillin
Methicillin
Nafcillin

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 6:

A patient is prescribed probenecid along with penicillin. What is the rationale behind this?
It is a beta lactamase inhibitor
It increases the duration of action of penicillins
It increases the excretion of penicillins in kidney
It decreases the metabolism of penicllins in liver



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
Probenecid is used along with penicillin because it increases the duration of action of penicillin.
Penicillin is excreted by tubular secretion in the kidney. Probenecid is a uricosuric drug used in gout that competes with the same transporter (OATP: organic anion transporter) used by penicillin for tubular secretion. Therefore, it decreases the rate of excretion and increases the duration of action of penicillin.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 7:

The culture and sensitivity report from a wound swab is positive for penicillinase-producing Staphylococcus aureus. Which of the following antimicrobials can be administered?
Amoxicillin
Penicillin G
Piperacillin
Cloxacillin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:
The drug that can be used here is cloxacillin since it is not penicillinase susceptible. It is penicillinase-resistant penicillin.
Bacteria can inactivate -lactam antibiotics by the action of the -lactamase enzyme. The
-lactamases enzyme activity can be narrow or broad spectrum. In general, gram-positive bacteria produce and secrete a large amount of -lactamase. Most of these enzymes are penicillinases.
Penicillinase-resistant penicillins are:
Cloxacillin
Dicloxacillin
Flucloxacillin
Methicillin
Nafcillin
Option B: Penicillin G encompasses the natural preparations and salts of penicillin. They have a narrow spectrum and are susceptible to penicillinase.
Options A and C: Amoxicillin and piperacillin are extended-spectrum penicillins but are susceptible to penicillinase.

Ampicillin
Cloxacillin
Carbenicillin

Piperacillin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:
Cloxacillin is not extended-spectrum penicillin. It is penicillinase-resistant penicillin.
Extended-spectrum penicillins have greater activity than penicillin against gram-negative bacteria because of their enhanced ability to penetrate the Gram-negative outer membrane.
Extended-spectrum penicillins are:
Aminopenicillins - ampicillin, amoxicillin
Carboxypenicillins - carbenicillin, ticarcillin
Ureidopenicillins - piperacillin, mezlocillin

A 22-year-old woman presented with dysuria and high-grade fever. Urine culture sensitivity shows the growth of carbenicillin-sensitive E. coli. Which of the following is true about the antibiotic?
Is effective in Pseudomonas infection
Has no effect in Proteus infection
Is a ureidopenicillins antibiotic
Is administered orally

Solution to Question 9:
Carbenicillin is effective in Pseudomonas infection.
It is extended-spectrum penicillin belonging to the carboxypenicillins group. It has activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and indole-positive Proteus. It is acid labile and is not administered orally.
Antipseudomonal penicillins are:
Carboxypenicillins - carbenicillin, ticarcillin
Ureidopenicillins - mezlocillin, piperacillin

Oral formulation

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 10:

A patient is to be started on a cephalosporin antibiotic. His serum creatinine levels yesterday at the time of admission was 1.1 mg/dl and now it is 1.5 mg/dl. Which of the following cephalosporins can be started without dose reduction in this patient?
Cefuroxime
Cefoperazone
Ceftazidime
Cefotaxime



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
The given scenario is suggestive of acute kidney injury and the cephalosporin that does not require dose reduction in this patient is cefoperazone.
All cephalosporins are usually excreted by glomerular filtration and tubular secretion. They need a dose reduction in renal failure, except cefpiramide and cefoperazone that have predominant biliary excretion.
Dose reduction is necessary for cefoperazone and cefpiramide in patients with hepatic impairment.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 11:

What is the drug of choice for a patient who presents with an initial episode of Clostridium difficile infection?
Metronidazole
Vancomycin
Fidaxomicin
Loracarbef



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
The drug of choice for the treatment of initial episode of Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) is fidaxomicin. It is a macrocyclic antibiotic.

Fidaxomicin is preferred because of its safety profile and higher beneficial effects. But in resource-limited settings where it is not available, vancomycin can be used for the treatment of this condition.
Treatment of Clostridium difficile infection:
Fidaxomicin
Vancomycin
Metronidazole
Vancomycin and fidaxomicin are more effective than metronidazole. All of the above drugs are given orally.
Loracarbef is a second-generation cephalosporin and is not indicated in pseudomembranous colitis caused by Clostridium difficile.
NOTE:
As per the Infectious Disease Society of America (IDSA) management guidelines 2021, Fidaxomicin is now preferred over Vancomycin for the treatment of initial episode of Clostridium difficile infection. Vancomycin can be used as an alternative drug.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 12:

What is the mechanism of action of vancomycin?
Cell wall synthesis inhibition
Cell membrane inhibition
Peptide synthesis inhibition
50s ribosome inhibition



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 12:
The mechanism of action of vancomycin is cell wall synthesis inhibition.
The bacterial cell wall has long chains of peptidoglycan and is cross-linked to each other by the action of the enzyme transglycosylase. Vancomycin is a glycopeptide group of antibiotics that binds to the D-alanyl-D-alanine terminus of the synthesized peptidoglycan. This inhibits the transglycosylase enzyme and prevents elongation and cross-linking of peptidoglycan. This leads to the weakening of the cell wall causing lysis.
It exhibits a time-dependant or concentration-independent killing of bacteria. It primarily acts on Gram +ve organisms which are resistant to other antibiotics such as methicillin-resistant staphylococcus and ampicillin resistant enterococci.
Lipoglycopeptides are a new generation of glycopeptide congeners which include telavancin, dalbavancin, and oritavancin. Dalbavancin and Oritovancin are administered as a single intravenous dose for skin and soft-tissue infections.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 13:

Oral vancomycin is used in the treatment of :
1, 4 and 5
1, 2 and 4
1 and 3
3 and 5



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 13:
Oral vancomycin is used in the treatment of Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea and staphylococcal enterocolitis.
Its oral formulation is not absorbed systemically and hence is used for local action in the gastrointestinal tract.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 14:

A patient on intravenous vancomycin develops flushing and erythematous lesions. On examination, tachycardia, and hypotension are noted. By what mechanism does vancomycin cause these effects?
Allergic reaction
Direct toxic effect on mast cells
Histamine antagonist action
Immune-complex deposition



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 14:
The given scenario depicts red man syndrome associated with vancomycin. It occurs due to a direct toxic effect on mast cells resulting in the release of histamine.
Red man or red neck syndrome is a non-allergic reaction due to rapid intravenous infusion of vancomycin characterized by:
Flushing
Erythematous, urticarial reactions
Tachycardia
Hypotension
Slow infusion, prophylactic use of antihistamines can reduce the incidence.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 15:

Match the following bacteria with the drug of choice for each.
A-1, B-3, C-4, D-2
A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3
A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2
A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 15:
Vancomycin is the drug of choice for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). It should be used only if the organism is resistant to other drugs.

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for anaerobic infections caused by Bacteroides. Metronidazole is used in the treatment of the following conditions:
Giardiasis
Trichomoniasis
Amoebiasis
Bacterial vaginosis
Pseudomembranous colitis
Meropenem is used in infections caused by ESBL producing bacteria like Klebsiella.
Carbapenems are not hydrolyzed by ESBL (extended-spectrum beta-lactamases). Therefore, carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem and ertapenem are resistant to hydrolysis by ESBLs. They are indicated in the treatment of infections caused by ESBL producing bacteria,
like Klebsiella and E. coli.
Penicillins like amoxicillin, ampicillin can be used in H. influenzae infections.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 16:

A patient allergic to penicillin requires antibiotic therapy. Which of the following can you safely prescribe?
Aztreonam
Cefepime
Imipenem
Ceftriaxone



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 16:
Aztreonam can be safely given to a patient with a history of allergy to penicillin. It is a monobactam group of -Lactam antibiotics resistant to narrow-spectrum beta-lactamase produced by bacteria.
It lacks cross-sensitivity with the other beta-lactams, except for ceftazidime. It has activity only against gram-negative bacteria. It has no activity against gram-positive bacteria and anaerobes.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 17:

Which of the following carbapenems has increased risk of causing seizures?
Meropenem
Imipenem
Etrapenem
Doripenem



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 17:
Imipenem is the carbapenem that is associated with an increased risk of causing seizures, especially when high doses are given to patients with CNS lesions.
Excretion of imipenem is mainly renal and dosage modification is required to avoid seizures in renal failure patients.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Which of the following statements is false about extended-spectrum beta-lactamases?
They can hydrolyse penicillins, cephalosporins as well as monobactam

Ambler classification of ESBL is based on amino acid sequence
Third and fourth generation cephalosporins are used for detection of ESBL



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 18:
Carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem, ertapenem are resistant to hydrolysis by
extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBL) and hence are indicated in the treatment of infections caused by ESBL producing bacteria.
Beta-lactamases are enzymes produced by bacteria that are able to hydrolyze antibiotics and make them ineffective, thus making the bacteria resistant to these antibiotics. They confer resistance against:

Penicillins
Cephalosporins
Monobactams
Beta lactamases hydrolyze first and second-generation cephalosporins but are ineffective against third and fourth-generation.
Beta lactamases are classified into four categories based on their amino acid sequences, by the Ambler classification.
ESBLs also hydrolyze third and fourth-generation cephalosporins - cefotaxime, ceftazidime, ceftriaxone and cefepime.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Meropenem
Imipenem
Cefazolin
Piperacillin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 19:
Cilastatin is administered to prolong the action of imipenem.
Imipenem is rapidly hydrolyzed by the enzyme renal dehydropeptidase. It is administered with cilastatin, a reversible inhibitor of dehydropeptidase to inhibit the breakdown and prolong the action of imipenem.
Meropenem is not hydrolyzed by renal dehydropeptidase. Cilastatin administration is not necessary with meropenem.



Vaborbactam is a recently approved non-suicidal beta-lactamase inhibitor. It is indicated in combination with meropenem for complicated urinary tract infections.
Sulbactam, tazobactam and clavulanic acid are suicidal inhibitors of beta-lactamase enzyme.
Suicidal inhibitors are irreversible inhibitors that can permanently inactivate the -lactamase through secondary chemical reactions in the enzyme active site.

Miscellaneous Antimicrobials

What is the mechanism of action of oseltamivir and zanamivir?
DNA polymerase inhibition
Protein synthesis inhibition
Nucleotide analogue
Neuraminidase inhibition



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
Oseltamivir and zanamivir are neuraminidase inhibitors.
They competitively and reversibly interact with the enzyme sites to inhibit viral neuraminidase activity. This interferes with the release of the progeny from infected host cells, halting the spread of infection.
Early administration hastens the resolution of symptoms if given within 48 h of infection. Oseltamivir is given at a dose of 75 mg, BD for 5 days for the treatment of Influenza A and B.
For prophylaxis, it is given at a dose of 75mg, OD and continued for the duration of exposure.

Metronidazole is selectively active against anaerobic and microaerophilic organisms because:

Metronidazole is selectively active against anaerobic and microaerophilic organisms because only these organisms reduce it to generate reactive nitro radicals.

Babesiosis is a zoonotic infection that resembles malaria. It presents with febrile illness, hemolysis and hemoglobinuria.
For mild or moderate disease: Azithromycin plus atovaquone. For severe disease:

Alternative regimen - clindamycin plus quinine.
Severe babesiosis typically occurs in patients with one or more of the following characteristics: age >50 years, neonatal prematurity, asplenia/hyposplenism, HIV/AIDS, malignancy, and immunosuppressive therapy.



Pyrimethamine is the most effective agent against toxoplasmosis and is present in most of the regimens. It is combined with sulfadiazine or clindamycin for toxoplasmosis.

Solution to Question 4:
Metronidazole is not effective in the management of pneumocystosis caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii. Co-trimoxazole is used in the management of this condition.
Metronidazole is used in the following conditions:
Giardiasis
Trichomoniasis
Amoebiasis

Bacterial vaginosis
Anaerobic infections - bacteroides and clostridium.
Pseudomembranous colitis (alternative to vancomycin & fidaxomicin)

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 5:

A 6-year-old boy presents with lower abdominal pain and diarrhea. The stool examination finding is shown below. Which of the following drugs cannot be used for the eradication of intestinal cysts in this condition?



Diloxanide furoate
Nitazoxanide
Metronidazole
Iodoquino



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
The image shows hematophagous trophozoite of Entamoeba histolytica and metronidazole is not an effective agent against cysts of amoeba in the colon.
Metronidazole is used in the treatment of amoebiasis (amoebic colitis, amoebic liver abscess). It is well absorbed from the small intestine and only a small amount of the unabsorbed drug reaches the colon, which is insufficient to kill the cysts.
Hence, luminal agents like diloxanide furoate, nitazoxanide or iodoquinol are required for the eradication of cysts and trophozoites in the intestine.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 6:

Which of the following is used in the treatment of a patient with asymptomatic intestinal amoebiasis?
Metronidazole
Tinidazole
Paromomycin
Tetracycline



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
The drug of choice for the treatment of asymptomatic intestinal luminal amoebiasis due to E. histolytica is paromomycin.
Paromomycin (aminosidine) is an aminoglycoside that has poor oral absorption and hence it acts only in the intestinal lumen as a luminal amebicide. It has no effect against extraintestinal organisms.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 7:

A 21-year-old male presented to the OPD complaining of blood-streaked stools. Sigmoidoscopy was done and it showed ulcers in the sigmoid. Biopsy was taken from this area and the histopathological image is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?



Intravenous ceftriaxone
Intravenous metronidazole
Intravenous paromomycin
Intravenous chloroquine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical picture and the histopathological image showing flask-shaped ulcers are suggestive of intestinal amoebiasis. The most appropriate treatment is intravenous metronidazole.
The amoebic ulcer which is flask-shaped is the typical lesion seen in intestinal amoebiasis. The ulcers are multiple and are confined to the colon. Sometimes, in secondary intestinal lesions, the ulcers are numerous in the cecum, followed by the sigmoido-rectal region.
Three classes of drugs are used in the treatment of amebiasis:
Luminal amoebicides- diloxanide furoate, iodoquinol, paromomycin, and tetracycline. They act in the intestinal lumen but not in tissues.
Tissue amoebicides- emetine and chloroquine. They are effective in systemic infection but less effective in the intestine.
Both luminal and tissue amebicides- Metronidazole, tinidazole and imidazole. They act on both sites and are the drug of choice for treating amebic colitis and amebic liver abscess.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 8:

A patient presents with sudden onset fever with chills and malaise. On examination splenomegaly was present. Bone marrow picture is shown in the image. Which of the following drugs is not used in the treatment of this condition?


Paromomycin

Liposomal amphotericin B
Hydroxychloroquine
Miltefosine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:
The given scenario and the bone marrow picture showing macrophages infected with intracellular Leishman-Donovan bodies point towards a diagnosis of visceral
leishmaniasis. Hydroxychloroquine is not indicated in the treatment of this condition. The drugs effective in visceral leishmaniasis are:
Liposomal amphotericin B (preferred)
Sodium stibogluconate (not in India)
Miltefosine
Paromomycin
Pentamidine (rarely used)
Hydroxychloroquine is an antimalarial agent and is also used in the treatment of dermatological conditions like:
Cutaneous lupus erythematosus
Cutaneous dermatomyositis
Polymorphous light eruption
Porphyria cutanea tarda
Sarcoidosis

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 9:

A 32-year-old woman presents with the finding as shown in the image. She gives history of travel to South America and was bitten by a reduvid bug. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this condition?


Nifurtimox
Albendazole
Benznidazole
Metronidazole



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 9:
The scenario and the image showing Romaña sign point towards a diagnosis of Chagas disease
(American trypanosomiasis) and the drug of choice in this condition is benznidazole.
American trypanosomiasis is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi and can be managed by either benznidazole or nifurtimox. Due to its favorable safety profile, benznidazole is considered the drug of choice.
Romaña sign is the unilateral painless periorbital swelling associated with the acute stage of Chagas disease.
Albendazole and metronidazole are not indicated for American trypanosomiasis. Albendazole is used in infections with Ascaris lumbricoides, Trichuris trichiura and hookworms. Metronidazole is used in the treatment of trichomoniasis and amebiasis.

explanation:

Monitoring of drug potency
Monitoring of drug efficacy



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 1:
Pharmacovigilance deals with the monitoring of drug safety. WHO definition of pharmacovigilance:
"Science and activities related to the detection, assessment, understanding, and prevention of adverse effects or any other drug-related problems”.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 10:

A pharmacologically inert substance used along with an active ingredient in a formulation is known as the:
Placebo
Nocebo
Excipient
Inducer



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:

An excipient is a pharmacologically inert substance used along with an active ingredient in a formulation. e.g., starch, lactose, FDKP
Role of excipients:
Add bulk to the active drug if used in small quantities
Increase the stability of the formulation
Mask unpleasant taste
Inhaled insulin (Afrezza) consists of 2- to 2.5-m crystals of the excipient, fumaryl diketopiperazine (FDKP), that provides a large surface area for adsorption of proteins like insulin.
Option A: Placebo is an inert substance given in the form of medication. It is generally not combined with the active ingredient.
Endorphins may play a role in the placebo effect especially for analgesic action.
It is used in the controls of clinical trials to elucidate the actual drug effect.
Not all but only a few patients respond to the placebo.
Option B: Nocebo is the opposite of the placebo effect where the patient experiences a negative psychodynamic effect due to their pessimistic attitude towards the medications or healthcare professionals.
Option C: Inducers refer to agents that increase the expression of cytochrome enzymes involved in the metabolism of drugs.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Which one of the following is a placebo?
Herbal medication with no effect known
Physiotherapy
Sham surgery
Cognitive behavioural therapy



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
Sham surgery (placebo surgery) is a faked surgical intervention that omits the step thought to be therapeutically necessary.
Note: While option A may be considered a placebo due to there being no known effects, it is not certain as to whether all possible effects (known and unknown) have been considered. Hence, weighing options A and C, the better option among the two would be C as sham surgery is a widely used placebo.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 12:

Which of the following are not reasons for the alteration of drug dosage in the elderly?

They have decreasing renal function with age
They have loss of lean body mass
They have increased baroreceptor sensitivity
Their total body water is decreased



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 12:
The reason for the alteration of drug dosage in the elderly is decreased baroreceptor sensitivity due to age-related vascular stiffening.
Reasons for the alteration of drug dosage in the elderly are:
Progressive decline of renal function
Loss of lean body mass and an increased ratio of fat to muscle, leading to an increased volume of distribution of lipophilic drugs
Decreased body water - causing volume of distribution (Vd) of hydrophilic drugs decreases.

Slower absorption due to reduced gut motility.
Plasma albumin decreases with aging which leads to decreased plasma protein binding.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 13:

A patient started on an anti-epileptic for epilepsy developed toxic epidermal necrolysis. It was documented as a type A adverse drug reaction. Which of the following is not true regarding this adverse effect?
These reactions occur due to genetically determined abnormal reactivity to a drug.
These reactions can be predicted from the drug’s known pharmacological or toxicological effects
These reactions are generally dose-dependent
These reactions are usually common



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 13:
Type A (augmented) adverse drug reactions (ADR) are not based upon the qualitatively abnormal responses to the drug. It is based on the pharmacological properties of the drug.
Examples of type A ADR:
Side effects
Toxic effects
Consequences of drug withdrawal.
They are common, reversible, and preventable.
Idiosyncrasy refers to the genetically determined abnormal reactivity to a drug. Adverse drug reactions can be classified into two types:

Type A reactions – sometimes referred to as augmented reactions – are dose-dependent and predictable based on the pharmacology of the drug

Type B reactions – bizarre reactions – which are idiosyncratic and not predictable on the basis of drug pharmacology. They can be based on the characteristics of patients.

Tetracycline
Thalidomide
Warfarin

Alcohol



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 14:
The baby has features suggestive of phocomelia and it results due to the consumption of thalidomide during pregnancy.
Phocomelia is associated with underdeveloped limbs and absent pelvic bones. Both upper and lower limbs are affected and a part of the limbs may be missing. Fused fingers and missing thumbs are also seen.
Thalidomide was originally used for the treatment of pregnancy-associated morning sickness but was withdrawn due to this adverse effect.
It re-entered the market for the treatment of erythema nodosum leprosum. It also has antiangiogenic and immunomodulatory effects.

Which of the following drugs cannot cross the placenta and can safely be used in a pregnant woman?
Phenytoin
Diazepam
Morphine
Heparin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 16:
Heparin is a large molecule and cannot cross the placenta. Hence, heparin can be used safely in a pregnant woman.
Unfractionated or low molecular weight heparin is the preferred anticoagulant in pregnancy. Option A: Phenytoin crosses the placenta and can cause fetal hydantoin syndrome.
Options B and C: Diazepam and morphine are lipophilic molecules and can cross the placenta.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 17:

'Me-too drugs' do not differ significantly in which of the following pharmacological features as compared to the prototypical drug?
Absorption
Metabolism
Mechanism of action
Elimination



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 17:
Me-too drugs are chemically related to the prototype or other chemical compounds that have an identical mechanism of action.
Various statins present in the market can be considered as "Me-too drugs". The pharmacokinetic parameters (absorption, distribution, metabolism, and elimination) vary significantly between them (atorvastatin and rosuvastatin have a very long duration of action), but the core mechanism of action remains the same: HMG CoA reductase inhibition and decrease in cholesterol synthesis.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 18:

As a medical officer in a PHC, you anticipate a rise in infections following the worsening flood in your area. You write a letter to the district collector requesting to provide an additional supply of essential medicines. Which of the following best describes these medicines?
These are drugs needed to treat emergency conditions

These are drugs needed to treat serious diseases
These are drugs that satisfy the priority health needs of the population
These are drugs that have been in use for a long time



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 18:
Essential medicines are those medicines that satisfy the priority health care needs of the population.
They are selected with due regard to:
Public health relevance
Evidence on efficacy and safety
Comparative cost-effectiveness
WHO publishes a model list of essential medicines that provides a framework for individual nations to draw their own national list. The 21st Essential Medicines List, published in April 2019 brings the total to 460 drugs deemed essential for addressing the most important public health needs globally.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 19:

The schedule that deals with prescription drugs under the Drugs and Cosmetics Act is
.
Schedule P
Schedule H
Schedule Y
Schedule D



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 19:
Schedule H deals with prescription drugs. All the drugs listed under schedule H should be provided to the patient only with the prescription from a registered medical practitioner.

All the drugs under the list must have the warning mentioned below, on their packaging listed prominently.
"Schedule H drug. Warning: To be sold by retail on the prescription of a registered medical practitioner only"
Schedule H1: To be sold on the production of a valid prescription, but the chemist will maintain a separate register where the identity of the patient, contact details of the prescribing doctor, and the name and dispensed quantity of the drug will be recorded. The dispensing quantity should be strictly according to the valid prescription. It is a recently introduced list with the objective of curtailing indiscriminate use of antimicrobials.
Schedule X: To be sold with a valid prescription. Prescription in duplicate, separate license requirements, meticulous storage, and dispensing records must be maintained by the chemist. The drugs that have high abuse liability are included in schedule X.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Which of the following organizations regulates the clinical trials and approval of investigational new drugs in India?
CPCSEA
CDSCO
FDA
DCGI



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 2:
Central Drug Standard Control Organisation (CDSCO) regulates the clinical trials and approval of investigational new drugs in India.
The proposal for initiating trials, review of clinical trial results, and recommendations for marketing authorization is done through a committee called the Investigational New Drug (IND) Committee formed by CDSCO.
Preclinical trials are performed on animals, and they are regulated by guidelines prescribed by the Committee for the Purpose of the Control and Supervision of Experiments on Animals (CPCSEA) in India.
The Drugs Controller General of India (DCGI) is the head of the CDSCO, under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in India.

According to The Drugs and Cosmetics Act-1945,
Schedule X drugs are those that have high abuse liability and are to be sold with a valid prescription only.
A prescription in duplicate, separate license requirement, meticulous storage, and dispensing records must be maintained by the chemist.
Option B: Thalidomide is a schedule H drug. Option D: Colistin is a schedule P drug.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 21:

A first-year resident administers an intramuscular injection to a patient by the Z track technique. What is the advantage of this technique?
Increase absorption rate
Prevent staining of skin
Reduce allergic manifestations
Longer duration of action



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 21:
The advantage of the 'Z-track technique' for intramuscular administration is that it prevents skin staining.
Z-track technique procedure:
Stretch the skin by pulling it laterally away from the intended point of injection.
Insert the needle into the site at a 90■ angle, aspirate by pulling back to see if the needle has a penetrated vessel.
If blood is aspirated withdraw the needle, and repeat the procedure at another site with new equipment and medication.
If no blood is aspirated administer the injection.
Wait for 10 seconds and then withdraw the needle, and release the skin allowing the displaced tissue to seal the needle track.
Advantages:

The 'Z-track' prevents leakage of the medication into the subcutaneous tissue and skin staining through the tract to the surface of the skin
Pain intensity is also reduced

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 3:

You are working as a research associate on clinical trials of a new drug for migraine. What is the dose of the test drug that is usually not exceeded in phase 0 studies?
1000 mcg
1000 mg
100 mcg
100 mg



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 3:
The dose of the test drug in phase 0 studies usually does not exceed 100mcg. Phase 0 studies are also called micro-dosing studies.
Very low doses of drugs, usually 1/100th of the estimated human dose or a maximum of 100 mcg is used.
They are done to obtain pharmacokinetic data in humans at a very early stage of drug development. The micro-dosing stage is not mandatory and not clearly categorized by regulatory authorities yet.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 4:

Good clinical practice is not required in which phase of clinical trials?
Preclinical phase
Phase 1 trial

Phase 2 trial
Phase 3 trial



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 4:
Good clinical practice is not required in the preclinical phase.
Good clinical practice (GCP) is an international ethical and scientific quality standard for the design, conduct, performance, monitoring, auditing, recording, analyses, and reporting of clinical trials. It is primarily for the conduct of clinical trials in humans.
Preclinical trials are performed on animals and they are regulated by guidelines prescribed
by the CPCSEA (Committee for the Purpose of the Control and Supervision of Experiments on Animals) in India. The guidelines are laid down in good laboratory practice (GLP).

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 5:

Which of the following is not a primary endpoint in phase 1 studies?
Safety
Tolerability
Pharmacokinetic parameters
Efficacy



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
Efficacy is not a primary endpoint in phase 1 studies. Phase 1 studies are generally done in healthy volunteers. Efficacy can be a secondary endpoint in some studies where patients are recruited.
The primary endpoints are:
Safety
Tolerability of single/multiple doses
Pharmacokinetic parameters
The primary endpoint denotes the purpose of the study for which it is primarily designed. The secondary endpoint denotes the measure of the valuable outcome of the study design.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 6:

Which of the following phases of a clinical trial is also referred to as efficacy trial?
Phase 1
Phase 2
Phase 3
Phase 4



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
Efficacy and appropriate dose range is the main aim of phase 2 of clinical trials. It is evaluated on a small group of patients with the target disease.
Phase II of clinical trials involve a small group of patients (50-500). Most of the new drugs will be administered for the first time in patients with the target disease. The study is designed to obtain proof of concept (potential of the drug to treat the disease) and dose-ranging study (provides input for choosing the most appropriate dose for phase 3 studies).
Phase 3 studies are also known as pivotal studies as they establish treatment benefits.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 7:

You read a news alert that mentions a novel drug has received marketing approval for diabetes mellitus and that it has shown positive results in a pivotal trial. This corresponds to which phase of clinical trials?
Phase I
Phase II
Phase III
Phase IV



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:
Phase III trials are usually considered pivotal trials and are necessary for the approval of the majority of drugs. They are also called multi-site trials and are done for 3–5 years.

When the initial Phase III trials are complete, the sponsor (usually a pharmaceutical company) applies to the FDA for approval to market the drug. This application is called either a New Drug Application (NDA) or a Biologics License Application (BLA).
In some drugs related to rare diseases or malignancies, phase II studies are considered as pivotal, and the drug may be approved on the basis of phase II studies.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 8:

A pharmaceutical company has set up a team of physicians to oversee the Phase IV clinical trial of a new drug for SARS-CoV2 infection, to identify possible drug interactions. Which is the most appropriate statement about this phase of the clinical trial?

Done in a group of 50-500 patients
Done after a drug is approved and marketed
Done for drugs used in rare diseases
Done for formulating guidelines for therapeutic use



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:
Phase IV study is conducted after the drug is approved and marketed by regulatory authorities. It includes post-marketing surveillance and other studies that complement the earlier findings of the drug.
After the drug is marketed for general use, practicing physicians are identified through whom data about the efficacy, acceptability, and adverse effects of the drug are collected on a structured proforma. Patients treated in the normal course form the study population. Therefore the study population is much larger. Uncommon adverse effects or those that occur only after long-term use and unsuspected drug interactions are detected at this stage.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 9:

Which of the following statements are true?
1, 3 and 4
2 and 4
2, 4 and 5
1, 2 and 3



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 9:
Orphan drugs are for the treatment or prevention of rare diseases with little commercial value for pharmaceutical companies. Orphan receptors are receptors that are discovered yet no known ligands are identified.
There are two types of drug development. They are:
Traditional drug development: Initial drug discovery is followed by the characterization of the receptors the drugs are used to act on.
Contemporary drug development: Due to advances in molecular biology and genome sequencing, receptors are identified initially. The drugs are identified later using chemical screening later resulting in the discovery of orphan receptors.
Special incentives are given by the government to pharmaceutical companies for the development and marketing of orphan drugs.
Few examples of orphan drugs are:
Liposomal amphotericin B
Digoxin antibody (Digibind)
Fomepizole

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Which of the following is a polyene antifungal agent?
Capsofungin
Griseofulvin
Amphotericin B
Terbinafine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 1:
Amphotericin B is a polyene antifungal. Other polyene antifungals are:
Amphotericin B

Nystatin
Natamycin
Hamycin
Amphotericin B is the least toxic among polyenes and is used systemically for fungal infections. Nystatin and hamycin have high systemic toxicity and are used only for local and topical actions.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 10:

To which of the following patients will you not prescribe griseofulvin?
A middle aged man with tinea capitis
A student with tinea cruris
A child with tinea versicolor
An athlete with tinea pedis



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
Griseofulvin is not useful in the treatment of tinea versicolor. It is treated with topical azoles.
Tinea capitis, tinea cruris and tinea pedis are dermatophytoses. Griseofulvin is indicated only for dermatophytoses caused by species of Microsporum, Epidermophyton, and Trichophyton. It is considered the drug of choice for tinea capitis in children. It is reserved only for large topical tinea infections when topical therapy is inadequate.
Tinea versicolor is not a dermatophytosis. It is a superficial mycosis caused by lipophilic yeast Malassezia.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 11:

Which of the following can cause contraceptive failure in a lady on oral contraceptive pills?
Ketoconazole
Fluconazole
Griseofulvin
Flucytosine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
Griseofulvin is a cytochrome enzyme inducer and can cause contraceptive failure when taken with oral contraceptive pills.
It induces hepatic CYP enzymes and can increase the metabolism of drugs. Warfarin metabolism is increased and the dose has to be adjusted according to the change in response. Estrogen metabolism is also increased thereby reducing the efficacy of low-dose estrogen-based oral contraceptives.
Note: Ketoconazole is a cytochrome enzyme inhibitor.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 12:

Fungal cell wall synthesis is altered by which of the following drugs?
Caspofungin
Amphotericin B
Nystatin
Flucytosine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 12:

Fungal cell wall synthesis is altered by caspofungin.
1,3--D glucan is an essential component of the fungal cell wall which maintains cell
integrity. Echinocandin group of antifungals like caspofungin, anidulafungin, and micafungin acts by inhibiting the synthesis of 1,3--D-glucan and thereby weakens the fungal cell wall and increases the osmotic susceptibility.
Echinocandins are fungicidal against Candida species. They show fungistatic activity against Aspergillus species.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 13:

What is the mechanism of triazoles?
Interferes with DNA and RNA synthesis
Inhibition of ergosterol synthesis
Forms pores in fungal membranes
Inhibits epoxidation of squalene in fungi



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 13:
Triazoles act by inhibition of ergosterol synthesis.
The azole group inhibits the fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme called 14- -sterol demethylase and results in an impairment of conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol. This results in the depletion of membrane ergosterol.
Azole antifungals are of two types:
Imidazoles - clotrimazole, ketoconazole, luliconazole
Triazoles - itraconazole, fluconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole and isavuconazole

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 14:

A patient was diagnosed with coccidioidal meningitis. What is the drug of choice for the condition?
Itraconazole
Fluconazole
Amphotericin B
Griseofulvin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 14:
Fluconazole is the drug of choice for coccidioidal meningitis caused by Coccidioides immitis because of better CSF penetration.
Itraconazole is also effective in this condition but it is not the drug of choice. Amphotericin B is indicated in patients in whom triazoles have failed.
Note: Amphotericin B is the drug of choice for initial treatment of cryptococcal meningitis caused by Cryptococcus neoformans and fluconazole is used for maintenance therapy.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 15:

A middle aged man presents with the condition shown in the image. Which of the following drugs can cause this condition?


Fluconazole
Itraconazole
Ketoconazole

Voriconazole



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 15:
The image above depicts gynecomastia and can be caused by ketoconazole due to its antiandrogenic action.
Ketoconazole use results in various antiandrogenic effects. It decreases testosterone production and displaces testosterone from protein binding sites in plasma. It also decreases hydrocortisone production, especially at higher doses. Adverse effects that can occur are gynecomastia, loss of hair, libido, and oligozoospermia.
Fluconazole, itraconazole and voriconazole do not have antiandrogenic action.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 16:

Which of the following is not an indication for ketoconazole use?
Cushing’s syndrome
Dermal leishmaniasis
Addison’s disease
Kala azar



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 16:
Ketoconazole is not indicated for use in Addison’s disease.
It is a potent nonselective inhibitor of adrenal and gonadal steroidogenesis by inhibiting 17
 -hydroxylase enzymes which are involved in steroid hormone synthesis and it can hence worsen Addison's disease. However, this property also makes it useful in the treatment of Cushing’s syndrome.
Azoles interfere with leishmanial cell membrane biosynthesis and are therefore used in dermal leishmaniasis and kala-azar.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 17:

While administering which of the following drugs will you counsel patients regarding transient visual and auditory hallucinations?
Oral voriconazole

Intravenous itraconazole



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 17:
Transient visual or auditory hallucinations are commonly seen with the use of intravenous voriconazole. These usually occur at night.
Other side effects of voriconazole are:
Hepatotoxicity
Prolonged QTc interval and increased risk of torsades de pointes
Anaphylactoid reaction when given intravenously

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Omeprazole dose is reduced when given along with voriconazole because of what action of the latter drug?
