subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 14:

In a middle-aged diabetic patient with chronic kidney disease stage 5, which of the following drugs can be given safely without altering the dose?
Vildagliptin
Linagliptin
Saxagliptin
Sitagliptin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 14:
Linagliptin can be given safely without altering the dose for this patient.

Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl-peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor and is eliminated by the hepatobiliary route. Hence no dosage adjustment is needed in renal failure.
It is used in type 2 diabetes as monotherapy or as combination therapy with other drugs when metformin is not tolerated or contraindicated.
Other DPP-4 inhibitors like sitagliptin, vildagliptin, saxagliptin, alogliptin show renal elimination.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 15:

Which of the following is not true about dapagliflozin?
It is indicated in heart failure
It causes weight gain
It is effective orally
It will increase the risk of fractures



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 15:
Dapagliflozin does not cause weight gain. It results in weight loss.
It acts by inhibiting the SGLT2 (sodium glucose-2) transporter, which is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule and responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose. It inhibits glucose reabsorption resulting in glycosuria and a decrease in blood glucose level. It is effective orally.
The common adverse effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine and also the high risk of fractures.
Other SGLT2 inhibitors include empagliflozin, canagliflozin, and ertugliflozin.
Note: Empagliflozin has been found to decrease the risk of mortality from cardiovascular causes in diabetic patients. Dapagliflozin has been recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction(HFrEF) in both diabetic and non-diabetic patients.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 16:

A patient with diabetes mellitus came to the OPD with a history suggestive of recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia. She was recently put on combination therapy. Her symptoms are least likely to be caused by which of the following drugs?
Acarbose
Insulin
Gliclazide
Repaglinide



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 16:
Acarbose is least likely to cause hypoglycemia among the given options.
It is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor. It inhibits the intestinal degradation and absorption of starch and disaccharides and thereby lowers the postprandial rise in glucose levels.
It has no role in stimulating insulin secretion and is therefore, least likely to cause hypoglycemia during monotherapy.
Insulin and insulin secretagogues like sulfonylureas (gliclazide) and meglitinides (repaglinide) can result in hypoglycemia.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 17:

While at a bakery, a man complains of giddiness and palpitations. As the only doctor there, you're asked for help. The man says he had just taken his diabetic medications and shows a prescription listing insulin and acarbose. What would you give for immediate management?
Honey
Bread

Sugar
Cake



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 17:
Giddiness and palpitations after taking insulin and acarbose are suggestive of
hypoglycemia. Honey is the most suitable agent among the given options for the management of hypoglycemia in a patient who is on acarbose therapy.
Acarbose is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor. It inhibits the intestinal degradation of starch and disaccharides into glucose. Honey contains monosaccharides (fructose and glucose) that do not need to be broken down and are directly absorbed and would be beneficial in hypoglycemia

caused by alpha-glucosidase inhibitors. However, glucose or dextrose tablets is recommended when available.
While alpha-glucosidase inhibitors themselves do not cause hypoglycemia, the risk of hypoglycemia is increased when they are taken along with insulin or insulin secretagogues.
Disaccharides and complex carbohydrates will not be completely broken down and absorbed in a patient who is on alpha-glucosidase inhibitors.
Option B - Bread predominantly contains complex carbohydrates like starch Option C - Sugar contains sucrose, a disaccharide
Option D - Cake contains sugar (disaccharide) and other complex carbohydrates

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 18:

A 52-year-old diabetic patient presented to the ED with complaints of chest pain on exertion. Laboratory tests showed dyslipidemia and features of metabolic syndrome. Which of the following drugs was recently approved for this condition?
Aleglitazar
Saroglitazar
Muraglitazar
Rosiglitazone



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 18:
Saroglitazar is a dual PPAR alpha/gamma agonist and is approved for diabetic dyslipidemia only in India.
Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs) are a superfamily of nuclear receptors involved in the regulation of energy homeostasis and metabolic function. It has three subtypes:
PPAR - reduces triglyceride leve
PPAR - causes insulin sensitization
PPAR - enhances fatty acids metabolism
Of the three PPAR isoforms, synthetic pharmaceutical ligands that activate PPARalpha (the antidyslipidemic fibrates) and PPARgamma (the antidiabetic thiazolidinediones) have been studied extensively. Recently developed dual PPARalpha/gamma agonists combine the therapeutic effects of these drugs to be used in type 2 diabetes with dyslipidemia.
Options A and C - Aleglitazar and muraglitazar are also dual PPAR alpha/gamma agonists but their development was halted due to increased risk of cardiovascular mortality.
Option D - Rosiglitazone is a PPAR gamma agonist indicated in type 2 diabetes mellitus. It has been withdrawn from many countries including India due to increased cardiovascular mortality.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Which of the following is approved as an adjunctive treatment for type 2 diabetes mellitus?
Bromocriptine
Phenytoin
Ropinirole
Metoclopromide



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 19:
Bromocriptine is a dopamine agonist that has been approved as an adjunctive treatment for diabetes mellitus.
The exact mechanism is unknown but may involve alteration in circadian (hypothalamic) control of blood glucose levels. A fast-release, low-dose formulation of bromocriptine is approved for type 2 diabetes that has to be administered within 3 hours of awakening.
Option B - Phenytoin is a Na+ channel blocker and is an antiepileptic drug
Option C - Ropinirole is an antiparkinsonian drug that is a dopamine agonist and is also approved for treatment of restless leg syndrome

Option D - Metoclopramide is a 5HT4 agonist and D2 blocker and used as an antiemetic agent

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Insulin release due to the closure of K+ channels is seen with?
Repaglinide

Sitagliptin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 2:

Repaglinide acts by increasing insulin secretion by blockage of ATP-sensitive K+ channels of the beta cells of the pancreas.
When ATP-sensitive K+ channels are blocked, it will lead to depolarization of beta cells and the release of insulin.
Sulfonylureas also act by this similar mechanism.
Option B - Metformin is an insulin sensitizer and also inhibits gluconeogenesis and increases hepatic uptake of glucose.
Option C - Exenatide is a GLP-1 analog. Option D - Sitagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 4:

A 62-year-old woman presents with complaints of fatigue. She is a known case of type 2 diabetes mellitus on treatment. On examination, there is pallor and knuckle pigmentation. Which of the following drugs could have caused her condition?
Gliclazide

Acarbose
Metformin
Rosiglitazone



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 4:
Metformin can cause vitamin B12 deficiency which manifests as megaloblastic anemia (pallor,
fatigue) with knuckle pigmentation.
The most common side effect of metformin is GI intolerance as nausea, bloating, abdominal cramps and diarrhoea.
Note: The exact reason why metformin causes vitamin B12 deficiency is not known. The proposed mechanisms include:

Alterations in small bowel motility, which stimulates bacterial overgrowth and consequentia vitamin B12 deficiency
Competitive inhibition or inactivation of vitamin B12 absorption
Alterations in intrinsic factor (IF) levels and interaction with the cubilin endocytic receptor.
Inhibition of the calcium-dependent absorption of the vitamin B12-IF complex at the termina ileum.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 5:

Which of the following is incorrect regarding metformin?
Causes little or no hypoglycemia in non-diabetic patients
Acts by increased insulin secretion
Increases peripheral utilization of glucose and decreases absorption of glucose from the intestine
Increase intake of calcium may prevent metformin induced B12 malabsorption



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
Metformin does not act by increasing insulin secretion.
It decreases insulin resistance and increases the peripheral utilization of glucose.
Metformin is a biguanide that acts by activation of AMP-dependent protein kinase activation and thereby mediates a series of actions that helps in reducing hepatic glucose production.
Option A - Metformin has minimal to nil effect on insulin secretion and as a result, has minimal or no hypoglycemic effect in non-diabetic patients.
Option C - Metformin reduces hepatic gluconeogenesis, increases the insulin-mediated peripheral glucose uptake and also decreases the absorption of glucose from the gut.
Option D - Increase intake of calcium will decrease the B12 malabsorption because metformin interferes with Ca2+ dependent B12 absorption.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 6:

What is the central pharmacological action of metformin in type 2 diabetes?
Reduction in glucose absorption
Reduction in insulin resistance
Reduction in hepatic glucose production
Reduction in effects of glucagon



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
The central pharmacological action of metformin is to reduce hepatic glucose production by inhibiting gluconeogenesis. Metformin effect is mainly mediated through activation of AMPK and altering the energy dynamics at mitochondrial respiration.
Option A - The reduction in glucose absorption can also occur but the contribution to the antihyperglycemic action is not significant
Option B - Metformin increases peripheral glucose utilization by both insulin-dependent (reducing insulin resistance) and independent ways. But the current evidence does not support the reduction in insulin resistance as the primary mechanism of metformin's action.
Option D - Recent evidence shows blunting of glucagon effects as one of the mechanisms of metformin's action
Note: All are mechanisms of metformin, however, the key action is Option C and it is the most appropriate answer.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 7:

A 58-year-old woman with chronic kidney disease with recently diagnosed Type 2 DM was started on metformin therapy. Her repeat eGFR was 40/min/1.73 m2. Which of the following is not true regarding the further management of this lady?
Metformin dose has to be decreased.
Metformin should be discontinued and replaced with insulin.
eGFR should be measured at least annually in her.
eGFR is preferred over serum creatinine concentration to assess renal function for metformin therapy.



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:

According to current guidelines (KDIGO 2020), metformin should be discontinued only in patients with eGFR less than 30 ml/min/1.73 m2 or kidney failure. Metformin dose should be reduced when the eGFR is less than 45 ml/min/1.73 m2.
Metformin is excreted by the kidneys, and accumulation with reduced kidney function may increase the risk of lactic acidosis (due to inhibition of hepatic gluconeogenesis). It is contraindicated below eGFR<30.
eGFR is obtained at baseline and at least annually in all patients taking metformin. It is recommended that the eligibility of CKD patients for metformin administration be changed from one based on a single laboratory parameter (blood creatinine concentration) to one that provides a better estimate of kidney function in patients with kidney disease i.e., glomerular filtration rate estimating equation (eGFR).

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Selective agonist for the nuclear peroxisome proliferator activated receptor

[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 9:
Pioglitazone need not be avoided in all patients with cardiovascular disease.
Pioglitazone is known to cause fluid retention and edema and is therefore avoided in patients who have heart failure. It is not avoided in all cardiovascular diseases.
Option A - Pioglitazone is metabolized by CYP3A4 and CYP2C8.
Option B - Pioglitazone is a selective agonist of nuclear peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR). It modulates the expression of genes involved in lipid and glucose metabolism, insulin signal transduction and adipocyte differentiation. These effects increase the sensitivity of the tissues to insulin.
Option C - Pioglitazone does not increase insulin levels in the body. It sensitizes the tissues to the action of insulin. Hence, insulin is needed for the action of pioglitazone. However, it does not need insulin to modulate the expression of genes.

You have started an infusion of drug Y in a patient at a rate of 200 mg/hr. Žrug Y has Vd of 100 liters and clearance of 100 ml/min. What will be the drug concentration at a steady state?

Steady state concentration (Css) for this drug is 33.33mg/L. Steady state concentration (Css) = ™ate of infusion / clearance.
™ate of infusion = 200 mg/h Vd = 100 L
Clearance = 100 mL/min

explanation:

The clearance of a drug which follows first-order kinetics (in one compartment model) is 0.2 L/min and volume of distribution is 40 L. What is the t1/2 of that drug?

140 min
220 min
240 min
180 min



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
The t1/2 of the drug would be 140 minutes.

t1/2 is the time required for the plasma concentration or the amount of a drug in the body to be reduced by 50%. It depends on its clearance and volume of distribution.
t1/2 = 0.693 x Vd/Cl where,
Vd - volume of distribution
Cl - clearance.
We can take 0.693 approximately as 0.7 Substituting,
t1/2 = 0.7 x 40 /0.2
t1/2 = 0.7 x 200
t1/2 = 140 minutes
Clinical implications: Half-life determines the duration of the drug effect. It also indicates whether the accumulation of the drug will occur under multiple dosage regimens thereby making it is essential to decide on the appropriate dosing interval.

The amount of drug being administered = 1.6mg/min
Amount of drug being excreted = Clearance (CL) x Plasma concentration of the drug (C)
Clearance = 640ml/min Therefore,
1.6mg/min = 640ml /min ( clearance) x Plasma concentration of the drug Hence,
Plasma concentration of the drug = 1.6 mg/min / 640 ml/min = 0.002 mg/ml.

500mg of a drug was administered to a patient. 100mg was cleared in 1 hour. How much of the drug would be left in his body after 3 hours if the excretion of the drug follows zero-order kinetics?
300 mg
200 mg
400 mg
100 mg



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 3:
In zero-order kinetics, a constant amount of drug is eliminated in unit time. In this question, 100 mg of the drug is eliminated in 1 hour.
After 3 hours,
3 x 100 = 300 mg would be eliminated.
500-300 = 200 mg will be the remaining drug in the body.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 4:

200 mg of a drug is administered to a patient, of which 20 mg is excreted in 90 minutes. How much of the drug will remain after 3 hours if it follows first-order kinetics?
162 mg
145.8 mg
50 mg
40 mg



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 4:
After 3 hours, 162mg of the drug will remain.
In first-order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time. In the given question,
20mg out of 200mg is excreted in 90 minutes, 20/200 = 0.1 fraction is eliminated every 90 minutes. After 90 minutes, 200mg - 20 mg = 180 mg remains
The next 90 minutes (i.e. after 180 minutes) = 180 x 0.1 = 18 mg is eliminated.

Therefore, 180 - 18 = 162 mg remains. Simpler way:
1/10 fraction of the drug is excreted in 90 minutes  9/10 remains after 90 minutes. 3 hours (180 min) is 2 times 90 minutes.
So 200 x (9/10)(9/10) = 162 mg remains after 180 minutes

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 6:

Calculate hepatic clearance of a drug with hepatic blood flow of 2000 mL/min and hepatic extraction ratio of 0.5.
4000 mL/min
2000 mL/min
1500 mL/min
1000 mL/min



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
The hepatic clearance is 1000 mL/min.

Clearance of a drug by an organ is the difference between the rate of presentation of the drug to the organ and the rate of exit of the drug from the organ. It is calculated by the equation:
CLorgan = Q x E Where,
Q - Organ blood flow
E - Extraction ratio (organ-specific)
In the question, it is given that the hepatic blood flow (Q) is 2000 mL/min and the hepatic extraction ratio (E) is 0.5.
Substituting the values in the above equation, CLorgan = 2000 X 0.5 = 1000 mL/min
Note: The extraction ratio (E) is the fraction of the drug that is removed from the blood by the eliminating organ.
Extraction ratio (E) = CA-CV/CA Where,
CA is the concentration of drug presented to the organ
CA-CV is the drug removed by the organ

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

A diabetic patient is in the postoperative area following cardiac surgery. He is to be given intravenous insulin for optimal glycemic control and to avoid sternal wound infection. Which of the following should not be administered?

Options A, C, and D: Regular insulin and short-acting insulins (glulisine and aspart) can be given intravenously. While short-acting insulins are approved for intravenous administration under supervision, regular insulin is preferred in perioperative glycemic control due to the lesser risk of hypoglycemia.
Intravenous insulin is used in diabetic ketoacidosis and other conditions where insulin requirements change drastically like perioperative period, labor, and in intensive care situations.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 11:

Which of the following insulin precipitates into a cloudy white precipitate when mixed with short acting insulins?
Insulin detemir
Insulin degludec
Insulin glargine
Insulin glulisine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
Insulin glargine forms a cloudy white precipitate when mixed with short-acting insulins.
Due to the acidic pH (4.0) of insulin glargine, it cannot be mixed with short-acting insulin preparations that are formulated at a neutral pH as it aggregates at neutral pH into a cloudy white

precipitate. This reduces the effectiveness of the insulin dose.
Insulin degludec and detemir have a pH of 7.4 that is very near to neutral pH and they do not form such aggregates when mixed with short-acting insulins.
But the manufacturers do not advise manual mixing with short-acting insulin as it may alter the activity profile of the combination that can turn unpredictable. Degludec is available as an approved fixed-dose combination with aspart that can be used with predictable effects.

explanation:

Composition of Lente insulin is:

70% crystalline 30% amorphous
Only 70% amorphous
Other name of NPH insulin

Solution to Question 12:
Lente insulin is an intermediate-acting insulin and is a combination of Ultralente and Semilente in the ratio of 7:3
Two types of insulin zinc suspensions have been produced. The one with large particles is crystalline and practically insoluble in water (Ultralente). It is long-acting. The other has smaller particles and is amorphous (Semilente), is short-acting. Their 7:3 ratio mixture is called ‘Lente insulin’ and is intermediate-acting.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 13:

You are counseling a diabetic patient and teaching her the technique to self-administer insulin at home every day. Which of the following sites would you not suggest as the preferred site for insulin administration?
Anterior part of thigh
Lateral part of thigh
Buttocks
Medial part of thigh



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 13:
The medial part of the thigh is not a preferred site for insulin administration in patients. This is because of the relatively higher density of blood vessels and nerves in this area. Another consideration is that the inner thighs rub together while walking and may cause soreness at the injection sites.
The preferred sites for insulin administration are:
Upper arm
Anterior and lateral aspects of the thigh
Buttocks
Abdomen (with the exception of a circle with a 2-inch radius around the navel)
Rotation of the injection site is important to prevent lipodystrophy. However, rotating within one area is recommended (e.g., rotating injections systematically within the abdomen) rather than rotating to a different area with each injection. This helps decrease variability in absorption from day to day.

Exenatide is a GLP-1 analog that acts as an insulin secretagogue. As the beta cells are already destroyed and do not secrete insulin in type 1 diabetes, there is no role of drugs that enhance insulin secretion.

Pramlintide is administered as a subcutaneous injection.
Option A - It is a synthetic analogue of amylin and is approved for both type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus

Option B - It has weight reducing property by causing a central anorectic effect. It acts by reducing glucagon secretion, delaying gastric emptying and decreasing appetite.
Option C - It should not be administered with insulin in the same syringe because of a difference in pH

A 40-year-old diabetic woman comes for follow up. Her BMI is 32 kg/m2 despite several months of diet and exercise. Which of the following is the drug preferred for her condition?
Liraglutide
Linagliptin
Insulin lispro
Pioglitazone



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 17:
Liraglutide is approved for the management of obesity.
GLP-1 is a physiological regulator of appetite and calorie intake, and the GLP-1 receptor is present in several areas of the brain involved in appetite regulation. Liraglutide is a GLP-1 analog and lowers body weight by decreasing calorie intake.
Note: FDA has recently approved semaglutide subcutaneous injection once weekly for chronic weight management. This is for use in patients with obesity and overweight individuals with at least one weight-related condition such as type 2 diabetes, hypertension or dyslipidemia.

A 45-year-old man comes for a routine health check-up. He has a family history of medullary thyroid cancer. His thyroid examination is normal but his HbA1c is found to be 7.5%. In view

of his history, which of the following should not be prescribed for him?
SGLT 2 inhibitors
DPP4 inhibitors
GLP 1 agonists
Sulfonylureas



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 18:
GLP-1 analogues are contraindicated in patients with a personal or family history of medullary thyroid cancer and in patients with MEN 2 syndrome.
GLP-1 analogues cause thyroid C-cell tumours at clinically relevant exposures in rodents. However, studies have not yet shown if they cause thyroid C-cell tumours like medullary thyroid carcinoma in humans.

Teduglutide
Semaglutide



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 19:
Teduglutide is a GLP-2 analog and is approved for the treatment of short bowel syndrome.
GLP-2 binds to enteric neurons and endocrine cells, stimulating the release of a number of hormones such as insulin-like growth factor. This stimulates mucosal epithelial growth and enhances fluid absorption.
GLP-1 analogs:
Exenatide
Liraglutide
Albiglutide
Dulaglutide
Lixisenatide
Semaglutide
Note: GLP-1 analogs are used for the treatment of Type II diabetes mellitus.

Teduglutide can potentially cause bowel cancer, therefore it is not recommended for patients with active malignancies.
It is a GLP-2 analog that has been recently approved for the treatment of short bowel syndrome. It inhibits gastric acid secretion and gastric emptying, stimulates mucosal epithelial growth
and intestinal blood flow, and enhances nutrient and fluid absorption
The drug has a t1/2 of 1–2 hours and is administered subcutaneously once daily. Note: GLP-1 analogs are used for the treatment of Type II diabetes mellitus.

OCPs, Estrogens and Progestins

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 2:

A 28-year-old nurse was brought to the casualty with seizures and altered mental status. Her plasma glucose was 35 mg/dl. Which test would help to rule out the possibility of exogenous insulin administration?
Glucagon
C-peptide
Pancreatic polypeptide
Preproinsulin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 2:
C-peptide can be used to rule out the possibility of factitious hypoglycemia resulting from exogenously administered insulin.
Endogenous insulin is initially synthesized as preproinsulin that is processed to proinsulin inside beta cells. Proinsulin is released by secretory granules after processing it to form insulin and
C-peptide.
Synthetic insulin usually lacks C-peptide, so in factitious hypoglycemia secondary to exogenous insulin administration, plasma insulin will be elevated, but there will be suppression of C-peptide and proinsulin, and insulin to C-peptide ratio will be greater than one.
On the other hand, insulinomas and insulin secretagogues like sulfonylureas stimulate endogenous insulin production. As a result, plasma insulin, C-peptide, and proinsulin levels will be all elevated. The only way to differentiate between insulinoma and insulin
secretagogues-induced hypoglycemia is by detecting the drug, e.g., sulfonylurea, in the blood or urine.

C-peptide has no known physiological function or receptor. It has a half-life of about 30 min.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 7:

A 30-year-old patient with type 1 diabetes presented with complaints of vomiting and abdominal pain. On examination, she had fast, deep breathing with a fruity odor. Her capillary blood glucose was 450mg/dL. What is the clinical concern associated with administering insulin alone?
Hypokalemia
Hypernatremia
Hyperkalemia
Hyponatremia



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:

Deep breathing (Kussmaul respiration) and fruity breath (acetone odor) in a symptomatic patient with type 1 diabetes are suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis. Insulin therapy alone in a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) may result in hypokalemia.
DKA is usually associated with a major K+ deficit. Potassium loss is caused by an extracellular shift of potassium (in exchange with hydrogen ions) due to acidosis. Much of the shifted extracellular potassium is lost due to emesis and osmotic diuresis.
When insulin therapy is initiated for DKA, the serum K+ is shifted intracellularly. Dangerous hypokalemia might occur if K+ supplementation is not initiated subsequently. Insulin should be withheld if the serum level of potassium is below 3.3 mmol/L.

A migraine headache is a relative contraindication for the use of combined oral contraceptives. Migraine with focal neurological symptoms is an absolute contraindication to combined oral contraceptive use.
Absolute contraindications to combined oral contraceptive use:
Presence or history of thromboembolic disease, cerebrovascular disease, myocardial infarction, coronary artery disease
Congenital hyperlipidemia
Known or suspected carcinoma of the breast, female reproductive tract

Undiagnosed vaginal bleeding.

Relative contraindications to combined oral contraceptive use:

AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 11:

Progestin-only pills do not act by which of the following mechanisms?
Inhibition of ovulation
Decreasing sperm penetration
Impairing implantation
Eliciting an inflammatory action in the endometrium



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
Copper intrauterine devices elicit an inflammatory reaction within the endometrium. This impairs sperm viability, motility, and fertilization.
All the following actions contribute to the contraceptive action of progestin-only pills:
The effectiveness of this drug is largely due to the thickening of cervical mucus which in turn impair sperm penetration.
Inhibits ovulation via exerting negative feedback on the hypothalamus (GnRH). This leads to the absence of the FSH and LH surge, which is essential to mature the dominant follicle and trigger ovulation.
Interfere with the implantation of a zygote by altering the endometrial environment.
The major reason women discontinue the use of progestin-only contraceptives is breakthrough bleeding.

Tamoxifen acts as an estrogen receptor antagonist in breast tissues. The use of tamoxifen in carcinoma of breast patients decreases the incidence of carcinoma in opposite breasts.

You are an intern posted in the medicine ward and you notice the given dermatological finding in a patient with abdominal distension. Which of the following hormones is implicated in this finding?


Testosterone

[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 24:
The image shown is of spider nevus and the hormone implicated in its development is estrogen.
It is commonly seen in hyperestrogenic states such as pregnancy and in those taking
estrogen-containing contraceptives. It can also be seen in male patients with cirrhosis due to the decreased ability of the liver to metabolize circulating estrogens, specifically estrone, which derives from the androgen androstenedione. Estrogens cause blood vessels to enlarge and dilate.



This is a case of gynecomastia which can occur as an adverse effect of spironolactone or ketoconazole or chlorpromazine.
Spironolactone - decreases testosterone production, increases peripheral conversion of testosterone to estradiol, and displaces estradiol from their plasma-protein-binding sites
Ketoconazole - decreases testosterone production and displaces testosterone from their binding sites
Chlorpromazine (neuroleptics) - increase prolactin release by blocking the inhibitory action of dopamine on prolactin
Clomiphene and tamoxifen are used mainly in reducing male gynecomastia.

Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

subject: Pharmacology

A post-menopausal lady who is on estrogen therapy for hot flashes is concerned about its adverse effects. She is not at an increased risk of developing which of the following cancers?
Breast cancer
Endometrial cancer
Carcinoma of the gall bladder
Hepatocellular carcinoma



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 3:
Women receiving estrogen therapy do not have an increased risk of developing gall bladder carcinoma.
Long-term estrogen therapy can increase the risk of gall stones. Although gall stones can be associated with the development of gall bladder carcinoma, there is no direct correlation between long term estrogen therapy and gall bladder carcinoma.
Estrogen therapy has been associated with breast, endometrial and hepatocellular carcinoma.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 4:

In which of the following conditions is hormone replacement therapy not helpful?
Vaginal atrophy
Flushing

Coronary heart disease
Osteoporosis



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 4:
Hormone replacement therapy(HRT) is not helpful in coronary heart disease.
Progesterone used in the HRT is associated with an increased risk of coronary artery disease, thromboembolism, and related mortality. Estrogens promote coagulation and thromboembolic episodes.
Options A and B: Estrogen is helpful in flushing and local preparations are preferred for vaginal atrophy.
Option D: Estrogen is beneficial for osteoporosis if it is started before the onset of significant osteoporosis.
Note: The use of HRT for cardiovascular benefits is quite controversial. The current consensus is that the HRT should be started only after assessing the benefit/risk profile individually and is not indicated for the prevention of cardiovascular events in all menopausal women as it was previously advocated.

subject: Pharmacology

Progestin dose remains constant throughout the cycle in which of the following type of combined contraceptive pills?
Monophasic pills
Biphasic pills
Triphasic pills
Multiphasic pills



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
Monophasic pills contain constant amounts of progesterone and estrogen that is taken daily for 21 days, followed by a 7-day pill-free period.
Biphasic and triphasic pills have variable amounts of active ingredients (especially progesterone) that mimic the natural changes in the hormonal levels in the menstrual cycle. These pills reduce the total amount of steroids that needs to be administered.

A young lady who is on oral contraceptive pills refrains from taking any drug even for minor ailments due to the fear of contraceptive failure. Which of the following drugs can be taken safely?
Aspirin
Tetracycline
Phenytoin
Rifampicin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
Among the given drugs, aspirin use is least likely to cause contraceptive failure.
Option B: Broad-spectrum antibiotics like tetracycline suppress the intestinal flora and interfere with the enterohepatic circulation of estrogen. This leads to lowering of plasma estrogen levels and can result in contraceptive failure.
Options C and D: Enzyme inducers like phenytoin and rifampicin increase the metabolism of oral contraceptives and can cause contraceptive failure.

A 23-year-old lady has been on anti-epileptic therapy since childhood and now comes to the OPD seeking advice on a suitable method of contraception. Which contraceptive method should be avoided in her?
Oral contraceptives
Condoms
Intrauterine contraceptive devices
Post-coital pills



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:
Oral contraceptives must be avoided or used cautiously in epilepsy.
The most important aspect to consider is the drug interactions between anti-epileptic drugs and contraceptives. There is no conclusive evidence on whether estrogen is beneficial or harmful for

seizure control.
Note: Convulsive disorder is not an absolute contraindication; it is safe to avoid but can be used with caution.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 8:

Which of the following statements about oral contraceptive pills is true?
Progesterone is resposible for thromboembolism
It is protective against ovarian cancer
OCP are used in treatment mastalgia
Rifamipicin decreases the metabolism of OCP



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:
Oral contraceptive pills (OCP) protect against ovarian cancer.
This benefit is thought to be due to the prolonged suppression of gonadotropin stimulation of the ovary on long-term use of OCPs.
Other benefits of oral contraceptive pills:
Lesser incidence of endometrial carcinoma due to progestin component in OCP
Regularisation of menstrual cycles results in relief of dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia
Reduced incidence of fibrocystic breast disease and ovarian cysts
Endometriosis and pelvic inflammatory disease are improved
Option A: The estrogen component of combined oral contraceptive pills is mainly responsible for venous thromboembolism.
Option C: OCP is not used in the treatment of mastalgia. Mastalgia, chloasma, and breakthrough bleeding are known side effects of oral contraceptive pills.
Option D: OCPs are metabolized by CYP3A4 enzymes. Rifampicin is a strong inducer of CYP3A4. Hence, if administered together, rifampicin can cause enhanced metabolism of OCPs and may lead to contraceptive failure.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 9:

A 23-year-old lady on oral combined contraceptive pills misses a single dose and reports to you in the OPD the next morning. What will be the most appropriate advice to this patient?
Continue taking the next dose as scheduled
Double the next dose to make up for the missed dose
Interrupt the course and start taking the medications again on 5th day of bleeding
Start a fresh course of OCP again



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 9:
The most appropriate advice for this patient who has missed a single dose of the oral contraceptive pill (OCP) is to double the next dose to make up for the missed dose.
Missed dose considerations for oral combined contraceptive pills:
If a single dose is missed - a double dose can be taken on the next day to make up for the missed dose.
If two or more doses are missed on subsequent days - the last missed pill has to be taken along with the present pill and alternative methods of contraceptive must be used for the next 7 days.
If the pills were missed on the last week (days 15-21) - omit the hormone-free interval by finishing the hormonal pills in the current pack and starting the new pack from the next day.

subject: Pharmacology

AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 2:

Aromatase converts testosterone into
Dihydrotestosterone
Estradio
Epiandrosterone

[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 2:
Aromatase (CYP19) converts testosterone to estradiol. Certain effects of testosterone are mediated by estradiol.
In men with deficient CYP19 or ER receptors, the epiphyses do not fuse, the long bones grow indefinitely and such patients are osteoporotic. Administration of estradiol can correct the bone abnormalities in CYP19 deficiency. However, this cannot be used in those with ER receptor defects.
Testosterone is converted to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) by 5-alpha-reductase.
Androstanedione and epiandrosterone are metabolites of DHT due to the action of 17-beta-HSD.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 3:

A 59-year-old man with metastatic prostate cancer is started on flutamide therapy. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
5-alpha reductase inhibitor
Non-competitive androgen receptor inhibitor
Competitive androgen receptor inhibitor
Selective Androgen Receptor Modulator (SARM)



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 3:
Flutamide acts by competitive inhibition of androgen receptors and is used to treat prostate cancer.
Flutamide is a non-steroidal antiandrogen that competes with androgens such as testosterone and dihydrotestosterone for binding to the androgen receptors in the prostate gland. By doing so, it prevents them from stimulating the prostate cancer cells to grow.
In addition to its use in prostate cancer, flutamide has been used to treat hyperandrogenism
(excess androgen levels) in women, such as in those with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and

Hirsutism.
Other anti-androgens are:
Bicalutamide, apalutamide, and nilutamide
Spironolactone (aldosterone antagonist with antiandrogen activity)
Cyproterone acetate (progestin with antiandrogen activity)
Cimetidine (H2 blocker with anti-androgen activity)
Selective Androgen Receptor Modulators (SARMs) are a class of androgen receptor ligands that have similar anabolic properties to anabolic steroids, but with reduced androgenic side effects. There are no FDA-approved SARMs at present.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 4:

A 25-year-old medical student is worried about his receding hairline and is thinking about taking finasteride. The drug enhances hair growth by acting on which of the following?
Aromatase enzyme
5 alpha reductase enzyme

Androgen receptors
PDE-5 enzyme



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 4:
Finasteride is a competitive inhibitor of 5  -reductase enzyme and thereby inhibits the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone.
Finasteride selectively inhibits the Type 2 isoenzyme of 5 -reductase. It is indicated for use in:
Benign prostatic hyperplasia
Male pattern baldness
Hirsutism.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 5:

Which of the following inhibits spermatogenesis?
Gemfibrosi
Gemcadio
Gestodine
Gossypo



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
Gossypol is a non-steroidal agent that inhibits spermatogenesis.
Gossypol is obtained from cottonseed. It inhibits spermatogenesis by exerting toxic effects on seminiferous tubules but has low efficacy. Libido and potency are not significantly affected and fertility usually returns after a few months of discontinuation of the drug. But, around 10% of the patients may remain infertile. Hypokalemia is a major adverse effect and may even lead to transient paralysis.
Low efficacy and significant toxicity have caused gossypol to be abandoned as a candidate male contraceptive.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 6:

A 30-year-old male patient presented to the urology OPD with complaints of erectile dysfunction and was prescribed a PDE-5 inhibitor. Identify the drug.
Podofilox
Finasteride
Apalutamide
Tadalafi



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
Tadalafil is a PDE-5 inhibitor used in the treatment of patients with erectile dysfunction.
Penile erection is mediated by NO and cGMP. During arousal, the corpus cavernosum produces nitric oxide which in turn stimulates the formation of cGMP. This leads to relaxation of the smooth muscle of corpus cavernosum and penile arteries, causing engorgement of corpus cavernosum producing an erection. The biological actions of cGMP are terminated by

phosphodiesterase enzymes and PDE-5 is the major cGMP metabolizing enzyme in the penile tissue.
Phosphodiesterase-5-inhibitors include:
Sildenafi
Tadalafil - Longest acting (24-36 hrs), bioavailability is not affected by food
Vardenafi
Avanafil - Most Rapid-acting (within 15 -30 mins)
Option A: Podofilox topical cream is used in the treatment of genital warts and molluscum contagiosum lesions.
Option B: Finasteride is a 5  -reductase inhibitor.
Option C: Apalutamide is a androgen receptor antagonist.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 7:

A 40-year-old diabetic patient was prescribed sildenafil for his erectile dysfunction. Following this, he develops a blurring of vision and complains that things seem to appear with a
bluish-green hue. Inhibition of which of the following enzymes is likely to have caused his visual side effects?
Phosphodiesterase 3
Phosphodiesterase 5
Phosphodiesterase 6
Phosphodiesterase 2



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:
Visual disturbance seen with sildenafil is due to PDE-6 inhibition.
Sildenafil is used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction principally due to its inhibitory actions on PDE-5 (Phosphodiesterase 5) in the vascular tissues of the corpus cavernosa. However, it also exerts minor inhibitory action against PDE-6, which is present exclusively in rod and cone photoreceptors and results in blurring and blue-green tinting of vision.
Tadalafil and avanafil have better PDE-5/PDE-6 selectivity, compared to sildenafil and vardenafil and hence have lesser visual side effects.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 8:

Which of the following is a prostaglandin that can be administered as an intracavernosal injection for erectile dysfunction?
Dinoprost
Dinoprostone
Alprostadi
Misoprosto



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:
Alprostadil can be given as a direct intracavernosal injection for erectile dysfunction.
Alprostadil is a natural PGE1 preparation. It is usually used in patients who are not responding to PDE-5 inhibitors. It is also available as an intraurethral suppository.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 9:

A 35-year-old physician presented to the ED with a prolonged painful erection induced by intracorporeal injection of an alprostadil+phentolamine combination. Which of the following is the drug of choice to treat his condition?
Finasteride
Phenoxybenzamine
Phenylephrine
Prazosin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 9:
Phenylephrine is the drug of choice for the treatment of low flow priapism.
Characteristics of low-flow priapism include painful rigid erection and ischemic corpora, indicated by dark blood upon corporeal aspiration.
Prazosin, and, phenoxybenzamine are alpha-blockers that cause vasodilation and can worsen priapism.

All anabolic steroids have significant androgenic action and the use of anabolic steroids by athletes is not recommended.
Testosterone and its derivatives are used for their anabolic effects but they have significant androgenic action. Some of them (17 methyl derivatives) are also hepatotoxic. The current consensus is to advise against the use of such anabolic steroids.

Drugs Acting on Uterus

A patient is administered oxytocin as part of the active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL) protocol. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this drug?
It is responsible for galactokinesis

It is secreted by anterior pituitary
At higher doses, it exerts diuretic like action

Oxytocin is responsible for galactokinesis (milk ejection reflex). Option B: It is a peptide and inactive orally.
Option C: It is secreted by posterior pituitary along with vasopressin.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 2:

Which of the following is not an oxytocic?
Ethacridine
Ergometrine
Pitocin
Orciprenaline



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 2:
Orciprenaline is a beta 2 receptor agonist that has uterine relaxing property. Oxytocics are uterine stimulants that increase uterine motility, especially at term. Uterine stimulants are:
Posterior pituitary hormones - oxytocin/pitocin
Ergot derivatives - ergometrine, methylergometrine
Prostaglandins - PGE2, PGF2 alpha, and others
Others - quinine, ethacridine Ethacridine is used as an abortifacient.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 3:

A 32-year-old multipara at 40 weeks gestation developed water intoxication and hyponatremia following prolonged IV infusion with oxytocin by an inexperienced junior resident. This adverse effect is due to oxytocin's action on which of the following sites?
Vasopressin V2 receptors on serosal surface of renal tubular cells
Vasopressin V2 receptors on luminal surface of renal tubular cells
Vasopressin V1 receptors on serosal surface of renal tubular cells
Vasopressin V1 receptors on luminal surface of renal tubular cells



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 3:
Oxytocin can bind to V2 receptors on the serosal surface of renal tubular cells resulting in reduced free water clearance.
This is because oxytocin and vasopressin have structural similarities. Oxytocin can have vasopressin (ADH) like activity at V2 receptors. The increase in water permeability occurs through the insertion of aquaporins (water channels) in collecting tubules.
Prolonged i.v. administration at high doses in conjunction with large volumes of hypotonic fluid may cause water intoxication associated with hyponatremia.

To avoid this complication, whenever high doses of oxytocin are administered over a long time:
An electrolyte-containing diluent must be used (not dextrose)
The volume of infused fluid should be kept low (by infusing oxytocin at a higher concentration)
Fluid intake must be restricted, fluid balance chart should be kept and serum electrolytes shoul be monitore

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

In which of the following patients is oxytocin not indicated?
A primiparous woman with spontaneous premature labor

A multiparous woman with postpartum haemorrhage
A primiparous woman with uterine inertia
A patient with breast engorgement due to inefficient milk ejection reflex



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 4:
Spontaneous premature labor is not an indication for oxytocics. Infact, it is an indication for tocolytics.
Uses of oxytocin are:
Induction of labor
Postpartum hemorrhage
Uterine inertia
Breast engorgement due to insufficient milk ejection reflex

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

A 33-year old lady with an obstetric score of G4P3L3 delivered a baby by cesarean section. She is at risk of developing uterine atony and the resident asks you to bring a long-acting analog of oxytocin. Which drug will you get?
Desamino-oxytocin
Carbetocin
Solifenacin
Darifenacin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
Carbetocin is a long-acting analog of oxytocin.
It is indicated for the prevention of uterine atony following caesarian section and for prevention of PPH.
Option A: Desamino-oxytocin is a buccal formulation of oxytocin that is similar to oxytocin injection.
Options C and D: Solifenacin and darifenacin are synthetic tertiary amine antimuscarinic agents that are indicated in overactive bladder.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Which of the following is a synthetic PGF2 alpha derivative used as an abortifacient?
Dinoprost
Dinoprostone
Misoprostol
Carboprost



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
Carboprost is a 15-methyl synthetic derivative of PGF2 alpha. It is used as an abortifacient and in refractory PPH.
Options A: Dinoprost is a natural PGF2 alpha preparation. Option B: Dinoprostone is natural PGE2 preparation.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 7:

Which of the following is/are the primary indication(s) of ergot alkaloids in obstetrics?
2,3
1,2,3
Only 3
1,2,3,4,5



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:

Ergot derivatives are indicated for the prevention and/or treatment of postpartum hemorrhage.
Ergot alkaloids markedly increase the motor activity of the uterus. The capacity to induce sustained uterine tetany and fetal distress exclude their use in the initiation or facilitation of labor.
Due to the high incidence of postoperative vomiting and lack of evidence in reducing bleeding, routine or prophylactic use of uterotonic medications at the time of MTP is not recommended.
Ergot alkaloids used in PPH include ergometrine and methylergometrine.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 8:

You administer methyl ergometrine to a patient with postpartum hemorrhage in the labor ward. Which of the following adverse effects will you not expect to occur in this patient?

Nausea and vomiting
Hypotension
Decrease in pain threshol
Decrease milk secretion postpartum



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:
Administration of Ergot alkaloids (such as methyl ergotamine) result in hypertension. The use of ergot alkaloids is preferably avoided in hypertensive patients.
Adverse effects of ergometrine/methylergometrine are:
Nausea and vomiting
Hypertension
Decrease in pain threshold but analgesia might be require
Decrease in milk secretion postpartum (due to dopaminergic action especially at higher doses)

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 9:

A 23-year old woman, G2P1L1 at 33 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with spontaneous preterm labor. The senior resident instructed you to give the patient antenatal steroids and a tocolytic. Which of the following drugs will you not choose?
Atosiban
Dopamine
Nifedipine
Isoxsuprine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 9:
Dopamine does not have any significant activity on the tone of the uterus, since uterine relaxation is mediated by beta-2 receptors.
Specific tocolytic agents are:
Beta 2 agonists - ritodrine, isoxsuprine, terbutaline
Calcium channel blockers - nifedipine
Oxytocin receptor antagonist - atosiban
Magnesium sulfate
Indomethacin



Progesterone can be given prophylactically to reduce the risk of preterm labor.
It inhibits the secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines and delays cervical ripening. Therefore, progesterone and its derivatives have been advocated to diminish the onset of preterm labor in women at high risk due to previous preterm delivery.

Intramuscular hydroxyprogesterone administered weekly as well as vaginal administration has both been shown to reduce the incidence of preterm delivery.
Ritodrine, terbutaline, and nifedipine are tocolytics that are indicated for inhibition of uterine contractions of preterm labor and not for prophylaxis against preterm labor.

NSAIDs

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 1:

Which of the following statements is true?
NSAIDs act by inhibiting lipooxygenase.
NSAIDs act by inhibiting the phospholipases.
Cyclooxygenase-1 is a housekeeping enzyme.
Phospholipase-A2 is a housekeeping enzyme.



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 1:
Cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) is primarily a housekeeping enzyme. NSAIDs act by inhibiting both COX-1 and COX-2.
COX-1 is constitutively expressed in most cells. It performs housekeeping functions like gastrointestinal cytoprotection, fluid and electrolyte balance in the kidney.
COX-2 is normally present in insignificant amounts in most of the cells. It is induced by cytokines, growth factors and other stimuli during inflammation.
Phospholipase-A2 is the initial enzyme that acts on the membrane phospholipids to generate arachidonic acid. Arachidonic acid produces prostaglandins by the action of the cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX).

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 10:

Which of the following drugs has the least COX-2 selectivity?
Lumiracoxib
Etoricoxib
Valdecoxib
Celecoxib



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
Celecoxib has the least COX-2 selectivity among the following.
Some selective COX-2 inhibitors are withdrawn or have restricted use because of an increase in the risk of cardiovascular events like myocardial infarction, serious skin reactions (valdecoxib), fatal hepatic failure (lumiracoxib).
Nowadays, dual inhibitors inhibiting 5-LOX and COX like licofelone and tepoxalin are also used for their anti-inflammatory property.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 11:

Your senior asks you to administer a selective COX-2 inhibitor intravenously to a patient for post-op analgesia. Which of the following will you choose?
Celecoxib
Etoricoxib
Rofecoxib
Parecoxib


[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
Parecoxib is chosen as it is the only injectable COX-2 selective drug among the given options.
It is a water-soluble prodrug of valdecoxib. It is effective in the perioperative period when oral medications are not indicated.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 12:

Which of the following is a true statement about acetaminophen?
It has significant analgesic, antiinflammatory and antipyretic action.
Acetaminophen toxicity causes periportal necrosis.
It does not antagonize effects of uricosuric drugs.
It has significant anti-platelet effect.



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 12:
Acetaminophen does not antagonize effects of uricosuric agents. It may be used concomitantly with probenecid in the treatment of gout as it does not have any effect on uric acid levels.
Option A - Acetaminophen has analgesic and antipyretic action equivalent to aspirin but lacks a significant anti-inflammatory effect.
Option B - Acetaminophen toxicity causes centrilobular necrosis.
Option D - It is a weak inhibitor of both COX-1 and COX-2 and has minimal or no effect on platelet activity.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 13:

A 25-year-old patient of major depression presented to the ER after having consumed 20 tablets of acetaminophen (500 mg each) 1 hour ago in a self-harm attempt. She does not have any symptoms at the moment. Which of the following should you administer to her?
Flumazeni
N-acetylcysteine
Methylene blue
Nothing as she is asymptomatic



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 13:
The patient in the given clinical scenario has ingested a potentially toxic dose of acetaminophen. N-acetylcysteine is considered as a definitive antidote for acetaminophen poisoning to prevent hepatic injury.
N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI) is a toxic metabolite of acetaminophen which causes hepatotoxicity. In adults, hepatotoxicity may occur after ingestion of a single dose of 10–15 g (150–250 mg/kg) of acetaminophen; doses of 20–25 g or more are potentially fatal.

In acetaminophen poisoning, due to increased NAPQI, there is utilization of glutathione (GSH).
This in turn leads to depletion of GSH leading to oxidative cellular damage of the hepatocytes. N-acetylcysteine replenishes GSH stores and also conjugates with NAPQI and prevents oxidative damage to the cell. It also protects against extrahepatic injury due to its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.
Option A: Flumazenil is an antidote for benzodiazepine toxicity. Option C: Methylene blue is used in methemoglobinemia.
Option D: Symptoms may take upto 2 days to develop in a case of acetaminophen poisoning by which time the hepatic damage may become irreversible. Thus, early treatment is initiated in all suspected cases.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 14:

Which of the following drugs is not considered a hit and run drug?
Phenelzine
Omeprazole
Piroxicam
Aspirin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 14:
Piroxicam is a reversible inhibitor of cyclooxygenase enzyme and cannot be considered as a hit and run drug.
Hit and run drugs are a group of drugs whose half-life is short, but cause irreversible inhibition of a particular enzyme. So, the effect of the drug is present even after the drug is cleared from the system. Examples include:
MAO inhibitors ( e.g.: Phenelzine)
PPI (e.g.: omeprazole)
Guanethidine
Reserpine
Aspirin

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Which of the following patients should be prescribed NSAIDs for pain relief?
A hypertensive patient on chlorthalidone having osteoarthritis
Patient suffering from primary dysmenorrhea
Patient complaining of low back pain who is a known case of CKD

Patient having painful diabetic neuropathy



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 15:
NSAIDs can be used in the treatment of primary dysmenorrhea. Prostaglandin release from endometrium causes cramps and other symptoms. NSAIDs inhibit the synthesis of prostaglandin and cause symptomatic relief.
Option A: NSAIDs interfere with the antihypertensive effect of diuretics. The exact mechanism is not yet known. So it should be avoided in such cases.
Option C: NSAIDs are generally avoided in renal diseases as inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis worsens renal function.
Option D: NSAIDs generally lack efficacy in cases of neuropathic pain like diabetic neuropathy.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 16:

A patient of chronic low back pain has presented to your OPD with deranged LFT reports. He tells you he has been on long term treatment with a painkiller for his condition. Which NSAID has he most likely been taking?
Acetaminophen
Diclofenac

[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 16:
Diclofenac is the NSAID that has the highest risk of hepatotoxicity within the therapeutic dose.

Liver injury occurs in acetaminophen overdose but it is extremely rare in therapeutic dose. NSAIDs are not recommended in advanced hepatic and renal failure.



This is a case of fixed drug eruption and the most likely cause is ibuprofen.
Fixed drug eruptions are characterized by sharply demarcated dull red to brown lesions. They occur in lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and cause a burning sensation. The lesion recurs in the same locations upon re-exposure to the offending drug.
Some of the drugs commonly known to cause fixed drug eruptions are Sulphonamides, NSAIDs, Analgesics, and Hypnotics.
Diagnosis is based on history and lesion morphology. Discontinuation of the offending drug is the first step in management.
Phenytoin and carbamazepine can lead to Stevens-›ohnson syndrome (S›S)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) and drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome).

Antimigraine and Antigout drugs

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 2:

A patient with a history of myocardial infarction asks you why he is being prescribed aspirin. You tell him it prevents the formation of clots which reduces the risk of MI. Formation of which of the following eicosanoids is blocked by aspirin for this purpose?
PGI2
PGD2
Thromboxane A2
All of the above



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 2:

Thromboxane A2 is a pro-aggregatory eicosanoid whose formation requires the activity of COX enzyme. Aspirin blocks this step, thus reducing the chances of clot formation.
Thromboxane A2 is an inducer of platelet aggregation and amplifies the signal of more potent platelet agonists, such as thrombin and ADP.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 3:

Which of the following helps in maintaining the patency of ductus arteriosus?
PGF2
PGE1
PGH2
PGI2



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 3:
Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) maintains the patency of ductus arteriosus (PDA). This is used in term neonates with underlying cyanotic congenital heart disease awaiting surgical intervention as they have duct-dependant circulation.
Indomethacin and Ibuprofen are the NSAID indicated for closing the ductus arteriosus in premature infants and neonates.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 4:

A patient of CREST syndrome has developed pulmonary hypertension. Which of the following drugs will you not prescribe to treat this?
Epoprosteno

Iloprost
Treprostini
Rioprosti



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 4:
Rioprostil is a PGE1 analog and is not indicated in the treatment of pulmonary hypertension.
Long term therapy with PGI2 analogs can delay or preclude the need for lung or heart-lung transplantation. PGI2 analogs used for the treatment of pulmonary hypertension are:
Epoprostenol (IV)
Iloprost (IV)
Treprostinil (IV or SC)
PGI2 (Epoprostenol) can also be used to prevent platelet aggregation and damage during haemodialysis or cardiopulmonary bypass. It also improves the harvest of platelets for transfusion.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 5:

A ‹5-year-old man has presented to the OPD with a complaint of erectile dysfunction not responding to oral medication. The issue is determined to be of vascular origin. Which prostaglandin preparation can be given as a local injection to treat this?
Dinoprost
Epoprosteno
Enprosni
Alprostadi



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
Alprostadil (PGE1) is given as an intracavernosal injection or urethral suppository for erectile dysfunction.
It is considered as a second-line therapy. Its use has been largely replaced by phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors like sildenafil and tadalafil which are the drugs of choice.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 6:

Which of the following statements is false about aspirin?
It is an irreversible inhibitor of the cyclooxygenase enzyme.
Its clearance is independent of plasma concentration at low dose.
Alkalinization of urine increases its rate of excretion.
Its antiplatelet effect at low dose is related to presystemic COX inhibition.



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
Aspirin clearance is dependent on plasma concentration at a lower dose.
Aspirin shows saturation kinetics. This means that at lower plasma concentrations it has first-order kinetics where the rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma

concentration but at higher plasma concentrations it has zero-order kinetics where the rate of elimination is independent of its plasma concentration.
Around 80-90% of aspirin (salicylates) are bound to plasma proteins, especially albumin.
Low dose aspirin acetylates the COX enzyme of platelets in the portal circulation (pre-systemic)
and deactivates it which is responsible for antiplatelet action.
Aspirin and salicylates are acidic in nature. Alkalinization of the urine increases the rate of excretion of aspirin, as ionised form of aspirin increases which is not reabsorbed from the tubular fluid in kidney.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 7:

A 12-year-old child developed fever during an epidemic of influenza. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in this child?
Acetaminophen
Aspirin
Oseltamivir
Baloxavir



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:
Aspirin is contraindicated in this child due to the risk of development of Reye syndrome.
Children and young adults less than 20 years of age with viral fever have a risk of developing Reye's syndrome on administration of aspirin or other salicylates.
Features of Reye syndrome include:
Acute onset of encephalopathy
Liver dysfunction
Fatty infiltration of the liver
Option A - Acetaminophen is considered the antipyretic of choice in children with viral infections. Options C and D - Oseltamivir and baloxavir are antiviral drugs used in influenza.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 8:

A 30-year-old pilot with low back pain requires a painkiller that is effective at once-daily dosing. You decide to prescribe the NSAID with the longest plasma half-life. Which drug will you choose?
Aspirin
Phenylbutazone
Piroxicam
Ibuprofen



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:
Piroxicam is chosen as it has the longest plasma half-life among NSAIDs.
Piroxicam is absorbed completely and undergoes enterohepatic circulation. Due to the long half-life, once-daily administration of the drug is sufficient for the therapeutic response.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 9:

A patient with a history of gastritis complains of joint pain. You diagnose it to be a case of osteoarthritis and prescribe celecoxib. Which of the following statements is true regarding this drug?
It causes renal toxicity
It is more likely to cause gastric ulcers compared to ibuprofen
It is not associated with cardiotoxicity
It has antiplatelet action



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 9:
Celecoxib is a selective COX-2 inhibitor. As COX-2 enzyme is constitutively active within the kidney, recommended doses of selective COX-2 inhibitors cause renal toxicities similar to those associated with traditional NSAIDs.
Option B - It is less likely to cause gastric ulcers. Celecoxib has analgesic, antipyretic, and
anti-inflammatory effects similar to those of non-selective NSAIDs but with better gastrointestinal tolerability.
Option C - It inhibits COX-2-mediated prostacyclin synthesis in the vascular endothelium. As a result, use of celecoxib is associated with increased cardiovascular risk.

Option D - Celecoxib at usual doses does not inhibit platelet aggregation. This is because platelet aggregation is mediated by thromboxane produced by the COX-1.
These points are also true for other selective COX-2 inhibitors.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 1:

Which of the following receptors is a ligand-gated ion channel?
5-HT 1 receptor
5-HT 2 receptor
5-HT 3 receptor
5-HT 4-7 receptors



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 1:

The 5-HT3 receptor is a ligand-gated ion channel receptor. It rapidly depolarizes nerve endings by opening the cation channels located within the receptor.
The 5-HT3 receptors are located in the GI tract (vagal & splanchnic afferents) and the brain
(nucleus tractus solitarius & area postrema) and are involved in the emetic response. Hence 5-HT3 receptor antagonists like ondansetron, dolasetron etc are used as antiemetics.
All other 5-HT receptors are G-protein-coupled receptors.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

A middle-aged obese man has presented to the OPD with acute pain around his left first metatarsophalangeal joint. He has a history of similar episodes in the past. X-ray is given below. Which drug is commonly used as initial treatment for this condition?


Aspirin
Indomethacin

Allopurino
Colchicine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
The given scenario and the X-ray showing Martel's sign point towards a diagnosis of acute on chronic presentation of gout. Indomethacin is commonly used in the initial treatment of gout.
In addition to inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis, indomethacin and other NSAIDs also inhibit urate crystal phagocytosis.
Option A - Aspirin is not used because it causes renal retention of uric acid at low doses. It is uricosuric only at higher doses that are poorly tolerated.
Option C - Allopurinol is used for prophylaxis of gout.
Option D - NSAIDs are selected over colchicine because of troublesome diarrhea associated with colchicine.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

A patient undergoing chemotherapy was diagnosed with tumour lysis syndrome. She was administered rasburicase. Which group does this drug belong to?
Recombinant xanthine oxidase
Recombinant urate oxidase
Inhibitor of xanthine oxidase
Inhibitor of uric acid oxidase



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
Rasburicase is a recombinant urate oxidase which converts uric acid into soluble and inactive allantoin. It is more effective in reducing the urate level than allopurinol.
Recombinant uric acid oxidase is available as rasburicase and pegloticase. It is produced by genetically modified Saccharomyces cerevisiae strain. They are indicated in gout only for chronic refractory gout. It is primarily indicated for hyperuricemia associated with tumor lysis syndrome.

Pegloticase is a recombinant pegylated uric acid oxidase that is indicated for treatment of severe, treatment-refractory, chronic gout and also prophylaxis of gout.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 12:

†ou have prescribed the first-line urate-lowering drug to a patient with chronic gout. Which of the following is true about this drug?
Pyrimidine antimetabolite
Inhibitor of neutrophil recruitment
Uricosuric drug
Xanthine oxidase inhibitor



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 12:
Allopurinol is recommended as the first-line urate-lowering agent in all patients with gout. It is a purine antimetabolite and an inhibitor of xanthine oxidase enzyme.
It prevents the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid reducing plasma uric acid levels. Allopurinol is also a substrate for xanthine oxidase. The metabolite of allopurinol called oxypurinol is a non-competitive inhibitor of xanthine oxidase.

Febuxostat
Either a or b
Sulfinpyrazone

Febuxostat is a non-purine xanthine oxidase inhibitor that is indicated for reducing hyperuricemia in chronic gout. Both allopurinol and febuxostat can be used as first line agents but since the question mentions a non-purine inhibitor is chosen, febuxostat is the answer.
Option A - Allopurinol is a purine xanthine oxidase inhibitor. Option D - Sulfinpyrazone is a uricosuric agent.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

A patient, who is a known case of gout on treatment with allopurinol, comes to the OPD for follow up. His serum uric acid level is 11 mg/dl. †ou add lesinurad to his treatment regime for

adequate disease control. Which group does this drug belong to?
Uric acid synthesis inhibitor
Uricosuric agent
Xanthine oxidase inhibitor
Recombinant xanthine oxidase



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 14:
Lesinurad is a uricosuric agent.
It is a URAT1 inhibitor indicated in combination with a xanthine oxidase inhibitor for the treatment of hyperuricemia associated with gout. By inhibiting URAT1, it increases the urinary excretion of uric acid.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

What is pegloticase used for?
Chronic gout
Rheumatoid arthritis
Psoriatric arthritis
Paralytic ileus



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 15:
Pegloticase is used in the treatment of chronic gout.
Pegloticase is a pegylated uricase (urate oxidase). It catalyzes the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin, which is a more soluble and inactive metabolite.
It is used in the treatment of severe, refractory chronic gout or in cases where other urate-lowering therapies are contraindicated.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

An elderly woman on treatment for migraine presents with chest pain. She has a previous history of angina/MI. Which of the following mechanism of the prescribed drug for migraine might have caused this presentation?
5-HT antagonist
5-HT agonist
Calcium Channel Blocker action
Nitric oxide mediated vasodilation



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 16:

The patient may have been given sumatriptan, a 5-HT1b/1d receptor agonist which causes vasoconstriction and used in migraine. Thus, sumatriptan will worsen angina by causing coronary vasoconstriction.
Angina will be worsened if the O2 demand of the heart is increased or there is reduced blood flow to the already ischemic areas.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 17:

Which of the following is correct about the drugs used in gout?
1, 2 & 3
2, 3 & 4
1, 2 & 5
3 & 4



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 17:
Gout is a metabolic disease associated with hyperuricemia.
The drug of choice in an acute attack of gout is NSAIDs (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) like indomethacin or the drug colchicine. Colchicine is poorly tolerated and should not be used in elderly patients with chronic kidney disease.
Indomethacin is commonly used in the initial treatment of gout. In addition to inhibiting prostaglandin synthase, indomethacin and other NSAIDs also inhibit urate crystal phagocytosis
Intraarticular steroids like triamcinolone or methylprednisolone can also be given.
Aspirin is not used because it causes renal retention of uric acid at low doses. It is uricosuric only at higher doses that are poorly tolerated.



Erenumab-aooe is a calcitonin gene related protein (CGRP) receptor antagonist approved for the prophylaxis of migraine.
The pathology of migraine is not completely understood but it includes activation of trigeminal ganglion nociceptive neurons and the subsequent release of CGRP from fibers associated with meningeal vessels. This is believed to mediate vasodilation and mast cell degranulation. Thus, CGRP is involved in the development and maintenance of persistent pain, central sensitization and allodynia, which are events characteristic of migraine pathology.
Blockage of CGRP receptors by CGRP receptor antagonists, causes inhibition of the inflammatory and nociceptive effects of CGRP at multiple sites within the peripheral and central nervous systems that are implicated in the underlying pathology of migraine.
Monoclonal antibodies that directly inhibit CGRP have also been developed. These include:
Fremanezumab
Galcanezumab Note:
The FDA has recently approved Atogepant, a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonist for the preventive treatment of episodic migraine in adults. The recommended dosage is 10 mg, 30 mg, or 60 mg orally once daily. In severe renal impairment or end-stage renal disease it is 10 mg once daily.

Anti-rheumatoid drugs

After the administration of a drug for an acute attack of migraine, a patient developed nausea and vomiting. She also developed tingling and numbness at the tips of her fingers that eventually turned blue. Which of the following is the most likely drug implicated?
Dihydroergotamine
Sumatriptan
Butorphano
Aspirin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
Nausea and vomiting, as well as tingling and numbness (paresthesia), are common adverse effects of dihydroergotamine.
The numbness progressing to bluish discolouration of the fingers are the initial signs of occlusion. It can eventually lead to gangrene if left untreated. This is a rare adverse effect of

dihydroergotamine. Contraindications for ergotamine:
Peripheral vascular disease
Coronary artery disease
Uncontrolled hypertension
Fever and/or sepsis
Pregnancy
Within 24 hours of using triptans

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 6:

A patient has just been diagnosed with migraine. Which of the following drugs can you prescribe for prophylaxis?
Sumatriptan
Ergotamine
Domperidone
Topiramate



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
Topiramate is used in the prophylaxis of migraine. Long-term use of topiramate can cause weight loss.
The drugs that have been approved by the FDA for the preventive treatment of migraine include:
Propranolo
Timolo
Sodium valproate
Topiramate
Options A and B - Sumatriptan, a 5HT1B/1D agonist is a first-line agent for the termination of acute attacks. Ergotamines are also used in the termination of acute attacks.
Option C - Domperidone is indicated as an adjuvant in acute attacks. Acute attacks are associated with gastric stasis and an increased incidence of nausea and vomiting. It is helpful in reducing gastrointestinal effects. It can also increase gastrointestinal absorption of other antimigraine agents that are not absorbed due to gastric stasis.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 7:

What is the mechanism of action of colchicine?
Inhibits synthesis of uric acid
Promotes excretion of uric acid
Inhibits xanthine oxidase enzyme
Binds to tubulin and inhibits granulocyte migration



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:
Colchicine acts by binding to tubulin and inhibits granulocyte migration.
Colchicine produces its anti-inflammatory effects by binding to the intracellular protein tubulin. This prevents the polymerization of tubulin into microtubules which is necessary for leukocyte migration and phagocytosis. Inhibition of microtubule formation prevents granulocyte migration and also arrests cell division at G1 phase.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 8:

Which one of the following drugs inhibits neutrophil recruitment?
Montelukast
Sodium cromolyn
Colchicine
Febuxostat



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:
Colchicine inhibits neutrophil (granulocyte) recruitment.

Colchicine acts by preventing the polymerisation of microtubules by binding to tubulin. This reduces neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue and also decreases the secretion of chemotactic factors by activated neutrophils, thus reducing the inflammatory response overall.
Colchicine is used in gout and Mediterranean fever.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 9:

A patient with chronic tophaceous gout was prescribed sulfinpyrazone. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
Inhibits formation of uric acid
Promotes excretion of uric acid
Inhibits xanthine oxidase enzyme
Inhibits cyclooxygenase enzyme



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 9:
Sulfinpyrazone is a uricosuric agent that promotes excretion of uric acid. It is used to decrease the body pool of urate in patients with gout. They act by inhibiting the organic anion transporter that is involved in uric acid reabsorption in renal tubules.
Uricosuric agents used in gout are:
Probenecid
Sulfinpyrazone
Benzbromarone
Lesinurad
Uricosuric therapy should be initiated in gouty patients with underexcretion of uric acid and when allopurinol or febuxostat is contraindicated or when tophi are present. Therapy should not be started until 2–3 weeks after an acute attack.

subject: Pharmacology
