Febuxostat is a uric acid synthesis inhibitor that acts by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase and it is indicated in gout management.
Examples of histone deacetylase inhibitors are:
Vorinostat - cutaneous T cell lymphoma
Belinostat - peripheral T cell lymphoma
Romidepsin - cutaneous/peripheral T cell lymphoma

Panobinostat - multiple myeloma

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 23:

A 60-year-old woman was diagnosed with melanoma. Sentinel lymph node biopsy showed malignant cells. Which of the following drugs used in this condition is a MEK inhibitor?
Dabrafenib
Vemurafenib
Trametinib
Ipilimumab


[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 23:
The scenario is suggestive of metastatic melanoma and trametinib is used in this condition. It is a reversible inhibitor of the mitogen-activated extracellular signal-regulated kinase (MEK). It inhibits the serine-threonine kinase domain of BRAF V600E mutant of MEK.
It can be used as a single agent but it is more effective when used with BRAF inhibitors like dabrafenib.
Adverse effects of this drug include:
Cutaneous rash
Acneiform dermatitis
Diarrhea
Fatigue
Nausea
Lymphedema.
Cardiomyopathy
Hypertension
Hemorrhage
Interstitial lung disease
Ocular toxic effects.
Options A and B: Dabrafenib and vemurafenib are BRAF inhibitors used in metastatic melanoma.
Option D: Ipilimumab is a human cytotoxic T-lymphocyte antigen 4 (CTLA-4) blocking antibody used in metastatic or unresectable melanoma.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 24:

A 4-year-old child who was being evaluated for pancytopenia is diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Which of the following is the first gene therapy-based treatment approved for use in this condition?
Trastuzumab
Tisagenlecleucel
Riociguat
Dinutuximab



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 24:
Tisagenlecleucel is the first gene therapy-based treatment that is approved for use in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
The therapy involves reprogramming a patient’s own T-cells with a transgene encoding a chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) to identify and eliminate CD19-expressing malignant and normal cells.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 25:

A 67-year-old man presented with fatigue and weight loss. On examination, pallor and splenomegaly were noted. Peripheral blood smear examination findings are shown in the image. Which of the following BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitors is not a first-line agent for this condition?


Imatinib
Dasatinib
Nilotinib
Bosutinib



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 25:
The given scenario and the peripheral smear findings (increased WBCs with myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band forms), is suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia

(CML). Bosutinib is approved for use in this condition only for resistant and/or intolerant cases and not in newly diagnosed cases.
Agents that can be used as first-line for CML are:
Imatinib
Dasatinib
Nilotinib
Dasatinib and nilotinib can be used in newly diagnosed cases of CML, that are found to be imatinib-resistant.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 26:

A 63-year-old postmenopausal woman came to the OPD with a 12 cm adnexal mass. Her CA-125 levels were raised and her risk of malignancy index was calculated to be 250. PET scan revealed hepatic metastases. Which PARP inhibitor can you use in her treatment?
Palbociclib
Rucaparib
Vorinostat
Romidepsin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 26:
The clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of metastatic ovarian cancer. Rucaparib is a poly ADP-ribose polymerase/ PARP inhibitor approved for the treatment of advanced ovarian cancer.
PARP is a nuclear protein that transfers ADP-ribose from NAD+ to target proteins and this plays an important role in the DNA damage response. Rucaparib and olaparib are PARP inhibitors.
Option A: Palbociclib is a selective inhibitor of the cyclin-dependent kinases CDK4 and CDK6. It is used in the treatment of metastatic breast cancer.
Options C & D: Vorinostat and romidepsin are histone deacetylase inhibitors.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 27:

Which of the following conditions has hydrogen peroxide been recently approved for?
Psoriasis
Rosacea
Atopic eczema
Seborrheic keratoses



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 27:
A topical solution of hydrogen peroxide has been approved for the treatment of raised seborrheic keratoses.
Hydrogen peroxide is a keratolytic agent. Its exact mechanism of action in the treatment of seborrheic keratoses is not fully understood. Supraphysiologic concentrations may cause oxidative damage and death to seborrheic keratosis cells.
Hydrogen peroxide is commonly used as a disinfectant to clean wounds. It can also be used as a mouthwash.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Breast cancer

[EXPLANATION START]

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

A 60-year-old woman was diagnosed with melanoma. Sentinel lymph node biopsy showed malignant cells. Which among the following is a recombinant interleukin-2 preparation approved for use in this condition?

Aldesleukin
Imatinib
Nilotinib


[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 29:

The clinical scenario is suggestive of metastatic melanoma. The recombinant interleukin-2 (IL-2) preparation that is approved for use in metastatic melanoma is aldesleukin. It acts as an IL-2 agonist and is also approved for use in metastatic renal cell cancer.
Denileukin diftitox is an immunotoxin made from the recombinant combination of IL-2 and the catalytically active fragment of diphtheria toxin. It is approved for use in cutaneous T cell lymphoma.
Imatinib and nilotinib are a BCR/ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitor.



Denileukin diftitox is an immunotoxin made from the genetic recombination of IL-2 and the catalytically active fragment of diphtheria toxin.
It is indicated for advanced cutaneous T-cell lymphoma in patients with >20% of T cells expressing the surface marker CD25. After binding to the IL-2 receptors, it is internalized by endocytosis. The active fragment of diphtheria toxin then is released into the cytosol, where it inhibits protein synthesis through ADP ribosylation, leading to cell death.
Immunotoxins are proteins that contain a toxin along with an antibody that binds specifically to target cells.
Antibody-drug conjugates are complex molecules composed of an antibody linked to a biologically active cytotoxic (anticancer) drug. These antibody-targeted drug therapies are cell-specific to kill efficiently the target cells that bind and internalize the drug conjugate. Examples are:
Gemtuzumab ozogamicin - Monoclonal antibody against CD33 linked to a semisyntheti derivative of calicheamicin, a potent antitumor antibiotic. It was approved for the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia.
Brentuximab vedotin - Anti-CD30 IgG1 monoclonal antibody linked with the
microtubule-disrupting agent MMAE. It is used for the treatment of Hodgkin and anaplasti lymphoma.
Ado-trastuzumab emtansine - It combines the HER2-targeted properties of trastuzumab with the antimicrotubule agent DM1 (derived from maytansine), allowing preferential intracellular drug delivery to HER2+ cells. It is used in the treatment of HER+ breast cancer.

The drug of choice for the management of a patient with a metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumor is imatinib.
It is an oral anticancer drug that acts by inhibiting tyrosine kinase activated due to BCR-ABL fusion. It also inhibits other related tyrosine kinases and hence is used in the treatment of conditions like gastrointestinal stromal tumor (driven by a c-KIT mutation).
Imatinib is the agent of choice for GIST patients with metastatic disease and as adjuvant therapy for c-kit positive GIST.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 4:

A patient with chronic myeloid leukemia was switched to nilotinib as he showed only partial response to imatinib therapy. What is the mechanism resulting in the loss of response?

Amplification of wild-type kinase gene
Increased efflux
Point mutations in kinase domain
Overexpression of MDR gene



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 4:
The given scenario is suggestive of the development of resistance to imatinib, which is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor. This condition arises due to point mutations in three separate regions of the kinase domain.
The contact points between imatinib and the enzyme become sites of mutations in drug-resistant leukemic cells and hence these mutations prevent tight binding of the drug and lock the enzyme in its open configuration (the configuration in which it has access to the substrate and is enzymatically active).
Mechanisms other than BCR-ABL kinase mutations play a minor role in resistance to imatinib. They include:
Amplification of the wild-type kinase gene has been identified in some cases.
Overexpression of MDR-gene leading to increased drug efflux transporter has been shown experimentally but not implicated in clinical resistance.
Nilotinib retains inhibitory activity in the presence of most point mutations that confer resistance to imatinib.

Imatinib is an oral anticancer drug that acts by inhibiting tyrosine kinase activated due to

Which of the following inhibits the rate-limiting enzyme in catecholamine synthesis?
Tyrosine
Metyrosine
Propranolo
Valbenazine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 1:
The rate-limiting enzyme in catecholamine synthesis is tyrosine hydroxylase and is inhibited by metyrosine (alpha-methyl-p-tyrosine).
Tyrosine hydroxylase converts tyrosine to dopa (rate-limiting step). Dopa is then converted to dopamine by dopa decarboxylase.
Metyrosine is indicated preoperatively in pheochromocytoma and in inoperable cases.

Following spinal anesthesia, the blood pressure of a patient started dropping. Your senior asks you to administer a mixed-acting sympathomimetic. Which of the following loaded syringes will you pick?
Dobutamine
Isoprotereno
Ephedrine
Epinephrine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 12:
Ephedrine is a mixed-acting sympathomimetic agent which can be used to manage hypotension following spinal anesthesia.
Drugs that release norepinephrine and also directly activate receptors are called mixed-acting sympathomimetics.
Ephedrine has a dual action:
Releasing agent: releases neurotransmitters from nerve endings.
Direct action on  1,  2, 1, and 2 receptors.
The adrenergic agents are classified into three sub-groups:
Directly acting agents:
Selective agents - phenylephrine ( 1), clonidine ( 2), dobutamine (1), terbutaline (2).
Non-selective agents - oxymetazoline ( 1 +  2), isoproterenol (1 + 2), epinephrine
( 1 + 2 +1 + 2) norepinephrine ( 1 + 2 + 1)
Mixed acting agents - ephedrine ( 1 + 2 +1 + 2 + catecholamine releasing agent)
Indirectly acting agents:
Catecholamine releasing agents - amphetamine and tyramine
Uptake inhibitor - cocaine
MAO inhibitor - selegeline
COMT inhibitor - entacapone

Which of the following statements is not true about clonidine?
It acts on alpha 2 adrenergic receptors
Can result in rebound hypertension on abrupt withdrawa
Can produce CNS stimulation
Inhibits salivation



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 13:
Clonidine is a centrally acting antihypertensive agent. It is not associated with CNS stimulation.
It treats high blood pressure by stimulating presynaptic  2 receptors in the vasomotor center in the brainstem. This binding has a sympatholytic effect, by suppressing the release of norepinephrine and other sympathomimetics.
Option A - Clonidine is an alpha 2 receptor agonist that reduces central sympathetic outflow. Option B - Abrupt withdrawal after long-term therapy can result in rebound hypertension.
Option D - Dry mouth and sedation are the major side effects of clonidine. It can also cause impotency and constipation.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 14:

You are administering clonidine intravenously to a patient. Which of the following effects would you observe?
Prolonged rapid fall in blood pressure
Transient rise in blood pressure followed by a prolonged fa
Transient fall in blood pressure followed by a prolonged rise
Prolonged rapid rise in blood pressure



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 14:
Intravenous administration of clonidine results in a transient rise in blood pressure followed by a prolonged fall.
2 receptors are present on the presynaptic as well as the postsynaptic ganglia. They are the autoreceptors of the sympathetic system.
Clonidine is a directly acting  2 agonist. When it activates the postsynaptic  2 receptors in vascular smooth muscle, there is a transient rise in the blood pressure. This is followed by activation of central  2 receptors, which results in decreases the central sympathetic tone and causes a prolonged fall in blood pressure.
2 receptors are present postsynaptically in vascular walls and activation results in the same action as  1 stimulation i.e., vasoconstriction. But the major receptor that is responsible for vasoconstriction in vascular walls is the postsynaptic  1 receptor.

40-year-old woman with blood pressure 160/100 mmHg

[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 15:
Adrenergic agonists are not useful in the treatment of erectile dysfunction. Adrenergic antagonists (phentolamine) are used locally for vasodilation in erectile dysfunction as PIPE therapy (Phentolamine Induced Penile Erection).
Adrenergic agonists are mainly sympathomimetic due to their action on peripheral vascular or post-synaptic alpha receptors. However, certain adrenergic agonists (like clonidine) act as a sympatholytic due to their predominant action on pre-synaptic  2 receptors which inhibits the release of noradrenaline.
Options A and B: In hypotensive states like shock and acute decompensated heart failure, short-term therapy with parenteral sympathomimetic drugs are indicated in treatment.
Option C: Clonidine is an adrenergic agonist which acts on the pre-synaptic  2 receptor and is used in the treatment of hypertension.

[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 19:
Salbutamol is preferred over adrenaline in an asthmatic patient due to 2 selectivity.
This 2 selectivity is relative and lost at higher concentrations. Around 40% of the beta receptors are of 2 type and their activation won't cause cardiac stimulation.
Major adverse effects of non-selective -agonists are attributed to the stimulation of 1 receptors in the heart which result in tachyarrhythmias. Selective 2 receptor agonists are introduced to overcome this major drawback.

Adverse effects of beta 2 agonists:

A 4-year-old child on salbutamol is brought to the hospital with complaints of tremors. Which of the following effects of the drug would explain this side effect?
1, 2, and 5
2 and 4
1 and 2
3 and 5



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 23:

Tremors due to 2 agonists can be both due to direct action on muscle spindle and hypokalemia.
Initially, it was thought to be due to beta receptor-mediated enhancement of discharge of muscle spindles. However, recently the tremors have also been closely correlated with hypokalemia.
Hence both direct action and hypokalemia can explain the tremors associated with 2 agonist use,
although the exact mechanism is still not known.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 25:

A 68-year-old man with Parkinson's disease was prescribed mirabegron to control his symptoms of urinary urgency and incontinence. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
2 agonist
3 agonist
M3 receptor antagonist
M1 receptor antagonist


[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 25:
Mirabegron is a 3 agonist used for the treatment of overactive bladder (OAB). Stimulation of
3 receptors in detrusor muscle increases the bladder capacity and provides symptomatic relief in overactive bladder.
Antimuscarinic drugs are the mainstay of oral pharmacological treatment for OAB. It acts by inhibiting muscarinic receptor subtypes, M2 and M3 in the bladder. Both subtypes are expressed in multiple tissues, resulting in anticholinergic adverse events such as dry mouth, constipation, and cognitive impairment. These adverse effects are not seen with mirabegron as it acts via adrenergic receptors.
Mirabegron is a moderate inhibitor of CYP2D6. Hence, caution has to be exercised when prescribing it along with CYP2D6 substrates such as metoprolol, desipramine, digoxin.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 26:

What dose of epinephrine is used in anaphylactic shock?
1:10000 I.V. - 10 m
1:1000 I.M. - 0.5 m
1:1000 I.M. - 1 m
1:1000 I.V. - 0.5 m



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 26:
Epinephrine (1:1000 solution) 0.5 ml via intramuscular route is preferred in the treatment of anaphylactic shock.
For intravenous use, 1:1000 adrenaline must be further diluted to 1:10,000 and should be used very cautiously as slow bolus.
There is a much greater risk of causing harmful side effects by either inappropriate dosage or misdiagnosis of anaphylaxis when using IV adrenaline. Hence, IM injection is preferred over intravenous (IV) bolus because it is faster in many situations and safer (lower risk of cardiovascular complications, such as severe hypertension and ventricular arrhythmias).
For intramuscular, subcutaneous, and inhalational (nebulization) routes of administration, 1:1000 dilution can be used.

In cardiac arrest, the 1:1000 adrenaline must be diluted to 1:10,000 for IV use. The recommended dose of epinephrine is 1mg = 10 mL of 1:10,000 solution IV administered every 3 to 5 minutes during resuscitation as per the CPR guidelines.
Epinephrine is also used in the treatment of hypotension, to induce local vasoconstriction to reduce the diffusion of local anaesthetics and to induce bronchodilation in asthma and COPD.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 27:

A patient was treated for septicemia with norepinephrine infusion. Which of the following best explains the benefit of this drug?
Bradycardia
Tachycardia
Increases urine output
Increases mean arterial blood pressure



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 27:
The benefit of using noradrenaline in septicemia is that it increases the mean arterial blood pressure. It acts as a powerful peripheral vasoconstrictor and inotrope.
Noradrenaline causes a rise in both systolic BP and diastolic BP, resulting in a rise in the mean arterial blood pressure. This increases the organ perfusion in patients in septic shock
or cardiogenic shock.
Another advantage of noradrenaline is that it does so without causing tachycardia, which is often a troublesome event with other inotropes in critical care.
Options A and B: The rise in mean arterial pressure causes reflex bradycardia which is not a major contributor to the treatment of septic shock.
Option C: Low-dose dopamine infusions and furosemide are used to increase urine output in critically ill patients.



Epinephrine (1:1000 solution) 0.5 ml I.M. is preferred in the treatment of anaphylactic shock.
In cardiac arrest, the 1:1000 adrenaline must be diluted to 1:10,000 for IV route, and used cautiously.
Adrenaline in a concentration of 1: 50,000 to 1: 200,000 is added to local anesthetics for:
Reducing the systemic absorption
Prolonging the duration of action
Providing a more bloodless field for surgery
1:1000 dilution can be used for the following routes of administration:
Intramuscular
Subcutaneous
Inhalational (nebulization)
IM injection is preferred over intravenous (IV) bolus because it is faster in many situations and safer (ie, lower risk of cardiovascular complications, such as severe hypertension and ventricular arrhythmias). There is a much greater risk of causing harmful side effects by inappropriate dosage or misdiagnosis of anaphylaxis when using IV adrenaline.

Epinephrine is also used in the treatment of hypotension, to induce local vasoconstriction to reduce the diffusion of local anaesthetics, to induce bronchodilation in asthma and COPD.
Note: The recommended dose of epinephrine is 1mg = 10 mL of a 1:10,000 solution administered IV every 3 to 5 minutes during resuscitation as per the CPR guidelines. For nebulization, 1:1000 adrenaline is commonly used.

Parasympatholytics

subject: Pharmacology

AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 3:

Which of the following statements most appropriately describes the vasomotor reversal of Dale?
Stimulation of alpha 1 followed by stimulation of beta 2
Blockade of alpha 1 followed by stimulation of beta 2
Stimulation of alpha 1 followed by blockade of beta 2
Stimulation of beta 1 followed by blockade of beta 2



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 3:
Vasomotor reversal of Dale is a blockade of alpha ( 1) followed by stimulation of beta (2)
receptors.
Normally, a high dose of epinephrine injected produces an  1-mediated rise in BP followed by a
2-mediated fall in BP.
Administration of epinephrine after administration of  -blockers produces only a fall in BP. This is because the  -mediated response is abolished and hence, only the -mediated response is seen, resulting in a fall in BP. This phenomenon is called the vasomotor reversal of Dale. This was first demonstrated by Sir H.H.Dale.

Adrenaline

Noradrenaline
Dopamine
Dobutamine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 4:
Biphasic reaction on blood pressure is seen with the administration of adrenaline. The BP initially rises followed by a fall in BP.
Adrenaline acts on  1,  2, 1, 2, and 3 receptors.
 1 - present in blood vessels - causes vasoconstriction - increases BP.
2 - present in blood vessels - causes vasodilatation - decreases BP.
At higher concentrations of adrenaline, alpha action predominates and hence a rise in BP is seen. Therefore an increase in BP is seen with IV administration of adrenaline.
Due to rapid metabolism and uptake, the concentration of adrenaline decreases, and the 2 action predominates. Hence a decrease in BP is seen. This is referred to as the biphasic reaction.

[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
S ow intravenous infusion of adrenaline results in a significant increase in systolic blood pressure with minimal effect on diastolic pressure.
Mean blood pressure and pulse pressure increase. This is because of the increased systolic pressure coupled with decreased, unchanged, or an insignificant increase in diastolic pressure.
At lower concentrations of adrenaline, vascular 2 receptors are more sensitive than  receptors, hence peripheral resistance decreases.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 6:

Which of the following statements is incorrect?
IV noradrenaline increases systolic and diastolic BP and causes tachycardia
IV adrenaline increases systolic, decreases diastolic BP and causes tachycardia
Dopamine increases peripheral resistance and improves renal perfusion
IV isoproterenol increases systolic and decreases diastolic BP and causes tachycardia



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
IV noradrenaline increases systolic and diastolic BP but is unlikely to cause tachycardia. IV noradrenaline acts on  1,  2, and 1 receptors:
 1- vasoconstriction - Increases DBP.
1 - increases heart rate and contractility - Increases SBP.
This increases mean arterial pressure which causes a reflex vagal activity that decreases the heart rate leading to bradycardia.
IV adrenaline acts on  1,  2, 1, 2, and 3 receptors:
1 - increases SBP, tachycardia.
DBP - either 2 - decrease DBP,  1 - increase DBP or  1+2 - no change. Dopamine acts on 1, 1, and D1 receptors:
D1 - low concentrations - causes vasodilatation thus improving renal perfusion
1- positive inotropic effect - increases SBP.
 1 - higher infusion rates - causes vasoconstriction and increases peripheral resistance IV isoproterenol is a non-selective  receptor agonist:
1- increases SBP
2- vasodilatation - decreases DBP
1- tachycardia

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 7:

A patient in low output cardiogenic shock is being treated with dobutamine. Which of the following is true about the drug?
Dobutamine decreases peripheral resistance
Acts on D1 and D2 receptors
Decreases renal circulation
Has no effect on coronary circulation



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:

Dobutamine decreases peripheral resistance minimally.
Clinically, dobutamine increases cardiac output by selectively increasing myocardial contractility and promotes coronary vasodilation. This is associated with a mild decrease in total peripheral vascular resistance, which is mediated by the reflex withdrawal of sympathetic tone to the vasculature.
Dobutamine has a t1/2 of 2 minutes. It resembles dopamine but no action is seen on dopamine receptors.
Renal circulation is variably affected depending upon the sympathetic tone of the patient.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 8:

During a rotation in the acute medical ward, you observe a patient in cardiogenic shock being started on a low-dose dopamine infusion. Which of the following would you expect to increase in this patient?

Cardiac output
Urine output
Heart rate
Blood pressure



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:
At lower doses (< 2 g/kg), dopamine only stimulates dopamine receptors in renal vasculature, causing increased urine output.
As the dose increases (2-5 g/kg), additional cardiac stimulant action (1) is also seen. At very high doses (5-15 g/kg), vasoconstriction ( 1) is additionally seen.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 9:

A stress ECHO has to be done for a 56-year-old COPD patient with high suspicion of coronary artery disease. Which of the following drugs can be used to perform this test?
Thalium
Noradrenaline
Adrenaline
Dobutamine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 9:
Dobutamine is used to perform a stress test.
Stress echocardiography is primarily done for the evaluation of myocardial ischemia. The basic principle is to increase cardiac stress (either with exercise or with a drug) in a controlled fashion, to aid with the identification and localization of ischemic areas (by detecting new or worsening wall motion abnormalities).
Performing stress echocardiography with a pharmacologic agent such as dobutamine allows for simulation of increased heart rate and increased myocardial physiologic demands in patients who may be unable to exercise due to musculoskeletal or pulmonary comorbidities.
Dobutamine causes cardiac stress by acting on 1-adrenergic receptors to increase cardiac contractility and heart rate, and on 2-adrenergic receptors to cause peripheral vasodilatation. It is preferred over vasodilators used in stress echo tests such as adenosine, dipyridamole, and regadenoson (adenosine derivative).

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 10:

Which of the following describes the mechanism of mydriasis due to the instillation of a muscarinic antagonist?
Contraction of the sphincter pupillae of the iris

Paralysis of the dilator pupillae muscles of the iris
Contraction of the dilator pupillae muscles of the iris
Paralysis of the sphincter pupillae of the iris



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
Mydriatic action of a muscarinic antagonist is due to the paralysis of the sphincter pupillae (circular) muscle of the iris.
In the iris, miosis occurs due to the constriction of the pupillary sphincter muscles and mydriasis is due to the contraction of the dilator pupillae (radial) muscles. They counter-balance each other.
When muscarinic antagonists are instilled, the pupillary sphincter muscle is paralyzed, causing mydriasis due to the unopposed contraction of the dilator pupillae muscle.
Adrenergic alpha agonists also cause mydriasis, but by mediating the contraction of the dilator pupillae muscle of iris.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 11:

To achieve which of the following states will you use phenylephrine instead of atropine?
Mydriasis without cycloplegia
Only cycloplegia
Both mydriasis and cycloplegia
Mydriasis and controlled cycloplegia



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
Atropine is substituted by phenylephrine in situations where mydriasis is required without cycloplegia, like in fundoscopy.
Phenylephrine, an alpha 1 agonist, acts on the radial muscle (dilator pupillae) of the iris and causes isolated mydriasis. It has no cycloplegic action because sympathetic receptors are present only on the iris and not on the ciliary body.

Atropine has both mydriatic and cycloplegic action, which is required for refraction testing.
In elderly people who have a low ciliary tone, phenylephrine is preferred as a mydriatic. This is because other anticholinergics can precipitate or aggravate glaucoma by relaxation of the ciliary body and altering the forces acting on trabecular meshwork for aqueous outflow.
Atropine, cyclopentolate, and tropicamide are antimuscarinics that are available for ophthalmic use and cause cycloplegia to a variable extent. This cycloplegia/paralysis of accommodation occurs due to their parasympatholytic action, which decreases the tone of the ciliary body.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 12:

Which of the following is a short-acting mydriatic that you can use for performing a fundoscopy?
Atropine
Homatropine
Cyclopentolate
Tropicamide



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 12:
Tropicamide is a short-acting mydriatic used in fundoscopy.
It has a rapid onset (20-40 minutes) and a brief duration of action (3-6 hours). The cycloplegia produced by tropicamide is unreliable and insignificant. It is indicated for fundoscopy and refraction testing in adults who have a relatively low ciliary tone when compared to children.
Atropine, which produces complete cycloplegia, is preferred in children as they have a higher ciliary tone. Atropine is usually preferred over other mydriatics for accurate refractory error testing because of reliable cycloplegia. However, it can also precipitate an acute attack of glaucoma and should not be used in patients with glaucoma.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 13:

A 70-year-old diabetic patient presents to the OPD for diabetic retinopathy screening. Why would you prefer phenylephrine over other anticholinergic drugs as a mydriatic agent before performing fundoscopy?
High ciliary tone in elderly patients
Anticholinergics can precipitate glaucoma
Phenylephrine can decrease ciliary tone in elderly patients
All of the above



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 13:
Phenylephrine is preferred in elderly people as other anticholinergics can precipitate or aggravate glaucoma.
E derly people have low ciliary tone, and phenylephrine does not alter the tone of the ciliary body. Other anticholinergics cause relaxation of the ciliary body and alter the forces acting on trabecular meshwork for aqueous outflow.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 14:

A young man with a history of motion sickness presents to your OPD with upcoming plans for a road trip. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
Scopolamine patch one night before
Ondansetran one night before and also before trip
Domperidone on the previous night
Dimenhydrinate 1 hour before



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 14:
Scopolamine (Hyoscine) transdermal patch is the most appropriate treatment for motion sickness before a trip.
It should be applied behind the ear about 5-6 hours before the journey, and gives protection for around 72 hours against motion sickness, after which the patch can be replaced if necessary.
Scopolamine is also used for narcoanalysis as it causes sedation and amnesia.
Dimenhydrinate is a first-generation antihistamine that can also be used in motion sickness. Although dimenhydrinate may have equal efficacy it is not preferred because of its sedating properties.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 15:

Which of the following conditions can be treated with pirenzepine?
Asthma
Peptic ulcer disease
Glaucoma
Hypertension



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 15:
Pirenzepine is used for treating gastric ulcers. It is a selective M1 anticholinergic drug. It decreases gastric acid secretions at doses that have little effect on salivation or heart rate.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 16:

A 32-year-old woman diagnosed with diarrhoea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome presented to the casualty with severe abdominal pain. She was prescribed a drug that exerts a direct spasmolytic effect on the smooth muscles of the gastrointestinal tract. Which drug could it be?
Dicyclomine
Scopolamine
Galantamine
Rivastigmine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 16:
Dicyclomine is a weak muscarinic receptor antagonist with non-specific direct spasmolytic effects on the smooth muscle of the gastrointestinal tract.
Other options:
Option B: Scopolamine exerts spasmolytic activity indirectly through its antimuscarinic action. It is not preferred due to its adverse effects like drowsiness, dryness, and blurred vision.
Option C and D: Galantamine and rivastigmine are central cholinesterase inhibitors and do not possess spasmolytic activity.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Which of the following agents shows M3 receptor selectivity?
Oxybutynin
Trospium
Tolterodine
Solifenacin


[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 17:
M3 receptor selectivity is shown by solifenacin and darifenacin.
Oxybutynin and trospium do not show any selectivity. Tolterodine has a more specific action on the urinary bladder but subtype selectivity is absent.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 18:

Among the following antimuscarinic drugs used in the treatment of overactive bladder, which one shows direct spasmolytic activity on smooth muscles?
Tolterodine
Darifenacin
Oxybutynin
Solifenacin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 18:
Oxybutynin is an antimuscarinic drug indicated in the overactive bladder that also exerts a direct spasmolytic action on the smooth muscles of the bladder.
Direct spasmolytic activity is the direct smooth muscle relaxation effect independent of relaxation caused by antimuscarinic action.
The most important adverse effects caused by the use of muscarinic antagonists for an overactive bladder are xerostomia (most common reason for discontinuation), blurred vision, and GI side effects like constipation and dyspepsia (due to blockade of M1, M2 & M3). Drowsiness, dizziness, and confusion can also occur.
Tolterodine, darifenacin, and solifenacin are antimuscarinic agents but they do not have the additional direct antispasmodic effect.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Which of the following is not true regarding the effects of muscarinic antagonists on the urinary bladder?
Lowers intravesicular pressure

Lowers the frequency of bladder contractions
Alters bladder sensation during filling



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 19:
Muscarinic antagonists increase bladder capacity by blocking M3 receptors on the detrusor. This results in the relaxation of the bladder.

Effects of muscarinic antagonists on the bladder:
Lowers intravesicular pressure
Increases bladder capacity
Lowers the frequency of bladder contractions
Alters bladder sensation during filling

What is the scientific name of this plant whose roots & leaves were historically used in the treatment of asthma?


Atropa belladonna

Solution to Question 2:
The above plant is Datura stramonium, also called Jamestown or Jimsonweed.
The active ingredient in Datura stramonium includes anticholinergic alkaloids such as atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine. These were helpful in relieving the symptoms associated with asthma via inhibition of M3 receptors on bronchi, leading to a decrease in bronchospasm and tracheobronchial secretions.

Solution to Question 20:
Duloxetine is not useful in detrusor instability. It is a selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor that is efficacious in stress urinary incontinence. It is also indicated
in depression, fibromyalgia, and neuropathic pain.
Muscarinic antagonists are useful in this case. They increase bladder capacity by blocking M3 receptors on detrusor. This results in the relaxation of the bladder.

Lowering of intravesicular pressure
Increases bladder capacity

Xerostomia

Dyspepsia



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 21:
Xerostomia is the most common reason for the discontinuation of muscarinic antagonists in overactive bladder.
The most important adverse effects caused by the use of muscarinic antagonists for an overactive bladder are xerostomia, blurred vision, and GI side effects like constipation and dyspepsia (due to blockade of M1, M2 & M3). Drowsiness, dizziness, and confusion can also occur.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 22:

Which of the following has selective action on M1 and M3 receptors?
Ipratropium
Tiotropium
Atropine methonitrate
Umeclidinium



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 22:
Tiotropium has a selective action on M1 and M3 receptors.
Tiotropium binds to all M1, M2 and M3 receptors. However, it dissociates slower from M1 and M3 receptors as compared to M2. This shows it has a higher affinity towards M1 and M3 receptors.
Ipratropium and atropine methonitrate do not have any subtype selectivity on muscarinic receptors.
Inhibition of mucociliary clearance by atropine results in the accumulation of lower airway secretions and the formation of mucus plugs. However, tiotropium and ipratropium have minimum interference with mucociliary clearance when compared to atropine, and the incidence

of mucus plugs is also less.

In which of the following patients is the use of trospium contraindicated?
10-year-old boy with bronchial asthma

50-year-old woman with peptic ulcer disease



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 23:
The use of trospium is contraindicated in urinary retention. It is an antimuscarinic agent and can worsen urinary retention.
Muscarinic antagonists are contraindicated in urinary tract obstruction and in benign prostatic hyperplasia (or used with extreme caution).
Bronchial asthma, hypertension, and peptic ulcer disease are not the contraindications for the use of trospium.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 24:

Which of the following does not produce central anticholinergic syndrome?
Glycopyrrolate
Atropine
Antihistaminics
Tricyclic antidepressants



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 24:
Glycopyrrolate usually does not produce central anticholinergic syndrome. It is a quaternary amine compound and lipid insoluble. Therefore, glycopyrrolate does not cross the blood-brain barrier.
Non-depolarising skeletal muscle relaxants are used in anesthesia. Neostigmine along with glycopyrrolate are used for reversal of this neuromuscular block. Glycopyrrolate blocks the peripheral muscarinic side effects due to the increased acetylcholine levels after the administration of neostigmine, without causing unwanted central anticholinergic effects.
Peripheral and central anticholinergic syndromes are reactions due to either overdose or any unusual reaction to the usage of drugs like atropine and other muscarinic agents, phenothiazines, antihistamines, and tricyclic antidepressants
Option B: Atropine is a tertiary compound that can cross the blood-brain barrier and cause central anticholinergic syndrome.
Option C and D: Some of the first-generation antihistamines and tricyclic antidepressants have significant anticholinergic activity and can cause central anticholinergic syndrome.

subject: Pharmacology

Which of the following is most commonly used for narcoanalysis?
Atropine sulfate
Pentothal sodium
Phenobarbitone
Scopolamine hydrochloride


[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 25:
The most commonly used drug in narcoanalysis is pentothal sodium (thiopentone).
Other drugs used in narcoanalysis are sodium amytal and secobarbital.
Scopolamine hydrochloride was also used in narcoanalysis during World War II. It was popularly known as the 'lie detector'. The amnesic and depressant actions of scopolamine are due to the inhibition of the brain cholinergic system. It would put the subject off guard in case of sustained interrogation and sleep deprivation, eventually forcing the truth out.

Both ipratropium and tiotropium have a minimal inhibitory effect on mucociliary clearance when compared to atropine. Inhibition of mucociliary clearance by atropine results in accumulation of lower airway secretions and formation of mucus plugs.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 3:

On administration of atropine, which of the following effects is unlikely?
Increased bowel sounds
Mydriasis
Dry mouth
Tachycardia



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 3:

Atropine does not cause increased bowel sounds. It decreases the amplitude and frequency of peristalsis, resulting in decreased bowel sounds.
Peristalsis suppression due to atropine is incomplete because of the additional control of peristalsis by local reflexes in the enteric nervous system and involvement of other neurotransmitters like 5-HT, encephalin, dopamine in peristalsis.
Actions of atropine:
Mydriasis - by blocking the contraction of sphincter pupillae muscle
Decreased secretions from salivary glands and lacrimal glands - by blocking M1 & M3 receptors
Tachycardia - due to its vagolytic activity at M2 receptor
Decreased sweating - by inhibiting sympathetic cholinergic supply to sweat glands which makes the skin hot and dry (atropine fever).

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 4:

While treating a patient with acute myocardial infarction, an abnormal rhythm was noted on the ECG. The senior resident decides to administer atropine to control this. What was the likely rhythm observed in the patient?
Sinus tachycardia
Sinus bradycardia
Ventricular arrhythmias
Atrial fibrillation



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 4:
Atropine is indicated in acute myocardial infarction when it is accompanied by sinus bradycardia due to excessive vagal tone. It is seen commonly in inferior or posterior wall myocardial infarction.
The dosage of atropine has to be carefully adjusted when used in a patient with myocardial infarction. If the dose is too low it will aggravate the bradycardia by action on presynaptic M1 receptors. If the dose is too high it will cause significant tachycardia and aggravate the condition by competitive inhibition of postsynaptic M2 receptors.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 5:

You administer atropine at a dose of 0.5 mg IV to a patient with symptomatic bradycardia. What would be the effect on heart rate?
Transient tachycardia followed by bradycardia
Transient bradycardia followed by tachycardia
Mild tachycardia
Worsening bradycardia



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
Atropine at average clinical doses of 0.4-0.6 mg administered parenterally results in transient bradycardia followed by tachycardia.
Parasympathetic postganglionic nerve terminals in the SA node contain presynaptic M1 receptors. These receptors normally inhibit the release of ACh. Therefore stimulation of these receptors decreases the release of ACh causing tachycardia. Inhibition of these receptors increases ACh causing bradycardia.
Atropine initially blocks these presynaptic M1 receptors. This increases the amount of ACh released at the SA node and causes bradycardia. Then, the progressive increase in the atropine concentration blocks the postsynaptic M2 receptors on the SA node (decreasing the ACh release) decreasing the parasympathetic tone, thereby causing tachycardia.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 6:

A delirious child was rushed to the ER with a history of ingestion of an unknown plant. On examination, his pulse rate was 150 beats per minute, and his skin was warm and dry. Pupils were dilated and bowel sounds were sluggish. Which of the following toxidromes is likely to be responsible for the symptoms in this child?
Anticholinergic
Sympathomimetic
Opioid

Sedative-Hypnotic



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:

Mydriasis, tachycardia, dry mouth, atropine fever (warm, hot skin) and delirium are classical symptoms of anticholinergic overdose following the ingestion of plants that contain belladonna alkaloids.
Physostigmine is the drug of choice for the treatment of atropine and belladonna poisoning.


Option B: Sympathomimetics can cause mydriasis and tachycardia. Hyperthermia can be seen secondary to increased agitation and aggressive movements. However, delirium is rare and bowel sounds would be normal or increased in sympathomimetic toxidromes.
Option C: Opioid overdose results in decreased bowel sounds but other symptoms are not seen.
Option D: In sedative-hypnotic toxidrome, CNS depression and reduced bowel sounds are seen. But it does not cause tachycardia or change in pupil diameter.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Which of the following would you use in the treatment of atropine toxicity?
Pralidoxime
Naloxone
Flumazeni
Physostigmine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:
Atropine toxicity is treated with physostigmine, a reversible anticholinesterase agent.
Physostigmine acts by decreasing the breakdown of acetylcholine, and it also overcomes the competitive blockade of atropine in all muscarinic receptors.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

You are monitoring a patient being treated with atropine for alleged consumption of an organophosphate compound. Suddenly he develops marked excitement and claims to see his late wife sitting next to him. All of the following can be used in the management of this patient except?
Physostigmine
Lorazepam

The clinical features of marked excitement and hallucinations are seen in atropine toxicity. Chlorpromazine should be avoided in patients with atropine toxicity.
Chlorpromazine is a low potency typical antipsychotic having high anticholinergic activity. Administering phenothiazines like chlorpromazine will worsen atropine toxicity.


Option A: Physostigmine is indicated as first-line therapy for atropine intoxication
Option B and D: Benzodiazepines can be used when marked excitement is present to calm down the patient

subject: Pharmacology

In which of the following conditions is propanolol not indicated?
Infantile hemangioma
Variant angina
Essential tremors
Portal hypertension



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
Propranolol is not indicated in variant angina. It can cause further constriction of coronary arteries by leaving alpha-mediated coronary vasoconstriction unopposed.
Uses of propranolol include:
Management of thyrotoxicosis
Management of hypertension (however, cardioselective beta-blockers are now preferred over non-selective)
Treatment of infantile hemangioma
Management of essential tremors and panic attacks
Prophylaxis of migraine
Prevention of variceal bleeding in portal hypertension

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 11:

A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus during a routine health evaluation. He mentions that he is on propranolol for essential tremors. You would caution him against continuing the drug due to what reason?
Causes hypertension
Causes seizures
Masks hypoglycemic symptoms
Causes hypotension



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
Propranolol is generally avoided in diabetic patients because it masks the hypoglycaemic symptoms.
Non-selective  blockers interfere with the counter-regulatory hormones secreted during hypoglycemia, resulting in prolonged hypoglycemia. It also decreases the perception of symptoms such as tremors, tachycardia, and nervousness. These symptoms are manifested due to stimulation of sympathetic beta receptors in response to hypoglycemia. Blunting of sympathetic response results in hypoglycemic unawareness.
Cardioselective beta-blockers have relatively lesser interference on the sympathetic response to hypoglycemia and are preferred in diabetic patients.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 12:

Propranolol is drug of choice for:
Ulcerated infantile hemangioma
Lymphangioma circumscriptum
Capillary malformation
Pyogenic granuloma



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 12:
Propranolol is the drug of choice in the management of infantile hemangioma complicated by ulceration or in symptomatic patients.
It acts by causing vasoconstriction, inducing apoptosis and inhibition of angiogenesis.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Nebivolol is a third-generation, long-acting, and highly selective 1 adrenergic receptor antagonist

It stimulates NO-mediated vasodilation via 3 receptor agonism
Nebivolol is approved for the treatment of hypertension
It has potential utility in the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
Nebivolol reduces oxidative stress and may have favorable effects on both carbohydrate and lipid metabolism
This can be used in metabolic syndrome.

3, 5
3, 4, 5
1, 2, 3, 5



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 14:
Esmolol is a short-acting cardioselective beta-blocker that is indicated in:
Prevention and management of intraoperative tachycardia
Postoperative hypertension
Supraventricular tachycardia
Hypertensive emergency
It is contraindicated in pulmonary hypertension.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 15:

Which of the following is a false statement?
Metoprolol prolongs survival in congestive cardiac failure
Celiprolol has vasodilatory property
Esmolol is mainly metabolised in the liver
Nebivolol releases nitric oxide



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 15:
Esmolol contains an ester linkage and it is hydrolyzed rapidly by esterases in erythrocytes and not in the liver. This results in a short half-life of about 8-10 minutes.
It is used in the management of intraoperative and postoperative hypertension as it has a short duration of action and can be discontinued quickly.
Option A: Metoprolol is approved for use in chronic congestive cardiac failure and has shown mortality benefit.
Option B: Celiprolol has shown a relaxant effect on vascular smooth muscle and weak vasodilation due to partial selective 2 agonism.
Option D: Nebivolol has the additional action of releasing nitric oxide.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Identify the third-generation beta-blocker that does not cause alpha 1 receptor antagonism.

Labetalo
Carvedilo
Celiprolo
Bucindolo



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 16:
Celiprolol is a third-generation beta blocker having no action on  1 receptors. It causes vasodilation by partial selective 2 agonist activity.
Labetalol, carvedilol, and bucindolol are non-selective third-generation beta blockers that possess additional  1 receptor antagonistic action. This is responsible for their vasodilatory effect.
Note: Third-generation -blockers are those that possess additional vasodilating actions and include cardioselective and non-selective drugs.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 17:

You are about to add a beta-blocker to the treatment chart of a patient with heart failure. Which of the following is not true about the use of these drugs in this condition?
Should be continued after discharge
Most effective in acute decompensated heart failure
Should be started at a low dose
Carvedilol is widely used in this condition



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 17:
-blockers are contraindicated in the treatment of acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF) as they can worsen the condition. They are indicated only in patients with chronic stable heart failure.
Option A: Though contraindicated in ADHF, it is safe to start once the patient is euvolemic. Initiation of -blocker prior to discharge is associated with improved outcomes and must be continued after discharge.
Option C: -blockers are initiated at a low dose and slowly titrated to decrease the risk of precipitating heart failure.
Option D: Carvedilol has been shown to reduce mortality in patients with heart failure, and is widely used because of additional benefits like antioxidant properties and peripheral vasodilatory action.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Which of the following is not true about beta-blockers?
Atenolol is longer acting than metoprolo
Labetalol has both alpha and beta blocking action
Celiprolol undergoes hepatic elimination
Nadolol has longest half life



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 18:
Celiprolol is excreted predominantly through the renal route. It is excreted unchanged in the urine.
Option A: Atenolol is longer acting with a longer half-life than metoprolol. It is usually administered once daily.
Option C: Labetalol is a non-selective -blocker with  1 blocking action similar to carvedilol. Option D: Nadolol has the longest half-life of 20 hours and is administered once daily.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

A nurse in the nephrology ward is managing the drug inventory for patients with severe renal failure. Which of the following beta-blockers is least likely to be present in the drug charts?
Carvedilo
Metoprolo
Sotalo
Labetalo



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 19:
Sotalol is least likely to be present in the treatment charts as it is contraindicated in severe renal failure. It has low lipid solubility and is excreted primarily unchanged in the urine.
Carvedilol, metoprolol and labetalol are metabolised by the liver and can be used in renal failure.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding prazosin?
Blocks all subtypes of alpha 1 receptors
It is only an arteriolar dilator
It has a beneficial effect on lipid profile
Causes minimal reflex tachycardia



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 2:
Prazosin causes dilation of both arterioles and veins.
As a result, both afterload and preload decrease. However, the reflex tachycardia is less pronounced due to the absence of  2 blockade.
Prazosin blocks all subtypes of the  1 receptor ( 1A,  1B, and  1D). It also has a beneficial effect on lipid profile as it decreases LDL and triglycerides and increases HDL levels.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

22-year-old singer with performance anxiety



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 20:
Beta-blockers are not indicated in hypothyroidism. They are indicated in hyperthyroidism and thyrotoxicosis that manifests with increased sympathetic activity.
Options B and C: Beta-blockers are useful in the treatment of alcohol withdrawal and in reducing variceal bleeding in portal hypertension.
Option D:  blockers like propranolol are effective in controlling acute panic symptoms and anxiety associated with performing in public. They reduce symptoms of increased sympathetic

activity such as tachycardia and tremors.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Cocaine-like effect of inhibiting neuronal uptake of noradrenaline is seen with which of the following?

Non-selective  receptor blockade
Selective  1 receptor blockade
Inhibition of neuronal uptake of NE/cocaine-like effect



Pindolol is a non-selective first-generation -blocker with significant intrinsic agonist activity, which may result in a smaller reduction in heart rate and blood pressure. This is useful in patients with diminished cardiac reserve or at risk of bradycardia.
Carvedilol is a non-selective third-generation -blocker with antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. These properties make it useful in the treatment of congestive heart failure.
Betaxolol is a 1 selective third-generation -blocker with additional calcium entry blockade activity and a slight membrane-stabilizing property. It does not have agonist activity.
Acebutolol is a 1 selective second-generation  blocker having both membrane-stabilizing and intrinsic agonist activity. It is useful in the treatment of atrial and ventricular arrhythmias.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 3:

In which of the following patients would prazosin not be used therapeutically?
45-year-old man with peripheral vascular disease
25-year-old woman with pheochromocytoma
30-year-old male with ejaculatory dysfunction
10-year-old boy stung by a scorpion



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 3:
Prazosin is not useful to treat a patient with ejaculatory dysfunction. It is indicated in relieving symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
Prazosin is an  1 receptor antagonist and is useful in:
Relieving vasospasm in peripheral vascular diseases
Controlling the symptoms of pheochromocytoma preoperatively (as an alternative to phenoxybenzamine)
Mainstay treatment for scorpion sting along with antivenom

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 4:

A patient presents with complaints of dizziness while getting up from bed. He tells you he was recently diagnosed with BPH and has been taking prazosin. Which of the following drugs would be a good replacement for him?
Terazosin
Silodosin

Doxazosin
Alfuzosin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 4:
The given scenario is suggestive of postural hypotension caused by prazosin. These symptoms can be avoided by using silodosin which has a selective antagonist action on  1A receptors over  1B receptors.
The prostate stroma has a maximum concentration of  1A receptors over other  1 receptor subtypes.  1B receptors are present on blood vessels which play a role in vasoconstriction. Hence, selective  1A receptor antagonists have minimal effect on blood pressure as compared to
non-selective  1 antagonists like prazosin.
 1 receptor antagonists can be classified as:
Selective antagonists
Silodosin ( 1A)
Tamsulosin ( 1A +  1D)
Non-selective
Prazosin
Terazosin
Doxazosin
Alfuzosin

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 5:

A 62-year-old male presents with complaints of a weak urine stream and frequent urination in small amounts for the past month. He also mentions that he often feels lightheaded and has low blood pressure. Which of the following alpha-blockers will you prefer to give him?
Alfuzosin
Terazosin
Tamsulosin
Doxazosin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
The given scenario is suggestive of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and tamsulosin should be given to this patient as it has the least effect on blood pressure.
It is an  -blocker that has more selectivity towards  1A/1D when compared to  1B receptors. The vasodilatory effects are mainly attributed to the blockade of  1B receptors present on blood vessels.
The relief of BPH symptoms is mainly due to the blockade of  1A receptors present predominantly in the prostatic stroma. It lacks the apoptotic effect on prostatic cells that is seen with terazosin and doxazosin.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 6:

You prescribe tamsulosin to a patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia. What is the main side effect that should be explained to the patient?
Priapism
Postural hypotension
Retrograde ejaculation
Erectile dysfunction



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
Retrograde ejaculation is the main side effect of tamsulosin.
It is a selective  1A/1D blocker and the relief of BPH symptoms is mainly due to blockade of  1A receptors. Blockade of  1D receptors present in the bladder relaxes the urethral sphincter, which is normally closed during ejaculation. This results in the redirection of semen into the urinary bladder.

Silodosin causes ejaculatory dysfunction due to absence of seminal emission.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 7:

Which of the following is a selective alpha 2 receptor antagonist?
Terazosin
Yasmin
Yohimbine
Alfuzosin



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:
Yohimbine is a competitive antagonist that is selective for  2 receptors. It was earlier used in the indication of erectile dysfunction but is rarely indicated now due to better results with PDE5 inhibitors.
Terazosin and alfuzosin are selective alpha 1 receptor antagonists.
Yasmin (drospirenone) is a 4th generation progestin used as an oral contraceptive having mineralocorticoid antagonist action.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 8:

Phenoxybenzamine is indicated in the management of which of the following conditions?
Pheochromocytoma

Essential hypertension
Erectile dysfunction
All of the above



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:
Phenoxybenzamine is indicated in the preoperative preparation of patients with pheochromocytoma. It is also indicated for symptomatic control in inoperable and advanced pheochromocytoma.
Option B: Phenoxybenzamine is not used in the management of essential hypertension because of the irreversible alpha blockade and increased risk of adverse effects.
Option C: For erectile dysfunction, intracavernous phentolamine, a reversible non-selective alpha-blocker is indicated.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 9:

A patient with erectile dysfunction complained of unsatisfactory response to oral medication. He was then administered an intracavernosal injection of phentolamine following which he developed sustained painful erection. Which of the following can be used to reverse his condition?
Phenoxybenzamine
Prazosin
Phenylephrine
Propranolo



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 9:
The reversal of phentolamine induced priapism (painful erection) can be achieved by intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine.
Intracavernosal phentolamine ( -blocker) is used for the management of impotency. Priapism is a serious adverse effect of this agent. Phenylephrine is an  agonist and counteracts phentolamine induced priapism by producing vasoconstriction.
Phentolamine is useful in:
Hypertensive crisis due to clonidine withdrawa
Short term control of intra-operative hypertension in patients with pheochromocytoma
MAO inhibitor-induced hypertension in cheese reaction
Options A and B: Phenoxybenzamine and prazosin are  -receptor antagonists and can worsen priapism.
Option D: Propranolol is a non-selective -blocker and is not indicated in this condition.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

You want to prescribe a drug that increases uveo-scleral outflow while treating a patient with open-angle glaucoma. Which of the following drugs would you choose?
Prostaglandin analogues
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

Beta-blockers



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 1:
The class of anti-glaucoma drugs which act by increasing the uveo-scleral outflow are prostaglandin analogues.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 10:

Which of the following antiglaucoma medications is unsafe in infants?
Timolol
Brimonidine
Latanoprost
Dorzolamide



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 10:
The use of brimonidine is unsafe in infants. It is an alpha-2 agonist that can cross the blood-brain barrier. This may result in CNS depression and apnoea in neonates. Therefore it is contraindicated in children less than 2 years.
 2 agonists, through the activation of G-protein coupled receptor activation, inhibit the activity of adenylate cyclase. This reduces cAMP and hence reduces aqueous humor production by ciliary action.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 11:

Which of the following can be administered orally for the treatment of glaucoma?
1 and 5
1, 2 and 3
2, 3 and 4
1, 2, 3, 4, 5



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 11:
Acetazolamide and methazolamide are carbonic anhydrase inhibitors that can be used orally in the treatment of glaucoma.
Acetazolamide can also be administered intravenously.
Dorzolamide and brinzolamide are topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitors.
Dichlorphenamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor approved for the treatment of familial periodic paralysis.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 12:

Intravenous mannitol is used in 	?
Pulmonary edema
Congestive cardiac failure
Acute kidney injury with anuria
Glaucoma



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 12:
Intravenous mannitol is used for the treatment of acute attacks of glaucoma. Uses of mannitol are:
To reduce cerebral edema and intracranial pressure
Enhancement of urinary excretion of salicylates, barbiturates, bromides, and lithium
Diagnosis of bronchial hyperreactivity (inhalation)
Antihemolytic urological irrigation during transurethral procedures
Treatment of acute attacks of glaucoma.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 13:

Which of the following drugs should not be given in a patient prone to developing angle-closure glaucoma?
Pilocarpine
Clozapine
Rivastigmine
Neostigmine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 13:
Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic having significant anticholinergic action. Drugs having significant anticholinergic action should be avoided or used with extreme caution in patients prone to developing acute angle-closure glaucoma.
The anticholinergic action results in the relaxation of the sphincter pupillae muscle. This results in the iris coming in contact with the lens and thereby obstructing the movement of the aqueous from the posterior to the anterior chamber.
This results in bulging of the iris and further leads to the obliteration of the narrow iridocorneal angle. This blocks the outflow of aqueous precipitating an acute attack of glaucoma.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 14:

While examining a patient using a corneal esthesiometer, you find that corneal sensations are decreased. Which of the following drugs could have led to this adverse effect?
Beta blockers
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
Cholinomimetics
Prostaglandin analogs



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 14:
Corneal hypoesthesia is a side effect of ocular beta-blockers.
For topical use in glaucoma, beta-blockers with no/minimal membrane-stabilizing action are used. This is the reason why propranolol is not formulated for ocular use. It has the highest membrane-stabilizing action and causes maximum corneal hypoesthesia if used.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 15:

A patient presents with severe eye pain to the ophthalmology OPD. On examination, there is circumcorneal congestion and the IOP is 40 mm Hg. Which of the following drugs should not be administered immediately to this patient?
Acetazolamide
Timolol
Latanoprost
Pilocarpine


[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 15:
The given scenario is suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma. Pilocarpine should not be administered immediately in this condition.
During an acute attack, the elevated pressure in the anterior chamber causes pressure-induced ischemic paralysis of the iris. Pilocarpine would be ineffective in this phase.
Once the IOP is reduced by other agents and reperfusion is achieved, pilocarpine can be used to overcome the pupillary block.
Pilocarpine is avoided in conditions like pseudo-exfoliation syndrome, phacomorphic glaucoma, and aqueous misdirection syndrome as it may exacerbate pupillary block in such cases.
Topical beta-blockers, alpha-2 agonists and prostaglandin analogs can be used to decrease the IOP initially at presentation. Oral or intravenous acetazolamide can also be used.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 16:

A patient who is on treatment for glaucoma presented with the following finding during his routine follow-up. Which of the following drugs can cause this adverse effect?


Timolol
Latanoprost
Brimonidine
Apraclonidine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 16:
The patient has presented with lid retraction which is most likely caused by the use
of apraclonidine. It is a congener of clonidine that has primary  2 agonist action and a subsidiary
 1 agonist action.
Adverse effects like mydriasis and lid retraction are common with apraclonidine.

Brimonidine is also a congener of clonidine with more  2 selectivity. Mydriasis and lid retraction are uncommon with this agent.
Timolol and latanoprost do not cause lid retraction.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 17:

The ophthalmologic examination of a patient who is on anti-glaucoma drugs shows the following finding. Identify the drug that might have resulted in this adverse effect.



Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
Anticholinesterase agents
Muscaranic antagonists
Sympathomimetic agents



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 17:
The ophthalmological examination shows a pearly white opacity of the lens suggestive of cataract. Anticholinesterase agents like echothiophate and cholinergic agonists like pilocarpine are known to be associated with cataract formation.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 18:

A patient who is on anti-glaucoma therapy presents with corneal findings as shown in the image below. This finding is most commonly observed with which of the following drugs?


Timolol

Apraclonidine
Netarsudil
Brimonidine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 18:
The bilateral whorl-like pattern of cream-colored lines on the cornea seen in the image is called cornea verticillata or vortex keratopathy. It is observed with the use of netarsudil. It is usually mild and reversible and not associated with any significant visual abnormalities.
Netarsudil is approved for lowering intraocular pressure in patients with open-angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension.
Other causes of corneal verticillata are:
Fabry’s disease
Amiodarone
Chloroquine
Hydroxychloroquine
Indomethacin
Phenothiazines.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 19:

A patient on treatment for glaucoma presented with complaints of floaters and flashing lights. He complains of seeing a dark grey curtain move across his field of vision. Which of the following can lead to this condition?
Beta-blockers
Prostaglandin analogs
Cholinergic agonists
Muscarinic antagonists



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 19:
The given scenario is suggestive of retinal detachment. It is associated with the use of miotics i.e., both cholinergic agonists and anticholinesterase agents.
Miotics produce ciliary body contraction which can lead to altered forces at the vitreous base resulting in retinal tears. Hence, they are to be used with extreme caution in patients who are at risk of developing retinal detachment.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 2:

Which of the following anti-glaucoma agents has no effect on aqueous outflow?
Netarsudil
Timolol
Brimonidine
Latanoprost



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 2:
Timolol is a non-selective beta-blocker. Beta-blockers reduce intra-ocular pressure primarily by reducing aqueous humor production. Another hypothesis states that by reducing ocular blood flow, there may be a decrease in ultrafiltration responsible for aqueous production.
Netarsudil is a rho-kinase inhibitor that acts by increasing trabecular outflow.
Brimonidine is an alpha-agonist that has a small effect on increasing both uveoscleral and trabecular outflow.
Latanoprost is a prostaglandin PGF2-alpha analog that primarily acts by releasing matrix metalloproteinases, thereby increasing trabecular and uveoscleral outflow.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 20:

Your friend who is on treatment for glaucoma tells you that she feels her eyes look prettier than before. On examination, you notice increased iris pigmentation and eyelash hypertrichosis. Which of the following drugs is associated with this effect?
Pilocarpine
Acetazolamide
Brimonidine
Bimatoprost



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 20:
Bimatoprost is a PGF-2 alpha analog. PGF-2 alpha analogs are associated with eyelash hypertrichosis and iris hyperpigmentation.

Bimatoprost is approved for topical application in the treatment of eyelash hypotrichosis.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 21:

What is the most probable diagnosis in a patient with a dilated pupil not responsive to 1% pilocarpine?
Diabetic 3rd nerve palsy
Adie’s tonic pupil
Uncal herniation
Pharmacological block



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 21:
The most appropriate answer would be a pharmacological block. Antimuscarinic will occupy the receptors and results in non-responsiveness to pilocarpine.
In diabetic third nerve palsy, the dilated pupil is due to the loss of innervation to constrictor pupillae. Muscarinic receptors on constrictor pupillae will be intact resulting in miosis by pilocarpine.
In Adie's tonic pupil, there is denervation hypersensitivity. Pupil responds to even lower concentrations of pilocarpine.
Uncal herniation causes pressure on the third nerve leading to ipsilateral mydriasis. But muscarinic receptors are intact and thus the pupil responds to pilocarpine.



Dexamethasone is a long-acting glucocorticoid and is not used to decrease the intraocular pressure in glaucoma.
Acetazolamide, apraclonidine, and mannitol are used in lowering intraocular pressure in glaucoma.

Anti-Anginal Drugs

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:

Which of the following cannot be used to decrease intraocular pressure in glaucoma?
Dexamethasone
Acetazolamide

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 3:

Dipevefrine is a prodrug of 	.
Noradrenaline
Adrenaline
Clonidine
Dopamine



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 3:
Dipivefrine is a prodrug of adrenaline (epinephrine).
Adrenaline has poor corneal penetration. Dipivefrine penetrates the cornea and is converted into adrenaline by the esterases.
Adrenaline lowers intraocular pressure by:
Increasing trabecular outflow - beta-2 receptor-mediated.
Increasing both trabecular and uveoscleral outflow, and decreasing aqueous production - alpha eceptor-mediated.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 4:

What is the primary mechanism of action of topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitors in glaucoma?
Increasing trabecular outflow
Increasing uveoscleral outflow

Reducing aqueous formation
Relaxation of trabecular meshwork



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 4:
The primary mechanism of action of topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitors in glaucoma
is reducing the aqueous formation. Topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitors act by inhibiting type II isoenzyme of carbonic anhydrase in ciliary body epithelium. This leads to a reduction in fluid transport and decreases aqueous formation and IOP.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 5:

A 40-year old man who is suffering from open-angle glaucoma reads about netarsudil being approved as a novel agent for his condition. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
Carbonic anhydrase inhibition
Phosphodiesterase 5 inhibition
Rho kinase inhibition
GPCR inhibition



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 5:
Netarsudil is a rho kinase inhibitor that acts by relaxing the trabecular meshwork. This increases the outflow of aqueous humor and reduces intraocular pressure.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 6:

A patient who was started on treatment for glaucoma comes to the casualty with acute onset breathlessness. On auscultation, bilateral wheeze is heard. Which of the following drugs might have led to this adverse effect?
Timolol
Betaxolol
Latanaprost
Acetazolamide



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute bronchial asthma which was most likely precipitated by timolol.
Timolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that reduces intraocular pressure by decreasing aqueous formation. It precipitates bronchial asthma in susceptible individuals by beta-2 blockade.
Betaxolol is a beta-1 selective blocker that is used in glaucoma and has a lower propensity to precipitate bronchial asthma.
Latanoprost is a prostaglandin (PGF-2 alpha) analog and does not precipitate bronchial asthma. Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and does not precipitate bronchial asthma.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 7:

A patient with diabetic macular edema developed glaucoma. Which of the following drugs would you consider giving last?
Beta blocke
Alpha agonist
Pilocarpine
Prostaglandin analogues



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 7:
Prostaglandin analogs are the last drugs to be considered in this patient since macular edema is one of their side effects.
Adverse effects of PGF 2alpha analogs are:
Blurring of vision
Macular edema (especially in aphakic patients)
Eyelash hypertrichosis
Iris pigmentation (Heterochromia iridis)
Peri-orbital fat depletion

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 8:

Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line medical therapy in a patient with open-angle glaucoma?
Beta blockers
Miotics
PGF 2 alpha analogs
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 8:
The most appropriate first-line medical therapy for open-angle glaucoma is PGF-2 alpha analogs.
They act by increasing the aqueous outflow. They have largely replaced beta-blockers and can be considered as first-line agents for open-angle glaucoma because of their following properties:
Once-daily dosing
Low incidence of systemic side effects
Potent IOP-lowering effect
When the use of PGF-2 alpha analogs or beta-blockers is contraindicated, topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitors or alpha-2 agonists are used.

subject: Pharmacology
explanation:
AI Processing Failed. Raw: Question 9:

You diagnose a patient with primary open-angle glaucoma and decide to prescribe a PGF2 alpha analog. Which of the following drugs would you not choose?
Bimatoprost
Travoprost
Dinoprost
Tafluprost



[EXPLANATION START]
Solution to Question 9:

Dinoprost is a derivative of natural PGF-2 alpha. It is indicated in the termination of pregnancy and post-partum hemorrhage and not for use in glaucoma.
PGF2 alpha analogs that are used topically for the treatment of glaucoma are:
Latanoprost
Bimatoprost
Travoprost
Tafluprost
